Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To prevail on an alter-ego claim under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show (1) that the parent and the subsidiary operated as a single economic entity and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law governing alter-ego claims, among the factors indicative of whether two corporations operate as a single economic entity are whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Former employee alleged that employer would not have laid her off but for her age, as required to state disparate-treatment claim under ADEA.

Title: Washington v. Jay Street Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To establish that two entities are alter egos of each other, one must demonstrate that one of the entities controls the other or that the two operate as a single integrated entity.

Title: Riad v. Porsche Cars North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Proving that a corporation is merely an alter ego is a burden that is notoriously difficult for plaintiffs to meet; in order to succeed on an alter ego theory of liability, plaintiffs must essentially demonstrate that in all aspects of the business, the two corporations actually functioned as a single entity and should be treated as such.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. Specific personal jurisdiction did not exist over automobile manufacturer, in action related to injuries owner suffered due to defect with used car.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, parties are not jointly liable for a corporation's obligations merely because they were part of a single business enterprise, that is, merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; rather, disregarding the corporate structure involves two considerations: (1) the relationship between the two entities and (2) whether the entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Headnote: As opposed to alter ego doctrine, which pierces the corporate veil to reach the members of a limited liability company (LLC), the single business enterprise doctrine is a theory for imposing liability on two or more business entities when they act as one.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Cam-Carson, LLC v. Carson Reclamation Authority
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: In determining whether alter ego liability can be found between affiliated companies under the single-enterprise rule, factors for the trial court to consider include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Performance and Breach. Land developer alleged that city and city reclamation authority were alter egos for purposes of developer's claim for breach of contract.

Title: Cam-Carson, LLC v. Carson Reclamation Authority
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: If private corporations are operated with integrated resources in pursuit of a single business purpose, and one of them so dominated the finances, policies and practices of the other that the latter had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, but was merely a conduit through which the former conducted its business, then alter ego liability may exist if an inequitable result would otherwise follow.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Performance and Breach. Land developer alleged that city and city reclamation authority were alter egos for purposes of developer's claim for breach of contract.

Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of alter ego claim against owners of corporate entity under Delaware law, factors to be considered in determining whether owners and corporation operate as single economic entity are whether: (1) corporation was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; (2) corporation was solvent; (3) dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) the owner siphoned corporate funds; and (5) generally, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Mortgage bank knowingly refused to close on merger agreement with title insurance company, as required for breach of parties' agreement.

Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The thrust of the "enterprise liability doctrine" is that, just as a corporation's owner or owners may be held liable for judgments against the corporation when equity requires, so may affiliated or "sister" corporations-corporations with common ownership, engaged in a unitary commercial endeavor-be held liable for each other's debts or judgments.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under the enterprise theory for piercing the corporate veil to reach a corporation's affiliated entities, two or more corporations are treated as one because of [1] identity of ownership, [2] unified administrative control, [3] similar or supplementary business functions, [4] involuntary creditors, and [5] insolvency of the corporation against which the claim lies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Among factors that Louisiana courts consider in deciding whether liability may be imposed on a "single business enterprise" theory are presence or absence of the following: (1) identity or substantial identity of ownership; (2) common officers or directors; (3) unified administrative control; (4) directors and officers who act independently in interest of that one corporation; (5) intercorporate financing; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) one corporation's involvement in incorporation of another affiliate; (8) payment by one corporation of salaries and other expenses or losses of another; (9) fact that one corporation receives no business except that provided by affiliate; (10) one corporation's use of property of another as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees or offices; (13) centralized accounting; and (14) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Title: United States v. Kindred Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must essentially demonstrate that in all aspects of the business, the two corporations actually functioned as a single entity and should be treated as such.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator sufficiently alleged that nursing home operators knew staffing levels they mandated made it impossible to provide for their residents' needs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: City of Long Beach v. Total Gas & Power North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To prevail on an alter ego claim under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show (1) that the parent and the subsidiary operated as a single economic entity and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Monopolies. City that traded natural gas derivatives lacked antitrust standing to pursue Sherman Act claims against traders based on manipulation of monthly index prices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: City of Long Beach v. Total Gas & Power North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law governing alter ego claims, operating as a single entity requires showing the parent entity's complete domination and control to such an extent that the subsidiary entity no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Monopolies. City that traded natural gas derivatives lacked antitrust standing to pursue Sherman Act claims against traders based on manipulation of monthly index prices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: North Carolina courts consider the elements of piercing the corporate veil, including control, breach of duty, and proximate cause, in light of several factors: (1) inadequate capitalization, i.e. "thin corporation," (2) non-compliance with corporate formalities, (3) complete domination and control of the corporation so that it has no independent identity, and (4) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Condominium developer's refusal to allow time share owners to use time share was not a breach of contract under the law of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Courts will not recognize corporations as separate entities where evidence shows that several corporations are acting as one.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate identity may be disregarded under the alter ego doctrine where multiple corporations are operated as a single entity: where they are manipulated or controlled as a single enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice or to enable one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Mou v. SSC San Jose Operating Company LP
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego doctrine may apply between a parent and a subsidiary or, under the single enterprise rule, between sister or affiliated companies.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Pleading. Former nursing home resident failed to state claim for violation of California's UCL, predicated on alleged violations of various California and federal statutes and regulations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Gaubert Oil Company, Inc. v. Bayou Fuel Marine and Hardware Supplies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: The "single business enterprise doctrine" is a theory for imposing liability where two or more business entities act as one.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Chatz v. World Wide Wagering, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Where affiliated corporations disregard their legal distinctiveness and operate through intermingled business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, and records, it is appropriate to treat them as a single enterprise and to conclude that the enterprise exists as the alter ego of those responsible for disregarding the legal distinctions between its component corporations.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Trustee stated breach of fiduciary duty claims against directors of horse racing tracks.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule, as used to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is proper, primarily applies to prevent injustice in the situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: City of Dana Point v. New Method Wellness, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Single-enterprise doctrine applies where one of the corporations is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Nuisance. Residential properties were being operated as part of drug treatment facility, and thus constituted nuisances per se under city zoning ordinance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, when determining for purposes of alter ego claim whether parent and subsidiary corporations were operated as single economic unit, "siphoning" suggests the improper taking of funds the owner was not legally entitled to receive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: When a group of affiliated corporations constitutes a single business enterprise, a court may disregard the concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each of the affiliated corporations for the purpose of preventing fraud or achieving equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the single-business-enterprise theory can be used to fuse either affiliated or unaffiliated corporations, but not to impute corporate jurisdictional contacts to shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Foreign companies' functions of setting policies, strategy, and budgets for resident subsidiary corporation were appropriate parental functions that did not support alter-ego or single-business-entity theories.

Title: Stoneledge at Lake Keowee Owners' Association, Inc. v. IMK Development Co., LLC

Headnote: The threshold issue when considering whether multiple corporations have been amalgamated is an assessment of whether the multiple corporate entities actually operate as a single business enterprise, and thus should be treated as a single entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Trinity Industries, Inc. v. Greenlease Holding Company
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Proving that a subsidiary corporation is merely an alter ego is a burden that is notoriously difficult for plaintiffs to meet; in order to succeed on an alter ego theory of liability, plaintiffs must essentially demonstrate that in all aspects of the business, the two corporations actually functioned as a single entity and should be treated as such.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Packaged Seafood Products Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Generally, alter ego liability is reserved for the parent-subsidiary relationship; however, under the single-enterprise rule, liability can be found between sister companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: A subsidiary may be the alter ego of its parent, so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, when the two operate as a single economic entity such that it would be inequitable for a court to uphold a legal distinction between them.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: A Delaware alter ego claim has two elements: (1) have the two companies functioned as a single entity and thus should be treated as such, and (2) has this corporate structure caused fraud, injustice, or unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to assess whether two entities function as one for purposes of the alter ego analysis, Delaware law asks courts to consider a number of factors about the parent and subsidiary companies, and their relationship to each other, including: (1) whether the company, i.e., the subsidiary was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder, i.e., the asserted alter ego of the company in question, siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Pertuis v. Front Roe Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Under the single business enterprise theory, corporations are not liable for each other's obligations merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; there must also be evidence of abuse, or "injustice and inequity," meaning not just a subjective perception of unfairness by an individual judge or juror, but rather, fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under single business enterprise theory, corporations may be liable for each other's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Pertuis v. Front Roe Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: The single business enterprise theory requires a showing of more than the various entities' operations are intertwined; combining multiple corporate entities into a single business enterprise requires further evidence of bad faith, abuse, fraud, wrongdoing, or injustice resulting from the blurring of the entities' legal distinctions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under single business enterprise theory, corporations may be liable for each other's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Pertuis v. Front Roe Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Equitable principles govern the application of the single business enterprise remedy, which will only be applied upon a showing of bad faith, abuse, fraud, wrongdoing, or injustice resulting from the blurring of the entities' legal distinctions, and this doctrine is not to be applied without substantial reflection.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under single business enterprise theory, corporations may be liable for each other's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Mongelluzzi
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Common enterprise, or single business enterprise, doctrine provides that the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded where corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Fact issues regarding indirect benefit barred summary judgment on constructive fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: U.S. KingKing, LLC v. Precision Energy Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Parties are not jointly liable for a corporation's obligations merely because they were part of a single business enterprise, i.e., merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; instead, there must also be evidence of the kinds of abuse that the corporate structure should not shield, such as fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual issues as to if member of oil equipment supplier's customer, a limited-liability company, was customer's alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Fuentes v. Zaragoza
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Corporate veil-piercing theories such as alter ego or single business enterprise cannot and do not abrogate the requirements of due process in the judicial system; parties must still be afforded notice and an opportunity to appear and defend themselves before being subjected to civil liability. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW  Community Property. Trial court's judgments against third party co-respondents nonsuited before trial in divorce case violated their due process rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Sky Cable, LLC v. DIRECTV, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: In Delaware, the alter ego theory is a general principle of corporate law according to which a court may pierce a company's veil if separate entities operate as a single economic entity such that it would be inequitable for a court to uphold a legal distinction between them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse piercing of LLC veil was available under Delaware law when LLC was alter ego of its sole member, as predicted by federal court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: When corporations represent precisely the same single interest, the court is free to disregard their separate corporate identity.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Landowner's complaint stated claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Factors for determining applicability of single-business-entity exception to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) identity of ownership; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in interest of that corporation; (5) corporate financing; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) causing incorporation of affiliated corporation; (8) payment of salaries and expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by affiliated corporations; (10) use of property; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by employees; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Landowner's complaint stated claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Landmark Legacy, LP v. Runkle
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate identity may be disregarded under the alter ego doctrine where multiple corporations are operated as a single entity; where they are manipulated or controlled as a single enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice or to enable one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. General partner and limited partnership's negligence claim against financial planner was groundless, thus warranting attorney fee award as sanction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: 21st Century Financial Services, LLC v. Manchester Financial Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under California's single enterprise rule, an equitable doctrine to reflect partnership-type liability principles when corporations integrate their resources and operations to achieve a common business purpose, liability can be found between sibling companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Partnerships. General partner of limited partnership that funded bank's pre-formation expenses was not alter ego of bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: 21st Century Financial Services, LLC v. Manchester Financial Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Common principles apply in determining alter ego liability, under California law, regardless of whether the alleged alter ego is based on piercing the corporate veil to attach liability to a shareholder or to hold a corporation liable as part of a single enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Partnerships. General partner of limited partnership that funded bank's pre-formation expenses was not alter ego of bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Conde v. Sensa
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: While, generally, alter ego liability is reserved for the parent-subsidiary relationship, California courts have recognized a "single-enterprise rule" where liability can be found between sister companies; in effect what happens is that a court, for sufficient reason, determines that though there are two or more personalities, there is but one enterprise, and that this enterprise has been so handled that it should respond, as a whole, for the debts of certain component elements of it.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. A plaintiff may not rely on unsubstantiated state-court allegations to defeat a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Ames v. Ohle
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: "Single business enterprise doctrine" is a theory for imposing liability where two or more business entities act as one; generally, under the doctrine, when corporations integrate their resources in operations to achieve a common business purpose, each business may be held liable for wrongful acts done in pursuit of that purpose.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Judgment. Settlement agreement and consent judgments between client and financial advisor precluded additional claims under doctrine of res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Khoobehi Properties, LLC v. Baronne Development No. 2, L.L.C.

Headnote: The single business enterprise doctrine is a theory for imposing liability where two or more business entities act as one.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Seller of membership interest in LLC relinquished its right to an accounting from LLC when it sold its interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Enron Corporation Securities, Derivative & "ERISA" Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: The single entity test considers multiple factors for deciding whether two or more corporations operated as a single economic entity: (1) a corporation is grossly undercapitalized for the purposes of the corporate undertaking; (2) a failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) the non-payment of dividends; (4) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time; (5) the siphoning of the corporation's funds by the dominant stockholder; (6) the nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (7) the absence of corporate records; and (8) the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Alleged conduct in helping corporation create a false public image of its financial strength was not cognizable under § 10(b).

Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: To show that a parent and its subsidiary operated as a single economic entity, as required to pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, the plaintiff must allege exclusive domination and control to the point that the subsidiary no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.

Headnote: In assessing the first requirement to pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, whether the challenged entities operate as a single economic entity, courts consider: whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Andretti Sports Marketing Louisiana, LLC v. Nola Motorsports Host Committee, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Non-dispositive factors used to determine whether a group of entities constitute a single business enterprise under Louisiana law are: (1) corporations with identity or substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation; (5) corporation financing another corporation; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) corporation causing the incorporation of another affiliated corporation; (8) corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; (10) corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Sports marketing company failed to plead that corporation and LLC involved in auto race were a single business enterprise.

Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Choice-of-law rules applicable to claims to pierce the corporate veil applied to allegations asserted in support of claim under Louisiana's single business enterprise doctrine, even though that doctrine arose in different context and required application of different test, given that doctrine was grounded on same policies and doctrinal underpinnings as traditional veil-piercing theories, applying same choice-of-law rules was consistent with rationale for applying law of state of formation to veil-piercing claims, and effect of single enterprise determination was the same as determination of liability under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Under test for alter ego liability under Delaware law, factors relevant to whether one or more companies constitute a single economic entity include (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) non-payment of dividends, (4) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time, (5) siphoning of the corporation's funds by the dominant stockholder, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee did not adequately allege claim to avoid repayment of insider's $4,000,000 loan as constructive fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Reed v. Reid
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, a court may disregard the separateness of affiliated corporate entities when they are not operated separately, but rather are managed as one enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice or to permit one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise; these single business enterprise corporations may be identified by characteristics such as the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Representation that allegedly hazardous waste to be dumped on landowner's property was clean fill could support fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: "Single employer doctrine" is exception to doctrine of limited liability in corporate law, which allows corporate entities to escape liability for acts of separate, related entity; only in particularly exceptional instances will employees of one entity be treated as employees of a separate, yet related, entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In the Second Circuit criteria in analyzing "interrelation of operations" between separate corporate entities for purpose of determining single employer status are (1) involvement in daily production, distribution, marketing, and advertising decisions, (2) sharing of employees, services, records, and equipment, (3) commingling of bank accounts, inventories, and lines of credit, (4) maintenance of corporate records, and (5) preparing and filing of tax returns.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the factors to be considered to determine whether one entity is an alter ego of another, or whether two entities are a single business enterprise, are similar, and include but are not limited to: (1) common ownership; (2) common directors and officers; (3) common employees; (4) common offices; (5) unified administrative control; (6) similar or supplementary business functions; (7) one corporation financing the other; (8) inadequate capitalization; (9) one corporation's creation of the other; (10) one corporation paying the salaries, expenses, or losses of the other corporation; (11) one corporation receiving no business other than that given to it by the affiliated corporation; (12) shared property; (13) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (14) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfer of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Indiana courts will not recognize corporations as separate entities where evidence shows that several corporations are acting as one.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate identity may be disregarded under the alter ego doctrine where multiple corporations are operated as a single entity, where they are manipulated or controlled as a single enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice or to enable one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Title: In re Autobacs Strauss, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: To state alter ego claim under Delaware law, plaintiff must allege: (1) that companies operated as single economic unit, and (2) presence of overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor stated plausible claim for recharacterization of debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Autobacs Strauss, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, no single factor is dispositive in deciding, for purposes of alter ego claim, whether corporate parent and subsidiary were operated as single economic unit; some combination of factors is required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor stated plausible claim for recharacterization of debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate identity may be disregarded under the alter ego theory where multiple corporations are operated as a single entity; where they are manipulated or controlled as a single enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice or to enable one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under California's single enterprise rule, liability can be found between sister or affiliated companies; factors for the trial court to consider include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.

Title: Shook v. Walden
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: "Single-business enterprise" theory is not a valid basis in Texas law for disregarding a business corporation's separate existence and imposing its liabilities on another person.

Title: Harding Co. v. Sendero Resources, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Under the "single business enterprise theory," corporations which are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, are treated as the same entity for liability purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. President of landman services company was not personally liable on contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Moll Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Corporate subsidiary is not "mere facade" for parent corporation, a relevant factor under Delaware alter ego doctrine, if companies conduct fundamentally different businesses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: New Hampshire law, as predicted by federal district court, does not recognize the single-enterprise theory under which an entity other than the owner of a corporation could be held liable for that corporation's conduct by means of veil piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Under New Hampshire law, corporation was not liable for the negligence of its sister corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Coleman v. Burgundy Oaks, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, under the "single business enterprise doctrine," when corporations integrate their resources in operations to achieve a common business purpose, each business may be held liable for wrongful acts done in pursuit of that purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Genuine issue of material fact as to the applicability of the single business enterprise doctrine precluded summary judgment.

Title: Wehlage v. EmpRes Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine may apply between a parent and a subsidiary or, under the single enterprise rule, between sister or affiliated companies.

Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: Technically, there is no single business entity (SBE) doctrine, under which separate business entities could be considered as one entity, under Texas law.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Choice of Law. Texas law applied to tort claims of HMOs' receivers in action by Insurance Commissioner in which they intervened.

Title: Wilson v. Thorn Energy, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To resolve alter-ego piercing claim under Delaware law, court asks: (1) whether the entities in question operated as a single economic entity, and (2) whether there was an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Fraud. Issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on fraud and veil piercing claims against energy company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Generally, alter ego liability is reserved for the parent-subsidiary relationship; however, under the single-enterprise rule, liability can be found between sister companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Res judicata did not prohibit amendment of judgment to add debtor, under alter ego theory, who was successful in underlying arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Broadstripe, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: To prevail on an alter ego claim under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show (1) that the companies operated as a single economic entity, and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Summary judgment was not warranted in committee's action for equitable subordination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Jackson v. Tanfoglio Giuseppe, S.R.L.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the factors to be considered to determine whether one entity is an alter ego of another, or whether two entities are a single business enterprise, such that court with jurisdiction over the entity has jurisdiction over the alter ego, include, but are not limited to (1) common ownership, directors and officers, employees, and offices; (2) unified control; (3) inadequate capitalization; (4) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (5) centralized accounting; (6) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; (7) one corporation paying the salaries, expenses, or losses of another corporation; and (8) undocumented transfers of funds between entities.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Italian firearms manufacturer in products liability suit.

Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Wisconsin has not adopted the single business enterprise doctrine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Conspiracy. Trustee failed to state civil conspiracy claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Lentz v. Trinchard
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when two or more corporations constitute a single business enterprise ("SBE"), a court may disregard the concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each of the affiliated corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Conspiracy. Trustee failed to state civil conspiracy claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Smith v. Louisiana Farm Bureau Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation is an alter ego or part of a single business entity, the court must look at the substance of the corporation rather than the form.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Automobile. Pickup truck qualified as a covered temporary substitute automobile under corporation's commercial automobile policy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. v. The ADS Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, when analyzing the domination and control element, a court considers: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed; (2) whether the capitalization is adequate; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Controlling corporation to produce products that infringed patent was not inducement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Fendi Adele S.R.L. v. Filene's Basement, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To prevail under Delaware law on an alter ego claim against parent corporation based on acts of its subsidiary, a plaintiff must show: (1) that the parent and the subsidiary operated as a single economic entity and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Dilution. Retailer was liable for trademark dilution under federal and New York law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Fendi Adele S.R.L. v. Filene's Basement, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining whether a subsidiary and parent operate as a single economic entity for purposes of alter ego claim under Delaware law are: whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a façade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Dilution. Retailer was liable for trademark dilution under federal and New York law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when two or more corporations constitute a single business enterprise (SBE), a court may disregard the concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each of the affiliated corporations in order to protect against public inconvenience, wrongs, fraud, or crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: A "single business enterprise" (SBE) occurs, under Louisiana law, when a corporation is found to be the alter ego, agent, tool or instrumentality of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, traditional veil piercing cases require consideration of four or five primary factors, and then an inquiry into the totality of the circumstances; single business enterprise (SBE) theory, on the other hand, uses an eighteen-factor test, in which no factor is dispositive, before considering the totality of the circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the eighteen factors a court must look at in determining whether to apply single business enterprise (SBE) theory to fuse either affiliated or unaffiliated corporations for jurisdictional purposes include: whether one corporation has sufficient ownership interest in another to give it actual working control, whether common directors or officers exist, whether a unified administrative control apparatus is present, whether the business functions of the companies are similar or supplementary, whether the directors of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation or instead in the interest of another corporation, whether one corporation finances or pays the salaries and expenses of another corporation, whether one corporation is inadequately capitalized or receives no business other than that given to it by another corporation, whether a corporation uses the property of another corporation as its own, complies with corporate formalities, or keeps common employees or offices with another corporation, and whether financial transactions suggest that two companies that are separate in form are in fact a single enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, single business enterprise (SBE) theory is not restricted to jurisdictional analysis; it is also a vehicle for holding a group of affiliated entities responsible for the obligations of one of the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when a group of corporations integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose and do not operate as separate entities, each affiliated corporation may be held liable under single business enterprise (SBE) theory for debts incurred in pursuit of the general business purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Gordon v. Greenview Hosp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: To disregard the presumption of corporate separateness between a subsidiary corporation and its parent, the party seeking to do so must demonstrate (1) that the subsidiary corporation is a sham or dummy, (2) that the two corporations are, in fact, identical and indistinguishable, or (3) that the subsidiary corporation is merely an instrumentality, agent, conduit, or adjunct of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Presence of hospital's director's offices in Tennessee was insufficient to justify exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: the disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, common office space or telephone numbers, the degree of discretion demonstrated by the allegedly dominated corporation, whether dealings between the entities are at arm's length, whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and the payment or guaranty of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; but no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts look to several non-exclusive factors to determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, addresses and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Board of Managers of 195 Hudson Street Condominium v. Jeffrey M. Brown Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under New York law, courts consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether alleged dominator deals with corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) intermingling of property between alleged dominator and corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Condominium association board's claim against holding company was precluded by res judicata.

Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To succeed on an "alter ego" claim under Delaware law, and permit piercing the corporate veil of a company to assert liability, plaintiff must show that the two corporations operated as a single economic entity and that there is an overall element of injustice or unfairness present.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation

Title: Classic Maritime Inc. v. Limbungan Makmur SDN BHD
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a company is the alter ego of another, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil, a court considers the following factors, among others: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm"s length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner asserted valid maritime claim against guarantor of charter contracts, supporting attachment of $20,457,047.72.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Arctic Ocean Intern., Ltd. v. High Seas Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When considering whether to pierce a corporate veil based on allegations of alter ego liability, courts may consider the following factors: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Eleven months of failed attempts at locating funds subject to Rule B maritime attachment rendered court without jurisdiction.

Title: Budisukma Permai SDN BHD v. N.M.K. Products & Agencies Lanka (Private) Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although guiding principle for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is achieving an equitable result, relevant factors in evaluating sufficiency of veil-piercing claim include (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms-length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.

Headnote: Alter ego liability is not limited to the parent-subsidiary corporate relationship; rather, under the single enterprise rule, liability can also be found between sister or affiliated companies.

Title: In re LMcD, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under "single entity" or "enterprise" theory of liability, two or more corporations are treated as one when the following circumstances exist: identity of ownership, unified administrative control, similar or supplementary business functions, involuntary creditors, and insolvency of corporation against which claim lies.

Title: In re LMcD, LLC

Headnote: "Single entity" theory of liability is applicable when two or more corporations share common ownership and are, in reality, operating as a corporate combine.

Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children

Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether complete domination exists, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.

Title: ASARCO LLC v. Americas Mining Corp.

Headnote: On an alter-ego claim under Delaware law, when determining whether the two corporations operated as a single economic unit, a court looks to a number of factors, including whether: (1) the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; (2) the corporation was solvent; (3) dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and (5) in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
