Title: Academy of Skills & Knowledge, Inc. v. Charter Schools, USA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: The "single business enterprise" doctrine is not a cause of action, but rather a theory for imposing liability where two or more business entities act as one; under the doctrine, when businesses are not operated as separate entities but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each business may be held liable for wrongful acts done in pursuit of that purpose.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Charter school's negligence claims were barred by the economic loss rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Academy of Skills & Knowledge, Inc. v. Charter Schools, USA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: The single business enterprise doctrine is not synonymous with the doctrine of alter ego; although the alter ego doctrine and the single business enterprise doctrine are both based on principles of equity, an important distinction is that the alter ego doctrine generally involves proof of fraud, whereas no proof of fraud is required under the single business enterprise doctrine.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Charter school's negligence claims were barred by the economic loss rule.

Headnote: Under Texas law, the "single business enterprise" theory of corporate disregard, which is similar in purpose to, but is not considered synonymous with, the alter ego strand, is an equitable doctrine applied to reflect partnership-type liability principles when corporations integrate their resources and operations to achieve a common business purpose.

Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, pursuant to the single business enterprise theory of corporate disregard, when corporations are not operated as separate entities but, rather, integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in the pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, as opposed to "piercing" through the corporate shield to hold a shareholder or perhaps another affiliated company liable, the single business enterprise doctrine of corporate disregard recognizes the corporate shields of the two companies, but treats the two as partners given their common business purpose and thereby subjects each "partner" to the liabilities of the "partnership" formed by their relationship.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Headnote: The factors to consider in determining whether separate corporations should be treated as one enterprise include: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.

Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: The "single business enterprise" theory, used to disregard corporate structure, is not synonymous with the doctrine of alter ego; although the alter ego theory and single business enterprise theory are both equitable doctrines, an important distinction is that the alter ego theory, unlike the single business enterprise theory, generally involves proof of fraud, that is, proof that the corporation is organized and operated as merely a tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that New York courts consider when evaluating whether a corporation has been so controlled or dominated as to permit a piercing of corporate veil include: (1) absence of corporate formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone number; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property which was used by other corporations as if were their own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil would be pierced to hold debtor's principal personally liable for debts of bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts consider several factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Likelihood of success on corporate veil-piercing claim supported propriety of attachment order.

Title: Luc v. Krause Werk GMBH & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In evaluating whether to disregard a corporate entity based on finding that a subsidiary is the alter ego for its parent corporation, the court considers whether: (1) parent corporation owns all or a majority of subsidiary's capital stock; (2) corporations have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent subscribed to all of subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation; (8) papers of parent and statements of its officers refer to subsidiary as such or as a department or division; (9) directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Subsidiary manufacturer was alter ego of foreign parent company for purposes of personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Roofers Local 149 Security Trust Fund v. Duane Smelser Roofing Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Seminal inquiry in determining applicability of alter ego doctrine in labor law context is whether two or more coexisting employers performing the same work are in fact one business, separated only in form, and in answering question, courts employ multifactor test to determine whether two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on multiemployer benefit funds' contribution claim under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: IGEN Intern., Inc. v. Roche Diagnostics GmbH
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the act of one corporation is not regarded as the act of another merely because the first corporation is a subsidiary of the other, or because the two may be treated as part of a single economic enterprise for some other purpose; rather, to pierce the corporate veil based on an agency or "alter ego" theory, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Continuation of suit against licensor was not sham, so licensee was immune from tort liability.

Headnote: No single factor, of the 18 In re New Orleans Train Car Leakage factors for determining whether two corporations are a single business enterprise, is dispositive, and it is not required that every factor be satisfied to justify a finding of a single business enterprise.

Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Under the "single business enterprise" doctrine, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.

Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: A court may disregard the separateness of affiliated corporations, and pierce the corporate veil, when the corporations are not operated as separate entities, but are manipulated or controlled as one enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice, or to permit one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.

Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The indicia of common identity, excessive fragmentation, or single-business-enterprise corporations may include, among other factors justifying piercing the corporate veil, the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether single business enterprise is present, as would subject corporation to personal jurisdiction based on activities of enterprise, include (1) common employees, (2) common offices, (3) centralized accounting, (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, (5) common business name, (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Title: Heslop v. UCB, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Guidelines considered under Kansas law for determining alter ego status include: (1) whether parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers, (3) whether parent finances subsidiary, (4) whether parent subscribed to all of the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent, (8) whether in papers of parent, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division, (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent, and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are observed.

Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons

Headnote: "Single business enterprise doctrine" is an equitable doctrine applied to reflect partnership-type liability principles when corporations integrate their resources and operations to achieve a common business purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Important distinction between alter ego doctrine, and single business enterprise doctrine, is that alter ego theory generally involves proof of fraud, i.e., proof that the corporation is organized and operated as merely a tool or business conduit of another corporation, while to recover under a finding of a single business enterprise, no proof of fraud is required, as theory instead relies on equity analogies to partnership principles of liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: No showing of fraud is required to pierce the corporate veil under single business enterprise theory, and, when two corporations are not operated as separate entities but instead integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, it may be equitable, under exceptional circumstances, to hold each constituent corporation liable for the debts and liabilities incurred in the common enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Single business enterprise doctrine does not require proof of all the elements of a true joint venture or partnership for corporate veil to be pierced; rather, it is a doctrine founded in equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: An equal right of control is not required for corporate veil to be pierced pursuant to single business enterprise doctrine, because the doctrine does not try to determine whether a true joint venture has been established; rather, doctrine looks to see if principles of equity support a holding that the two entities should be treated as one for purposes of liability for their acts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.

Title: Nichols v. Pabtex, Inc.

Headnote: When determining whether corporations have been maintained as separate entities for the purpose of application of the single business enterprise doctrine, courts consider: common employees and offices, centralized accounting, payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, common business names, services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.

Title: Commerce Bank, N.A. v. Liebau-Woodall & Associates, L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: The factors to assess the unity of interest of separate legal entities, under corporate alter ego doctrine, are: (1) whether the parent owns all or a majority of the capital stock of the subsidiary; (2) whether the organizations have common directors or officers; (3) whether the parent finances the subsidiary; (4) whether the parent subscribed to all of the capital stock of the subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) whether the subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether the parent pays the salaries or expenses or losses of the subsidiary; (7) whether the subsidiary has substantially no business except with the parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by the parent; (8) whether in the papers of the parent, and in the statements of its officers, the subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division; (9) whether the directors or executives of the subsidiary do not act independently in the interest of the subsidiary but take direction from the parent; and (10) whether the formal legal requirements of the subsidiary as a separate and independent organization are not observed.

Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Courts can pierce the veil of a corporation in order to reach the alter egos of the corporate defendant, especially where two corporations constitute a single business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: The following factors may be considered in determining whether a group of entities constitute a "single business enterprise" for purposes of imposing common liability, although factors are not exhaustive and no single factor is dispositive: (1) corporations with identity or substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation; (5) corporation financing another corporation; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) corporation causing the incorporation of another affiliated corporation; (8) corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; (10) corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under "single business enterprise doctrine" as applied under Texas law, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: Guest at hotel in Mexico sued corporate manager and its parent corporation for negligence in connection with drowning death of her husband. In accordance with recommendations of magistrate judge, the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Orlando L. Garcia, J., dismissed action. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, DeMoss, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) liability was not imputable to parent corporation under either the alter ego or single business enterprise doctrine, and (2) district court had neither specific nor general jurisdiction over hotel's corporate manager. Affirmed.

Title: In re Schimmelpenninck
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: A single business enterprise remedy defeats the corporate form, under Texas law, when two or more organizations that are separate de jure pool or integrate their resources de facto to achieve a common business purpose; if such commonality is established, each constituent organization may be held liable for the debts incurred by one or more of the others in pursuit of that common business purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Injunctive relief barring purported creditor's veil-piercing claims against foreign debtor's subsidiary was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Toshiba America Medical Systems, Inc. v. Mobile Medical Systems, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule for piercing the corporate veil primarily applies to prevent injustice in the situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of the existence of common owners, officers, directors or shareholders and because of the lack of observance of corporate formalities between the two entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for corporation's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Brown v. Vitelcom, Inc.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Thomas and St. John.
Headnote: Under "integrated enterprise test," to determine whether allegedly independent corporations constitute single employer, liability hinges on all circumstances surrounding parent-subsidiary relationship, including: (1) whether subsidiary's corporate operations were merged, integrated, or interrelated with parent corporation; (2) whether parent corporation exercised centralized control of subsidiary's labor relations; and (3) whether subsidiary and parent corporations were commonly owned and managed.
Document Preview: Employee, a black woman from Dominica, brought action against employer, its parent corporation, and other subsidiary corporations, alleging discrimination and retaliation based on race or national origin, under Title VII and §1981. On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Moore, Chief Judge, held that: (1) fact issues existed on Title VII and §1981 claims, and (2) parent corporation was properly named defendant. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Hall v. Timmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Imposition of liability under single business enterprise doctrine does not require that both enterprises be corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Incomplete instruction on alter ego probably caused rendition of improper judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Hall v. Timmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: In determining whether liability can be imposed upon two or more business enterprises under single business enterprise, courts look at a variety of factors, including: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one business to another business's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by employees of one business on behalf of another business; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between the businesses; and (8) unclear allocations of profits.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Incomplete instruction on alter ego probably caused rendition of improper judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Glover v. Heart of America Management Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: "Integrated enterprise theory" makes corporations liable for another corporation's actions when corporations are closely connected.
Document Preview: Former restaurant employee brought action against former employer, co-worker, company that managed umbrella of restaurants, corporation which owned restaurants under umbrella, alleging Title VII sex harassment and retaliation, and common law intentional infliction of emotional distress. On all defendants' motion for summary judgment, except co-worker, the District Court, Vratil, J., held that: (1) employee established prima facie case of retaliation; (2) claimed distress from harassment was not so severe, genuine, and extreme as to constitute intentional infliction of emotional distress; and (3) corporation which owned restaurants under was not employer, under integrated enterprise theory. Motion granted in part, and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Miners, Inc. v. Alpine Equipment Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: "Enterprise entity theory" or the "single entity theory" of piercing the corporate veil applies when two or more corporations share common ownership and are, in reality, operating as a corporate combine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations lacked identity of ownership necessary to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Miners, Inc. v. Alpine Equipment Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under "single entity theory" of piercing the corporation veil, two or more corporations are treated as one because of identity of ownership, unified administrative control, similar or supplementary business functions, involuntary creditors, and insolvency of the corporation against which the claim lies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations lacked identity of ownership necessary to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Schimmelpenninck
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under the "single business enterprise" theory, if corporations are not operated as distinct entities but, rather, integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Claim asserted by former director of foreign debtor's subsidiary was not estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Carner v. MGS - 576 5th Ave. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: "Single employer doctrine" is exception to doctrine of limited liability in corporate law, which allows corporate entities to escape liability for acts of separate, related entity, except under extraordinary circumstances, commonly referred to as piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Former employee brought Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) and Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) action against several corporations. The District Court, Motley, J., held that: (1) all corporations were employers within meaning of ERISA and COBRA; (2) employers were liable under COBRA for failing to notify employee of his right to continuation and conversion coverage under employers' medical plan; (3) employers violated ERISA provision requiring plan administrator to furnish participant with latest updated summary plan description; (4) employers which were administrators for ERISA plan, rather than insurer which processed claims for plan, were ERISA fiduciaries responsible for notifying employee of his continuing COBRA coverage; and (5) employers breached their fiduciary duties under ERISA. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Carner v. MGS - 576 5th Ave. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under single employer doctrine exception to doctrine of limited liability in corporate law, which allows corporate entities to escape liability for acts of separate, related entity, employees of one entity are treated as employees of related entity only under extraordinary circumstances.
Document Preview: Former employee brought Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) and Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) action against several corporations. The District Court, Motley, J., held that: (1) all corporations were employers within meaning of ERISA and COBRA; (2) employers were liable under COBRA for failing to notify employee of his right to continuation and conversion coverage under employers' medical plan; (3) employers violated ERISA provision requiring plan administrator to furnish participant with latest updated summary plan description; (4) employers which were administrators for ERISA plan, rather than insurer which processed claims for plan, were ERISA fiduciaries responsible for notifying employee of his continuing COBRA coverage; and (5) employers breached their fiduciary duties under ERISA. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Circle Land and Cattle Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: When parent and subsidiary corporations are focus of alter ego charge, Kansas courts consider ten factors in deciding whether corporate veil should be pierced: (1) whether parent corporation owns all or a majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent corporation finances subsidiary; (4) whether parent corporation subscribed to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise caused its incorporation; (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether parent corporation pays the salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation; (8) whether in the papers of parent corporation, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division; (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary act independently in interest of subsidiary or take direction from parent corporation; and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are observed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Veil-piercing factors alleged by creditor did not warrant substantive consolidation of Chapter 11 debtor with alleged corporate alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: NorDar Holdings, Inc. v. Western Securities (USA) Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, single business enterprise is doctrine, separate from piercing corporate veil doctrine, that allows court to impose joint liability when two corporations are not operated as separate entities and integrate their resources to achieve common purpose.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against shareholder of debtor corporation, seeking to collect deficiency on debtor's promissory note under doctrines of alter ego and single business enterprise. The District Court, Sanders, Senior District Judge, held that debtor corporation's financial statement, which allegedly glossed over debtor's limited liquid assets, was insufficient to establish that corporation and its shareholder perpetrated actual fraud against creditor, as required to impose liability on shareholder under single business enterprise or alter ego theory. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Beneficial Personnel Services of Texas, Inc. v. Rey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Under "single business enterprise" doctrine, when corporations are not operated as separate entities but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, each corporation may be held liable for wrongful acts done in pursuit of that purpose.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Evidence supported jury's finding that employer committed fraud in misrepresenting type of workers' compensation benefits it would provide.

Title: Beneficial Personnel Services of Texas, Inc. v. Rey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Elements that must be shown to support finding of "single business enterprise" are: common employees, common offices, centralized accounting, payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, common business name, services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Evidence supported jury's finding that employer committed fraud in misrepresenting type of workers' compensation benefits it would provide.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Beneficial Personnel Services of Texas, Inc. v. Rey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Single business enterprise theory is valid means of imposing tort liability on two constituent corporations for damages caused in pursuit of joint business.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Evidence supported jury's finding that employer committed fraud in misrepresenting type of workers' compensation benefits it would provide.

Title: Old Republic Ins. Co. v. EX-IM Services Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Under "single business enterprise" doctrine, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Some evidence supported jury finding of single business enterprise in insurer's customs bond claim against insured import-export corporation and other import-export entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Sonnenblick-Goldman Co. v. ITT Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Delaware law, if there is no fraud, plaintiff must show that parent and subsidiary operated as single economic entity and that overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: Licensed real estate broker brought action against corporation in New York County Supreme Court, alleging that corporate executive vice-president and chief financial officer of corporation's subsidiary, on behalf of corporation and its subsidiary, breached agreement to pay brokerage fees.  Corporation removed, then moved to dismiss.  Broker cross-moved to remand to state court.  The District Court, Batts, J., held that: (1) under Delaware law, broker's pleadings were insufficient as a matter of law to show that corporation and its subsidiary were single economic unit, for purpose of piercing corporate veil in order to bring breach of brokerage agreement action against corporation, and (2) broker's complaint, alleging that corporation was involved in fraudulent scheme to avoid paying broker, failed to plead elements of fraud with required amount of specificity. Broker's motion denied; corporation's motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Sonnenblick-Goldman Co. v. ITT Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether parent and its subsidiary are single economic unit, for purposes of determining whether to pierce corporate veil under Delaware law, factors to consider include: (1) whether corporation was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; (2) whether corporation was solvent; (3) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and (5) whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Licensed real estate broker brought action against corporation in New York County Supreme Court, alleging that corporate executive vice-president and chief financial officer of corporation's subsidiary, on behalf of corporation and its subsidiary, breached agreement to pay brokerage fees.  Corporation removed, then moved to dismiss.  Broker cross-moved to remand to state court.  The District Court, Batts, J., held that: (1) under Delaware law, broker's pleadings were insufficient as a matter of law to show that corporation and its subsidiary were single economic unit, for purpose of piercing corporate veil in order to bring breach of brokerage agreement action against corporation, and (2) broker's complaint, alleging that corporation was involved in fraudulent scheme to avoid paying broker, failed to plead elements of fraud with required amount of specificity. Broker's motion denied; corporation's motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Murray v. Miner
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Single employer doctrine is exception to doctrine of limited liability, which allows corporations to organize so as to isolate liabilities among separate entities; rationale for exception is fairness of imposing responsibility on entity that shares decisionmaking authority with employing entity; thus, for policy to apply, the two entities must constitute single employer at time unlawful act was committed.
Document Preview: Former employees of defunct corporation brought suit against successor corporation's principal shareholders, seeking to hold them liable, under single employer doctrine, for breach of employment contracts.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Robert P. Patterson, Jr., J., 876 F.Supp.  512, dismissed complaint for failure to state a claim, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Meskill, Circuit Judge, held that under New York law as predicted by the Court of Appeals, single employer doctrine did not apply to hold controlling shareholders of successor corporation liable for breach of employment contracts, where there was no employer-employee relationship between employees and successor at time of alleged wrong. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Eichenwald v. Krigel's, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Integrated enterprise test, for determining whether parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary, prevents court from imposing liability on parent corporation when parent corporation and its subsidiary are operating independently.
Document Preview: Three female former employees, and one male former employee, brought sexual harassment action against jewelry stores and stores' parent corporation.  The District Court, Lungstrum, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support conclusion that sexual harassment of three female employees was sufficient to subject them to abusive working environment; (2) management position of male employee who subjected female employees to abusive working environment was sufficient basis for imputing liability to stores and their parent; (3) evidence was insufficient to support conclusion that male employee was subjected to hostile work environment; (4) evidence was sufficient to support conclusion that female employees were constructively discharged; (5) evidence was insufficient to support finding that employer retaliated against male employee; (6) stores and parent would be treated as single employer under integrated enterprise test;...

Headnote: Under integrated enterprise test for determining whether parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary, centralized control of labor practices is not only the most critical factor in four-factor analysis, but is necessary for two corporate entities to be treated as one.

Title: Eichenwald v. Krigel's, Inc.

Headnote: To establish centralized control under integrated enterprise test for determining whether parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary, parent's control of day-to-day employment decisions of subsidiary must be shown; day-to-day control must actually be exercised, and potential control is not sufficient.

Title: Eichenwald v. Krigel's, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: To establish that parent corporation was liable for acts of its subsidiary under integrated enterprise test, employee was required to establish that parent's control over subsidiaries exceeded that normally exercised by parent corporation.

Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, whether parent corporation should be held liable for acts of its subsidiary based on alter ego doctrine, involves considering whether parent corporation owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers, parent corporation finances subsidiary, parent corporation subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation, in papers of parent corporation, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division, directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent corporation, formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Worker brought products liability action against corporation, and corporation's former subsidiary that manufactured computer keyboard, for injuries suffered from use of allegedly defective keyboard, corporation moved for summary judgment, and former subsidiary moved for dismissal.  The District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary; (2) corporation was not manufacturer of keyboard; and (3) worker's action against former subsidiary accrued when she knew she was injured and knew cause of her injury. Motions granted.
