Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary may be found to be alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, court considers, inter alia, whether: parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent and subsidiary have common business departments; parent and subsidiary file consulted financial statements and tax returns; parent finances subsidiary; parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; daily operations of two corporations are not kept separate; subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against sole shareholder of major supplier of breast implants.  Shareholder, which had never itself manufactured or distributed breast implants, moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pointer, Chief Judge, held that genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on corporate control and direct liability claims. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Brown v. Automotive Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Upon finding that group of affiliated corporations constitute a "single business enterprise," court may disregard concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each affiliated corporation to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: Liquidation. Casualty insurer and insurance premium finance company were a single business enterprise, all of whose assets could be administered by liquidator of insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Brown v. Automotive Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Among factors that court considers in deciding whether two affiliated corporations may be regarded as a "single business enterprise" are: whether corporations have identity or substantial identity of ownership; common directors or officers; whether corporations share unified administrative control; intercorporate financing; inadequate capitalization; whether one corporation has caused incorporation of another affiliated corporation; one corporation's payment of salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; one corporation's receipt of business only from other corporation; corporations' use of each other's property; noncompliance with corporate formalities; common employees; common offices; centralized accounting; undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and whether there has been excessive fragmentation of single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: Liquidation. Casualty insurer and insurance premium finance company were a single business enterprise, all of whose assets could be administered by liquidator of insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: George Grubbs Enterprises, Inc. v. Bien
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Doctrine of "alter ego" is separate and distinct theory from that of "single business enterprise."
Document Preview: Damages. Award of exemplary damages in amount of $5,000,000 against car dealership defendants in connection with their treatment of deaf mute customer was not excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Superior Derrick Services, Inc. v. Anderson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: The "single business enterprise" theory, by which corporations may be held jointly and severally liable, involves corporations that integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose.
Document Preview: Manufacturer brought action against buyers for balance due under purchase order to design and manufacture four masts for use in oil and gas industry.  The 295th District Court, Harris County, Frank O. White, J., entered judgment for manufacturer, and buyers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Sears, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's conclusion that masts were conforming goods; (2) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that buyers accepted delivery of first mast at manufacturer's facility; (3) evidence did not support recovery under sworn account for fourth mast; (4) buyers operated as single business enterprise; and (5) trial court properly admitted videotape and photographs of masts during fabrication. Modified in part and affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Local 397, Intern. Union of Electronic, Elec. Salaried Mach. and Furniture Workers, AFL-CIO v. Midwest Fasteners, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under single-employer or single-enterprise test for determining whether parent and subsidiary are the same so as to render parent liable for any violation by subsidiary, question is whether two nominally independent enterprises, in reality, constitute only one integrated enterprise, and court must consider common ownership, common management, centralized control of labor relations and functional integration of operations.
Document Preview: Local union brought action against subsidiary and parent corporations alleging violation of Workers' Adjustment and Retraining Acts of 1988 (WARN).  Parent corporations moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Clarkson S. Fisher, J., held that parent corporations and subsidiary were a single enterprise so that parents could be held liable for subsidiary's violation of Act. Motion denied. See also 763 F.Supp. 78.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Local 397, Intern. Union of Electronic, Elec. Salaried Mach. and Furniture Workers, AFL-CIO v. Midwest Fasteners, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: No one factor is conclusive in determining whether parent and subsidiary are single employer so as to render parent liable for actions of subsidiary; instead, court must weigh totality of circumstances and determine whether parent exercised such pervasive control of subsidiary at policymaking level that purposes of labor laws are served by treating the two entities as one.
Document Preview: Local union brought action against subsidiary and parent corporations alleging violation of Workers' Adjustment and Retraining Acts of 1988 (WARN).  Parent corporations moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Clarkson S. Fisher, J., held that parent corporations and subsidiary were a single enterprise so that parents could be held liable for subsidiary's violation of Act. Motion denied. See also 763 F.Supp. 78.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Las Palmas Associates v. Las Palmas Center Associates
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Generally, alter ego liability is reserved for parent-subsidiary relationship; however, under single-enterprise rule, liability can be found between sister companies.
Document Preview: Shopping center vendors sought declaratory relief concerning their duty to guarantee rents, and purchasers filed cross complaint for fraud and breach of contract.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, No. C575906, Arthur Baldonaldo, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for purchasers, and vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Nott, J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding of fraud; (2) compensatory and punitive damage awards were excessive; and (3) purchasers were not entitled to contractual attorney fees on their fraud claim, but were entitled to recover fees incurred in defending vendors' contract action. Affirmed as modified; remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Alvarado Morales v. Digital Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: "Common control" doctrine, not "nerve center" test, is proper test to use in determining existence of single enterprise or employer for purposes of imposing liability on parent corporation for acts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Employees brought putative class action against nonresident parent corporation for physical and emotional damages arising from work place conditions at wholly owned subsidiary.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, Chief Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation and its directors were not subject to personal jurisdiction under Puerto Rico long-arm statute for acts of wholly owned subsidiary, where subsidiary was separate legal entity; (2) employees' complaint was barred by Puerto Rico Workmens' Accident Compensation Act; and (3) employees and their attorney who alleged that parent corporation tortured and brainwashed employees with concentration camp tactics were liable for sanctions under Rule 11. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: U.S. v. ACB Sales & Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Under common law, separation between corporate entities will not be disregarded absent special circumstances showing that the corporations should be deemed a single economic enterprise.
Document Preview: The United States brought civil action against debt collectors for penalties under the Federal Trade Commission Act, alleging violations of Federal Trade Commission order and of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act.  The District Court, Hardy, J., held that: (1) letters by debt collectors violated statute and FTC order by threatening legal action where at time letters were sent collectors did not intend to bring such action; (2) individual collectors violated statute and order in telephone conversations with debtors; (3) local agencies who employed individual collectors who violated the order were liable under doctrine of respondeat superior; (4) corporate directors of debt collection companies were liable for employees' violations of order; (5) parent companies were liable for subsidiaries' violations of order and violations of statute; (6) corporate directors were not liable for employees' violations of statute; and (7) Fair...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Extension of liability for corporation's obligations beyond confines of its own separate entity is appropriate in those cases where essentially single business or economic enterprise is nevertheless conducted through several separate corporations, either in parent-subsidiary arrangement or under common ownership as in case of affiliated corporations.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex initiated action against individual who managed complex and corporate lessor alleging defendants had trespassed upon plaintiffs' premises by padlocking them out of their apartments, breached implied covenants of quiet enjoyment, and had wrongfully converted their personal property by removing and/or disposing of it.  Plaintiffs sought recovery against lessor on theory that corporate lessee was operated as mere instrumentality of lessor to shield it from liability, and that corporate entity of lessee should be disregarded to allow plaintiffs to recover directly from lessor for their damages.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of plaintiffs, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Johnson, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in charging jury that corporate entity may be disregarded if corporation is totally dominated by individual shareholder;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Cruttenden v. Mantura
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Some guidelines to be followed in determining if the alter ego theory is appropriate are, whether: parent corporation owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; the corporations have common directors or officers; parent finances subsidiary; parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries, expenses or losses of subsidiary; subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division; directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently but take direction from parent; and formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the District Court, Bernalillo County, James A. Maloney, D.J., in favor of judgment creditor in suit to garnish wages of employee of subsidiary corporation. The Supreme Court, Riordan, J., held that evidence that all agreements formerly between parent corporation and overseas entities were assigned to and operated by subsidiary corporation, and that management agreement between parent corporation and Saudi Arabian company was assigned to subsidiary corporation was insufficient to support finding that subsidiary corporation was the alter ego of parent corporation; therefore, judgment creditor could not garnish wages payable by subsidiary corporation to its employee by serving writ of garnishment on parent corporation. Reversed. Payne, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Tigrett v. Pointer
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: If relationship between several corporations is such that they constitute a single business enterprise, a creditor may attack separate identity of each without showing that he dealt with all of them.
Document Preview: Holder of judgment against corporation sought to pierce corporate veil in garnishment proceeding and hold sole stockholder and also other corporations owned by him personally liable for judgment. The 162nd District Court, Dallas County, Dee Brown Walker, J., entered judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Guittard, C. J., held that: (1) act of stockholder in using his dominant position as president, director, and sole stockholder to withdraw substantially all assets from corporation without making any provision for payment of plaintiff and other creditors was a violation of his fiduciary duty as an officer and director of an insolvent corporation to preserve assets for benefit of all creditors and, when he preferred himself as a creditor despite inadequate capitalization, was such as to require that corporate veil be pierced and that sole stockholder be held personally liable under alter ego doctrine to plaintiff and other creditors for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Westcott Const. Corp. v. Cumberland Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Fact of common ownership and control of two corporations and that they occupy same premises is of importance in determining whether they are merged into one or either is the agent of the other only where they combine in such a way as to permit conclusion that agency or similar relationship exists between the entities.
Document Preview: Bill was brought for declaratory relief in which corporate general bidder sought to establish propriety of bid submitted by it to joint board of water commissioners of two towns. The Superior Court, Norfolk County, Griffin, J., decreed the bid to be valid, and another bidder appealed. The Appeals Court, Armstrong, J., held that the general bid was not invalid on theory that corporate general bidder and corporate subbidder were essentially the same entity so that general bidder was therefore prohibited by statute from listing any other subbidder in general bid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: My Bread Baking Co. v. Cumberland Farms, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Bristol.
Headnote: Where there is common control of group of separate corporations engaged in single enterprise, failure (a) to make clear which corporation is taking action in particular situation and nature and extent of that action, or (b) to observe with care the formal barriers between the corporations with proper segregation of their separate businesses, records, and finances, may warrant some disregard of separate entities in rare particular situations in order to prevent gross inequity.
Document Preview: Conversion actions tried in Superior Court before Mitchell, J. One defendant excepted to judge's refusal to direct a verdict for it. The Supreme Judicial Court, Cutter, J., held that separate corporate entities were disregarded, and principal family-owned corporation which sold its milk and dairy products to retail dairy stores operated by satellite family-owned corporations was liable for conversions of plaintiff's bakery racks on termination of arrangement for sale of plaintiff's bakery products in stores, where principal corporation's sales manager was responsible for order that stores not return racks, principal corporation and satellite corporations were operated from same headquarters as closely coordinated single enterprise in which sales manager was dominant figure, and manager dealt ambiguously with plaintiff. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Markow v. Alcock
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors in determining whether to disregard corporate fiction include: (1) are formal legal requirements observed; (2) is subsidiary adequately financed or does parent furnish capitalization; (3) by whom are salaries and expenses paid; (4) do subsidiary's directors act in independent and primary interest of parents; (5) are operations so integrated through commingling of funds, interactivities and common direction and supervision that they should be considered as one enterprise; and (6) generally, is one corporation so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it merely an agency, instrumentality, adjunct, or alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: Action by corporation's bankruptcy trustee claiming a mortgage to be invalid as in fraud of general creditors. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, Emett C. Choate, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Benjamin C. Dawkins, Jr., District Judge, held that evidence did not establish that corporate mortgagor was a wholly owned subsidiary of bankrupt corporation, nor that such mortgagor was not a legally constituted separate corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Shanik v. Aller
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: When subsidiaries constitute mere instruments or departments of a parent company, or when subsidiaries and parent constitute a single integrated enterprise, or when insistence upon technical joinder of subsidiaries as parties would frustrate justice, a court of equity may disregard corporate entity of the subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court; John H. McCooey, Jr., Justice. Derivative class action by Joseph Shanik against Howard L. Aller and others, to recover from defendants for the benefit of the American Power & Light Company and the stockholders moneys paid by the operating companies upon alleged unlawful contracts. From an order, plaintiff appeals. Order so far as it relates to the first cause of action reversed and motion to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: State v. Lone Star Gas Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts will look through forms to realities of relationship between two or more corporations in order to determine whether each is separate entity or corporation or whether their commingled affairs are such as to constitute them one integrated and single business enterprise, or whether through intercorporate set-up, affiliation, or stock ownership, purpose is to control subsidiary corporation or corporations so that they are used as mere instrumentalities or agents of owning corporation or corporations.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; C. A. Wheeler, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas and others against the Lone Star Gas Company, to restrain the defendant from violating an order of the Railroad Commission. From a judgment granting an injunction, plaintiffs appeal. Judgment reversed, and injunction dissolved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Malaro v. Wilkie
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, two circumstances justify piercing the corporate veil: the first is when the subject party exercises pervasive control of the activities of the corporation and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, and the second is when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute pervasive control in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. On Point Capital Partners LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: A corporate entity can be responsible for the actions of other corporations in a business venture when the structure, organization, and pattern of a business venture reveal a common enterprise or a maze of integrated business entities. Federal Trade Commission Act § 5, 15 U.S.C.A. § 45(a).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consumer Protection. Common control, shared office space and employees, and commingled funds was sufficient to show common enterprise for purpose of injunctive relief.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. On Point Capital Partners LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Common enterprise theory may be used to disregard corporateness when granting injunctive relief in an enforcement action that is brought by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) under the FTCA. Federal Trade Commission Act § 13, 15 U.S.C.A. § 53(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consumer Protection. Common control, shared office space and employees, and commingled funds was sufficient to show common enterprise for purpose of injunctive relief.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. AMG Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: To determine whether a common enterprise exists, which allows each entity in a group of interrelated companies to be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, a court considers factors such as: common control; the sharing of office space and officers; whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies; the commingling of corporate funds and failure to maintain separation of companies; unified advertising; and evidence that reveals that no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants. Federal Trade Commission Act, § 5, 15 U.S.C.A. § 45.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Industry Regulation. Financial audit report from special investigation that had not been made in normal regular course of business was not admissible as business record.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Able Body Temporary Services, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: "Common enterprise" doctrine invokes the equitable doctrines of substantive consolidation and alter ego, and a proponent must prove the required element of a substantial identity between the entities to be consolidated.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Covering deposits made by debtor-depositors into accounts at bank were not potentially avoidable transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Able Body Temporary Services, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: "Common enterprise" doctrine is predicated on notion that the legal fiction of separate corporate entities should be disregarded when the entities are organized and controlled as a single operation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Covering deposits made by debtor-depositors into accounts at bank were not potentially avoidable transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Munsell v. Colgate-Palmolive Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a court may disregard corporate formalities when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Industry Regulation. Buyer of personal care products plausibly alleged product labels had capacity to mislead.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: The common enterprise doctrine avoids situations where corporations are so entwined that a judgment absolving one of them of liability would provide the other defendants with a clear mechanism for avoiding the terms of the order.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Attorney Fees. Law firm violated New Mexico Mortgage Foreclosure Consultant Fraud Prevention Act by failing to comply with statute's requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: The common enterprise inquiry is not an alter ego analysis; the entities formally may be separate corporations but operate as a common enterprise.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Attorney Fees. Law firm violated New Mexico Mortgage Foreclosure Consultant Fraud Prevention Act by failing to comply with statute's requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under the theory of common enterprise, each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Attorney Fees. Law firm violated New Mexico Mortgage Foreclosure Consultant Fraud Prevention Act by failing to comply with statute's requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: When determining whether a common enterprise exists, the pattern and frame-work of the whole enterprise must be taken into consideration.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Attorney Fees. Law firm violated New Mexico Mortgage Foreclosure Consultant Fraud Prevention Act by failing to comply with statute's requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: For evidence of a common enterprise, pursuant to which each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, a court looks to common control; the sharing of office space and officers and employees; whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies; the commingling of corporate funds and failure to maintain separation of companies; unified advertising; and evidence that reveals that no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Attorney Fees. Law firm violated New Mexico Mortgage Foreclosure Consultant Fraud Prevention Act by failing to comply with statute's requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: People v. Debt Resolve, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where multiple corporate entities operate a common enterprise, each of the interrelated companies may be held liable for the actions of the other, and as a result, complaints alleging the liability of a common enterprise need not allege that each defendant committed a particular unlawful act.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Entities involved in fraudulent student loan debt-relief scheme operated as a common enterprise for purposes of consumer law violation claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: People v. Debt Resolve, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a common enterprise exists among a set of corporate defendants, courts consider factors such as whether the corporations (1) maintain officers and employees in common, (2) operate under common control, (3) share offices, (4) commingle funds, and (5) share advertising and marketing; no single factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Entities involved in fraudulent student loan debt-relief scheme operated as a common enterprise for purposes of consumer law violation claims.

Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under the theory of "common enterprise," each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group.

Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: The common enterprise doctrine, where each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, avoids situations where corporations are so entwined that a judgment absolving one of them of liability would provide the other defendants with a clear mechanism for avoiding the terms of an order.

Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: The common enterprise inquiry, where each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, is not an alter ego analysis; the entities formally may be separate corporations but operate as a common enterprise.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Attorneys and mortgage assistance relief providers did not engage in unfair or deceptive practices violative of New Mexico Unfair Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee stated plausible strong-arm claim to avoid transfer of right to acquire real estate.

Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from the general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Hebert v. Vantage Travel Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, disregard of corporate separateness is permitted when two factors are met: (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Class Actions. Class certification was warranted with respect to proposed class of passengers on malfunctioning tour boat.

Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Life Management Services of Orange County, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: When a common enterprise exists, each corporation may be held liable for the others' deceptive acts and practices.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Owner had control over telemarketing company that sold debt-relief services, as required for personal liability for company's FTCA violations.

Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Life Management Services of Orange County, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: There is not one universal or mandatory test to determine whether a common enterprise exists; instead, the pattern and framework of the whole enterprise must be taken into consideration.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Owner had control over telemarketing company that sold debt-relief services, as required for personal liability for company's FTCA violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Life Management Services of Orange County, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Courts consider a variety of factors to determine whether a common enterprise exists, including common control, the sharing of office space and officers, whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies, unified advertising, and evidence which reveals that no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Owner had control over telemarketing company that sold debt-relief services, as required for personal liability for company's FTCA violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Mongelluzzi
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Common enterprise, or single business enterprise, doctrine provides that the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded where corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Fact issues regarding indirect benefit barred summary judgment on constructive fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Alliance Document Preparation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Entities constitute a "common enterprise" when they exhibit either vertical or horizontal commonality-qualities that may be demonstrated by a showing of strongly interdependent economic interests or the pooling of assets and revenues.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. FTC was likely to succeed on its claim that corporations and individuals engaged in the business of student loan debt relief violated the FTC Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Alliance Document Preparation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Courts are permitted to consider a variety of factors when deciding whether a common enterprise exists; for instance, courts may consider whether companies are under common ownership and control, whether they pool resources and staff, whether they share telephone numbers, employees, and e-mail systems, and whether they jointly participated in a shared business venture or referred customers to one another.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. FTC was likely to succeed on its claim that corporations and individuals engaged in the business of student loan debt relief violated the FTC Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Alliance Document Preparation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Where corporate entities operate together as a common enterprise, each may be held liable for the deceptive acts and practices of the others.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. FTC was likely to succeed on its claim that corporations and individuals engaged in the business of student loan debt relief violated the FTC Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Moore v. Navillus Tile, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In the ordinary case, two entities have the same business purpose, for purposes of alter ego doctrine, if they deal in the same product or service.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Subcontractor was alter ego of employer, and thus was obligated to make contributions to multi-employer benefit funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Moore v. Navillus Tile, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When companies describe their business purpose in nearly identical terms in letters sent to potential customers, this is evidence of common business purpose, as factor under the test for alter ego status.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Subcontractor was alter ego of employer, and thus was obligated to make contributions to multi-employer benefit funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Moore v. Navillus Tile, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of the alter ego doctrine, two entities may be considered to have substantially identical business purposes even if one entity performs only a subset of the business activities of the other.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Subcontractor was alter ego of employer, and thus was obligated to make contributions to multi-employer benefit funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Vantage Point Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a common enterprise, or maze of interrelated companies, exists, as a basis for joint and several liability, a court considers the pattern and framework of the whole enterprise, and relevant factors include whether the corporate defendants (1) maintain officers and employees in common; (2) operate under common control; (3) share offices; (4) commingle funds; and (5) share advertising and marketing.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Fact issues as to whether owners of debt engaged in common enterprise with third-party call-initiators precluded summary judgment in favor of FTC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Vantage Point Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: A common enterprise liability analysis is neither an alter ego inquiry nor an issue of corporate veil piercing; instead, the entities within the enterprise may be separate and distinct corporations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Fact issues as to whether owners of debt engaged in common enterprise with third-party call-initiators precluded summary judgment in favor of FTC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Medici v. Lifespan Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There are two scenarios in which the corporate form may be disregarded under Massachusetts law: (1) the first is when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the inter-corporate relationship, and (2) the second is when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Discipline. Scientist had to exhaust his administrative remedies before Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Research Integrity before bringing suit challenging termination for research misconduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Polanco v. UPS Freight Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under the integrated-enterprise test used to determine whether multiple corporate entities acted as one, a court considers the following four factors: (1) common ownership; (2) common management; (3) interrelation between operations; and (4) centralized control over labor relations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Female employee was not similarly situated to male salesperson, for purposes of sex discrimination claim under Title VII based on disparate treatment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Johnson
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under the theory of common enterprise, each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Operator was vicariously liable under FTC Act for deceptive statements posted on websites hosted by third party advertisers and marketers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Johnson
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Entities constitute a common enterprise, as would support each entity in a group of interrelated companies being held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, when they exhibit either vertical or horizontal commonality, that is, qualities that may be demonstrated by a showing of strongly interdependent economic interests or the pooling of assets and revenues.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Operator was vicariously liable under FTC Act for deceptive statements posted on websites hosted by third party advertisers and marketers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Johnson
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: To determine whether a common enterprise exists, as would support each entity in a group of interrelated companies being held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, a court considers factors such as: common control; the sharing of office space and officers; whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies; the commingling of corporate funds and failure to maintain separation of companies; unified advertising; and evidence that reveals that no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Operator was vicariously liable under FTC Act for deceptive statements posted on websites hosted by third party advertisers and marketers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission v. Trade Exchange Network Limited
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether several business entities are operating as a common enterprise, courts look to whether the companies: (1) maintain officers and employees in common; (2) operate under common control; (3) share offices; (4) commingle funds; and (5) share advertising and marketing; and courts also look to whether corporate formalities are observed and whether the companies conduct business at arm's length.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Commodity Futures. Prediction-related contracts were binary options that were subject to regulation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a relationship between two corporations may result in joint liability when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. E.M.A. Nationwide, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Courts generally find that a common enterprise exists, so as to disregard corporate structure and impose liability upon subsidiaries, if, for example, businesses: (1) maintain officers and employees in common; (2) operate under common control; (3) share offices; (4) commingle funds; and (5) share advertising and marketing.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Marketers and sellers of debt-relief services were jointly and severally liable, under common enterprise theory, for violations of Federal Trade Commission Act (FTCA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. Tax Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under the "common enterprise theory," each entity within a set of interrelated companies may be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities that are part of the group.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. FTC, Florida, and New Jersey stated claim for common enterprise liability among corporations for deceptive telemarketing tactics.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. Tax Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a common enterprise exists among a set of corporate defendants, such that each defendant may be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of the other defendants, courts consider a set of non-dispositive factors, including whether they: (1) maintain officers and employees in common, (2) operate under common control, (3) share offices, (4) commingle funds, and (5) share advertising and marketing.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. FTC, Florida, and New Jersey stated claim for common enterprise liability among corporations for deceptive telemarketing tactics.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. Tax Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The very nature of the common enterprise theory is that corporate entities that are a part of the common enterprise are liable for the conduct of other entities in the enterprise, regardless of whether the particular entity engaged in the behavior at issue.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. FTC, Florida, and New Jersey stated claim for common enterprise liability among corporations for deceptive telemarketing tactics.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Bridge Street Automotive, Inc. v. Green Valley Oil, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate formalities may be disregarded and the corporate veil may be pierced (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship; or (2) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Gas station owner did not establish relatedness prong of test for specific jurisdiction over lessor's alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Admiral Ins. Co., Inc. v. Arrowood Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Excess and Umbrella. Excess insurer had subrogation claim based on primary insurer's failure to tender its policy limits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: TechTarget, Inc. v. Spark Design, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a court may disregard corporate formalities and pierce the corporate veil when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Advertising firm could not pierce the corporate veil of client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Logistics Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of the corporate entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. State law governed evidentiary issue in strong-arm avoidance proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Trabucco v. Intesa Sanpaolo, S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, one corporation is considered to be mere alter ego when it has been so dominated by another corporation and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Jurisdiction. Bank purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities within New York forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Test to determine alter ego status is whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Brookridge Funding Corp. v. Aquamarine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Although common ownership of the stock of two or more corporations together with common management, standing alone, will not give rise to liability under Massachusetts law on the part of one corporation for the acts of another corporation or its employees, additional facts may be such as to permit the conclusion that an agency or similar relationship exists between the entities, particularly (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fish buyer was not unjustly enriched at secured lender's expense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Callahan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, there are two circumstances in which piercing corporate veil is appropriate: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising form of pervasive control, in activities of another, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship; or (2) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise, with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Tax lien did not attach to property titled solely in name of taxpayer's wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New York Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Perimeter Interiors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Two businesses are alter egos if they have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Corporation did not have to pay contributions for payments to president, precluding pension funds' recovery in ERISA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, "identity rule" requires that proponent of veil piercing claim show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, and adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Title: F.T.C. v. National Urological Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: When corporations act as a common enterprise, each may be held liable for the deceptive acts and practices of the other.

Title: F.T.C. v. National Urological Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: When determining whether a common enterprise exists, the pattern and frame-work of the whole enterprise must be taken into consideration.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Advertising. FTC standards requiring scientific studies to support health or safety claims in advertisements were not void for vagueness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. National Urological Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Some of the factors that courts evaluate to determine whether a common enterprise exists include: common control, the sharing of office space and officers, whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies, the commingling of corporate funds and failure to maintain separation of companies, unified advertising, and evidence that reveals that no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Advertising. FTC standards requiring scientific studies to support health or safety claims in advertisements were not void for vagueness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To determine "alter ego" status in situation where new employer is merely disguised continuance of the old, court asks whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; no one of these factors is controlling but rather analysis is flexible, and court evaluates all relevant factors together and can find alter ego status even if not all of them are present.
