Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Scott v. NG U.S. 1, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Corporate formalities may be disregarded when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's veil could not be pierced to hold it liable for environmental contamination by former subsidiary decades earlier.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Zimmerman v. Cambridge Credit Counseling Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts law permits piercing of the corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine where there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Admissions. Defendants were not entitled to withdrawal of admissions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Milan v. Centennial Communications Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: To determine whether separate corporations constitute a single employer, courts consider the following factors, none of which is controlling or needs to be present: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) common management; (3) centralized control of labor relations; and (4) common ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Employees who signed separation agreements knowingly and voluntarily waived all claims against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Four Seasons Mfg., Inc. v. 1001 Coliseum, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In a case where a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, the eight factors generally applied to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil are not exclusive, and the court may consider additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of LLC was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Brown v. ANA Ins. Group
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When a group of associated business entities or corporations integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose and do not abide by the formalities of law for operation as separate companies, a single business enterprise may be declared.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Insolvent Insurers. Insurance Commissioner breached fiduciary duty to insolvent insurer's owners by failing to supervise investment advisors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Ontos, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a claim may be brought against the "alter ego" of a corporation when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting; in such circumstances, courts may allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil of limited liability in order to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Trustee had standing to settle claims brought by debtor's former officers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Williams v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In determining whether parent corporation may be held liable for subsidiary's action under integrated-enterprise test, the court must examine four factors: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) common management; (3) centralized control of labor relations, and (4) common ownership.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent corporation was not liable for its subsidiary's allegedly discriminatory discharge of its employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Meredith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Accounting firm and financial services corporation formed by firm's principal and his wife were alter egos of each other, and thus could not be treated distinctly, given that principal moved his accounting business from firm to corporation, that nothing changed for principal's clients as a result of such move, that work being done by principal did not vary, address and telephone numbers did not change, and other work being done did not change business's character, and that income stream generated from accounting business was primary income for both firm and corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers of assets of Chapter 7 debtor were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New York State Teamsters Conference Pension and Retirement Fund v. Express Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: When entities are engaged in different lines of business, which serve different business purposes, common space and shared management cannot alone create alter ego status.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Determinations of employer status per se under Multiemployer Pension Plan Amendments Act are for the court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Brentwood Golf Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In the Sixth Circuit, factors to consider in making a determination of an alter ego include whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Substantive consolidation of debtor-golf course and tavern was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Davlyn Mfg. Co., Inc. v. H&M Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or corporation is an alter ego or successor of a corporation, the court should consider the nature of the corporate entities' ownership and control, including commonality of stockholders or officers, common use of employees, business locations, or sales systems, common marketing or trademarking; similarity of core business lines, and commingling of funds and assets; court should also consider the sufficiency of consideration paid for the transfer of the predecessor's assets or product line, as well as any other indicia of fraudulent intent in the creation of the second entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over defendants in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Massachusetts courts will pierce corporate veil only when there is compelling evidence of one of two situations: (1) that there is active and pervasive control of related business entities by same controlling persons, as well as a fraudulent or injurious consequence by reason of relationship among these business entities; or (2) there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or a serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some of the factors that may be considered when determining whether to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant corporation are: (1) identity of stock ownership, (2) common directors and officers, (3) unified administrative control, (4) directors and officers of one entity operate independently in interest of the other, (5) one corporation financing another, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) corporation causing incorporation of another, (8) one corporation paying salaries and expenses of another, (9) corporation receives no business except from other corporation, (10) corporation using property of the other as its own, (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities, (12) common employees, (13) common offices, (14) central accounting, (15) undocumented transfer of funds, (16) unclear allocation of profit and loss between the two corporate entities, and (17) excessive fragmentation of single business enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Commodity Futures Trading Com'n v. Wall Street Underground, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Where one or more corporate entities operate in a common enterprise, each may be held liable for the deceptive acts and practices of the other.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Sellers of commodities trading system engaged in fraudulent acts as commodity trading advisors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Cahaly v. Benistar Property Exchange Trust Co., Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In context of piercing the corporate veil, "identity rule" primarily applies to prevent injustice in situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of existence of common owners, officers, directors, or shareholders and because of lack of observance of corporate formalities between two entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Plaintiff could pursue prejudgment attachment while awaiting final judgment in another state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Litchfield Asset Management Corp. v. Howell
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule primarily applies to prevent injustice in the situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of the existence of common owners, officers, directors or shareholders and because of the lack of observance of corporate formalities between the two entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Companies were liable for personal debt through reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Plantation Realty Trust
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veil may be pierced in order to impute liability among differing corporate entities: (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of that intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced in order to permit creditor's proof of claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: American Institute of Certified Public Accountants v. Affinity Card, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, corporate form will be disregarded only when: (1) there is an active and direct exercise of pervasive control by the representatives of one corporation over the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence; or (2) there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities.
Document Preview: In suit for breach of contract, defendant corporation moved to vacate default judgment. The District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) assistant vice president of corporation separate from and unaffiliated with defendant, but sharing office and having common president and partial owner, was not sufficiently integrated with defendant to allow the inference that he had authority to receive service of process for defendant; (2) fact that president of defendant actually received summons and complaint on the very same day was not sufficient to cure defective service; (3) service on separate corporation would not be deemed to constitute effective service on defendant on ground that they were both virtual alter egos of person who was president and part owner of each, under Massachusetts law; (4) service was ineffective under New York law, where service was on a non-employee who made no representations as to authorization to receive service; (5) service was also...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Johnson v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing the corporate veil is permitted only (1) where one corporation actively and directly participates in activities of second corporation, apparently exercising pervasive control, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of intercorporate relationship, or (2) there is a confused intermingling between corporate entities engaged in common enterprise.
Document Preview: Cranberry suppliers brought action for damages and injunctive relief against corporations which had contracted to purchase cranberries, principals of corporations, and other entities. After preliminary injunction and writs of attachment were issued, the District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) regulation requiring private agreements to call for payment within 30 days of receipt in order for trust protection under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA) to be available was reasonable; (2) contract calling for 75% of payment to be made more than 30 days after receipt did not comply with regulation; (3) amounts owed under contract containing no terms regarding payment were payable within 10 days, so that trust protection was available; but (4) failure to provide written notice of intent to preserve benefits of trust deprived seller of trust protection; and (5) no reasonable likelihood of success existed on claim against principals under Massachusetts unfair trade...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is permitted, under Massachusetts law, only: (1) where one corporation actively and directly participates in the activities of the second corporation, apparently exercising pervasive control, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) there is a confused intermingling between corporate entities engaged in a common enterprise.
Document Preview: Cranberry supplier, who had not received payment, brought action against buyer, buyer's controlling shareholder, and company to which buyer had delivered the cranberries, asserting claims under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA), for misrepresentation, and for violations of the Massachusetts Fraudulent Conveyance Act and the Massachusetts Unfair Trade Practices Act.  The District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) supplier was not entitled to PACA trust protection; (2) alter-ego theory did not apply, so as to impose liability for debt on either shareholder or transferee company; (3) shareholder was not liable for any misrepresentation; and (4) shareholder's transfers of property were not fraudulent conveyances. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Olympic Financial Ltd. v. Consumer Credit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, when two or more corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: Finance company sued automobile seller for breach of consignment contract under which seller sold repossessed automobiles, and also against other dealers with which finance company had master dealership agreements. On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Atlas, J., held that: (1) seller and other dealers were not operated as single business entity; (2) there was no actual fraud by seller; and (3) there was no fiduciary duty on part of seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is permissible to pierce alleged corporate veil when there is either confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about matter and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Suppliers brought action against, inter alia, vice president of corporation that owed them money and company that was erroneously represented as the imminent purchaser of the corporation, alleging breach of contract and fraud. Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ponsor, J., adopted the opinion of Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) company was not liable for corporation's debts; (2) statute of frauds barred suppliers' breach of contract claim against company; (3) suppliers did not confer measurable benefit on company, as required for quantum meruit claim; (4) fact questions precluded summary judgment on misrepresentation claims against vice president of corporation and company; (5) vice president of corporation was not agent of company; (6) fact questions precluded summary judgment on estoppel claims against company; and (7) fact questions precluded summary judgment on unfair and deceptive trade practices claims against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Carlson v. Rockwell Space Operations Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under "integrated enterprise test," parent company may be liable for actions of its subsidiary based upon following four factors: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) centralized control of labor relations; (3) common management; and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: Female employee brought action against corporation, its wholly owned subsidiary and coemployee, alleging violations of Title VII, intentional infliction of emotional distress, assault, and negligent hiring, training and supervision.  Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Atlas, J., held that: (1) coemployee was not individually liable to employee under Title VII; (2) neither coemployee nor subsidiary was liable for intentional infliction of emotional distress; (3) neither coemployee nor subsidiary was liable for assault; (4) corporation was not employee's employer within meaning of Title VII; (5) corporation was not directly liable for intentional infliction of emotional distress, assault, or negligent hiring, training and supervision; (6) subsidiary was not liable for Title VII hostile environment sexual harassment; (7) employee failed to establish Title VII quid pro quo sexual harassment or retaliation claim against subsidiary;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Cotter
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether successor corporation is alter ego of its predecessor, courts consider several factors: whether they have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: Fund trustees filed action to examine books of alleged sole proprietorship operated by former president of dissolved corporate employer to assess appropriate multiemployer benefit plan contributions.  Defendants filed motion seeking relief from default judgment allowing funds to examine defendants' books.  The District Court, Bucklo, J., held that: (1) ten-year statute of limitations for breach of written contracts under Illinois law applied to action; (2) district court had jurisdiction over action; (3) bankruptcy court's rejection of claim for contribution brought by funds did not bar action on res judicata grounds; (4) corporate employer never adequately rejected collective bargaining agreement in bankruptcy proceeding; and (5) audit was authorized to determine whether former president of dissolved corporation could be liable for contributions that corporation owed to plans. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Mark Six Realty Associates, Inc. v. Drake
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Where evidence exists that corporation has no employees, does no business, uses no name, and is a shell created for very specific and limited purpose to benefit another corporation, court must look to activities of that other corporation to determine whether the corporations were engaged in common business enterprise.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employment Contract. Real estate brokerage retained sufficient control over agent's duties to make her employee not independent contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Warner v. Hillcrest Medical Center
Court: Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Showing of common board of directors and unity of corporate purpose is insufficient to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Sanctions. Counsel was sanctioned for filing and maintaining claims as against certain medical malpractice defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union, AFL-CIO, CLC v. Alden Corrugated Container Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, one corporation may be held liable for actions of another when there is act of indirect participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of inter-corporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard for separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Unions brought action against employers alleging violation of Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) in connection with plant closing. The District Court, Robert B. Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) employer's layoff of 30 employees on one date and 24 additional employees within 90 days of first layoff was a mass layoff under WARN Act; (2) two corporations and a holding company were a single employer for purposes of WARN Act; and (3) District Court would not exercise its discretion to reduce amount of liability and penalty to be assessed against employers for failure to give notice of mass layoffs as required by WARN Act. Judgment in favor of plaintiffs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Markham v. Fay
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing corporate veil may be warranted when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of intercorporate relationship, or when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy filed interpleader action with regard to proceeds from sale of nursing homes held in name of debtor and mortgaged by corporation and trusts, after United States asserted interest in proceeds as holder of judgment based upon responsible person liability against president of corporation and settlor of trusts for nursing homes' unpaid withholding taxes.  The District Court, Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) memorandum of decision on summary judgment was law of case as to timeliness of government's claims and as to which law applied; (2) under Massachusetts law, corporation and trusts were not alter egos of president of corporation and settlor of trust, for purposes of veil piercing; (3) Internal Revenue Service (IRS), as creditor of settlor of trusts, was entitled as matter of law to such portion of interpled fund as represented proceeds from sale of nursing homes, as assets of trusts; and (4) declaration...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Brown v. Automotive Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When group of corporations integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose and do not operate as separate entities, each affiliated corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of this general business purpose.
Document Preview: Liquidation. Casualty insurer and insurance premium finance company were a single business enterprise, all of whose assets could be administered by liquidator of insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Frank v. U.S. West, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under the integrated enterprise test for determining in federal employment discrimination cases if parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary, facts that are considered include interrelation of operations, centralized control of labor relations, common management, and common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: Employees of telephone company's subsidiaries brought action against parent telephone corporation, alleging employment discrimination based on age and national origin.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, Edward W. Nottingham, J., found that parent corporation was not employees' employer.  Employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baldock, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation was not liable for subsidiaries' actions under federal law or Colorado law, and (2) lower court properly refused to add subsidiary as defendant. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: United Elec., Radio and Mach. Workers of America v. 163 Pleasant Street Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts "alter ego" doctrine, corporate disregard is allowed, even absent finding of fraud, if there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Union sued employer and employer's foreign parent alleging that employer's planned cessation of health care payments after its closing would violate Massachusetts common law, Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA), and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, A. David Mazzone, J., ordered parent corporation to pay health care premiums, and parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Selya, Circuit Judge, held that there was insufficient evidence to find that Scottish parent corporation purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities in Massachusetts, and, thus, court lacked jurisdiction over Scottish parent of Delaware employer. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Green v. Champion Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When corporations integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose and do not operate as separate entities, each affiliated corporation may be held liable for debt incurred in pursuit of group's business purpose.
Document Preview: Liquidation proceedings were commenced against an insolvent insurance company and, after appointment of a special liquidator ad hoc, the special liquidator sought an injunction to prevent transfer of assets of affiliated companies.  The Nineteenth Judicial District Court, Parish of East Baton Rouge, Joseph F. Keogh and Douglas Moreau, JJ., decided to treat the insurance company and related entities as a single business enterprise and ordered on accounting, issued a permanent injunction and granted declaratory relief.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Lottinger, J., held that: (1) once the Commissioner of Insurance voluntarily recused himself, the trial court had authority to select a liquidator; (2) the insurance company and related entities were a single business enterprise for liquidation purposes; and (3) the trial court was not required to stay the liquidation proceedings until completion of pending criminal charges...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Blanton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, fact that companies were commonly owned and often act in concert toward similar goals did not rise to level of complete disregard of corporate entity which would allow corporate veil to be pierced on grounds of alter ego.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 debtors objected to claim of Arizona Department of Revenue for gross receipt taxes incurred by corporation owned by one debtor while corporation performed two family housing rehabilitation contracts at Air Force base in Arizona. The Bankruptcy Court, Larry E. Kelly, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Texas law applied to determine whether corporate veil should be pierced; (2) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate form was resorted to as means of invading existing legal obligation, was inapplicable; (3) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporation was mere alter ego of debtor, was inapplicable; and (4) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate entity of corporation and its related entities were used as means of perpetrating fraud, was inapplicable. Objection granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: NCR Credit Corp. v. Underground Camera, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, party requesting court to disregard corporate form must allege facts suggesting that representatives of one corporation exercise some type of pervasive control over activities of another corporation or that there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of the corporate entities, and, secondly, party must show that piercing of the corporate veil is necessary to defeat fraud or wrong or to prevent gross inequity.
Document Preview: In a suit for money allegedly due and unpaid on a computer sales contract, and on various motions, the District Court, Caffrey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) point charging that defendants conspired to defraud plaintiff to its great harm and detriment was insufficient to inform opposing party of nature of the conspiracy charged; (2) case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard; (3) court having declined to treat parent manufacturer and financing subsidiary corporation as same entity, it was found that subsidiary did not waive parent's right to arbitrate by filing suit in federal court, and where outcome of arbitration might dispose of some or all claims outstanding, proceedings in the court between plaintiff buyer and financing subsidiary would also be stayed pending outcome of arbitration; and (4) description of pending case in news weekly was unlikely to interfere with any litigant's right to fair...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Sheridan Hotel & Bar, Ltd. v. Commercial Leasing Corp., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: Before one corporation may be held liable for acts of another corporation, there must be such a close relationship between the two companies that one is, in essence, an instrumentality of the other; factors which enter into this determination include, inter alia, stock ownership of one corporation by the other, management decisions by one corporation for the other, and amount of business which one company has apart from its business with the other.
Document Preview: Lessee of telephone system brought action against lessor to rescind the lease agreement, and lessor counterclaimed to accelerate payments required under the lease and to recover attorney fees. The District Court, San Miguel County, Jerry Lincoln, J., entered judgment for lessor on both the complaint and counterclaim, and lessee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coyte, J., held that: (1) lessor was not responsible for any representations or warranties made by installer, from whom it had purchased the system, to lessee; (2) trial court did not err in accelerating payments due under terms of lease when lessee failed to make required payments; and (3) since no objection was timely made, lessee had no basis to complain as to amount of attorney fees awarded to lessor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: General Finance Corp. v. Skinner
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Although parent corporation and subsidiary were separate legal entities, only one commonly owned enterprise existed where all business of subsidiary was transmitted and processed by parent, parent issued binding instructions to subsidiary regarding issuance of credit disability insurance to customer, names of parent and subsidiary were used interchangeably on many written particulars mailed and handed to customers, subsidiary frequently represented itself on business letters, advertising and mailings to customers as "[parent]," and general supervisor of subsidiary was salaried executive of parent.
Document Preview: In action against finance corporation for recovery of benefits under credit disability insurance on loan balance, the Superior Court, Vigo County, Charles K. McCrory, J., awarded default judgment in favor of insured, and finance corporation appealed denial of its amended motion for relief from judgment, alleging insufficient service of process. The Court of Appeals, Neal, P. J., held that since subsidiary corporation did not conduct its own business as independent entity, but was maintained as instrument of finance corporation, service of process on registered agent of subsidiary was sufficiently served notice of action. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Farkar Co. v. R. A. Hanson DISC., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Under Washington law, a court will ignore nominal, corporate separation when there is such a commingling of property rights or interests as to render it apparent that corporations are intended to function as one, and, further, to regard them as separate would aid the consummation of a fraud or wrong upon others.
Document Preview: Buyer of excavation equipment filed petition to compel arbitration of dispute arising under contract for sale of excavation equipment, and sellers moved to dismiss. The District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) provision in purchase agreement to the effect that sellers would in no event be liable for consequential damages did not remove buyer's claim for consequential damages from subject matter jurisdiction of arbitrators; (2) district court would not direct arbitrators to make specific findings concerning clause in purchase agreement to the effect that sellers would in no event be liable for consequential damages, and (3) where wholly owned subsidiary which signed agreement to sell excavating equipment was alter ego of parent corporation, subsidiary's officers and directors were identical to those of parent, subsidiary had no employees, parent's personnel performed all of subsidiary's functions, and subsidiary had no inventory, buyer under purchase...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Westcott Const. Corp. v. Cumberland Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Separate corporate identities may be overlooked where, in addition to common ownership and management there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Bill was brought for declaratory relief in which corporate general bidder sought to establish propriety of bid submitted by it to joint board of water commissioners of two towns. The Superior Court, Norfolk County, Griffin, J., decreed the bid to be valid, and another bidder appealed. The Appeals Court, Armstrong, J., held that the general bid was not invalid on theory that corporate general bidder and corporate subbidder were essentially the same entity so that general bidder was therefore prohibited by statute from listing any other subbidder in general bid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Acme Precision Products, Inc. v. American Alloys Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where subsidiary corporation acts as direct instrumentality of and in direct cooperation with its parent corporation, and where properties and affairs of the two are so inextricably confused as to a particular transaction, the corporate structures cannot exist separate one from the other.
Document Preview: Patent infringement suit wherein defendant counterclaimed for treble damages under Sherman Anti-Trust Act. The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, William R. Collinson, J., found that patent was invalid and dismissed claim for infringement and counterclaim and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Lay, Circuit Judge, held that finding that assignee and licensee of patent obtained by assignee's subsidiary and licensee's predecessor had no knowledge of any fraud in procurement of patent upon which to ground claim for treble damages based upon monopoly in violation of Sherman Anti-Trust Act was clearly erroneous. Dismissal of counterclaim vacated and case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Philadelphia Storage Battery Co. v. Radio Corp. of Am.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: More than community of interest of two corporations in pursuit of common end, such as promotion of sales to public of products manufactured by one of them and sold by the other, must be shown before equity court will treat them as single corporation for purposes of given case.
Document Preview: Suit by the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company against the Radio Corporation of America, which filed a cross-bill. Decrees in accordance with opinion. Statement of the case. Disputes have arisen between the parties over whether the complainant breached the agreement not only with respect to the basis on which royalties are calculable and payable by the complainant to the defendant but with respect also to whether the agreement was breached by the complainant in regard to certain other of its terms. The complainant alleges that it has faithfully kept the agreement in all respects. As to the basis of computing royalties, it insists that while its method of calculating the same is...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Philadelphia Storage Battery Co. v. Radio Corp. of Am.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Two corporations, jointly interested in common result, such as purchases by public of products made by one and sold by the other, are not single company because they resort to economical methods of operation, saving expense to each, as by arranging for sales corporation's use of manufacturing company's factory to assemble such products.
Document Preview: Suit by the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company against the Radio Corporation of America, which filed a cross-bill. Decrees in accordance with opinion. Statement of the case. The complainant alleges that it has faithfully kept the agreement in all respects. As to the basis of computing royalties, it insists that while its method of calculating the same is...

Title: Ovation Finance Holdings 5 LLC v. G.E.T. Marketing, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Amarillo.
Headnote: Commonality of directors or managers alone does not permit courts to avoid corporations' separate identities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Limited liability companies (LLCs) with which insolvent member commercially interacted were not subject to receivership as member's business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC v. Caring Voice Coalition, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Shared leadership between parent companies and subsidiaries does not magically pierce the firewall separating an entity from its owner.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Parties. Assignees of health insurers did not have standing to bring antitrust claims against pharmaceutical and medical device companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts consider the following factors to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed, (2) whether the capitalization is adequate, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arm's length, (8) whether the corporation is treated as independent profit center, (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Former employee alleged that employer would not have laid her off but for her age, as required to state disparate-treatment claim under ADEA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brummett v. Bailey
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors, and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to find bar's owner and former owner personally liable for alleged assault on patron.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Lifetouch National School Studios Inc. v. Oklahoma School Pictures, LLC
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Mere fact that stockholders in two corporations are the same persons does not destroy the legal identity of the corporations, nor does the fact that one corporation may be in a position to exercise controlling influence through the ownership of stock, or the identity of stockholders, in itself operate to merge the two corporations for purposes of the theory of alter-ego liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Triable issues of fact existed as to whether LLC created judgment debtor as an instrumentality to wrongfully obtain clients and business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: GeoSolutions B.V. v. Sina.com Online
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Courts consider several factors to determine whether there is sufficient unity between two entities to pierce parent-subsidiary veil, including commingling of funds and other assets of entities, holding out by one entity that it is liable for debts of other, identical equitable ownership of entities, use of same offices and employees, use of one as mere shell or conduit for affairs of other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Dutch tech business and subsidiary did not establish unity between California businesses and any foreign defendant for general jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: GeoSolutions B.V. v. Sina.com Online
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Allegations of ownership and shared management personnel are insufficient to establish the required level of control to pierce the corporate veil between affiliated entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Dutch tech business and subsidiary did not establish unity between California businesses and any foreign defendant for general jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: A corporation's veil may not be pierced in order to hold a second corporation liable for the corporate misdeeds of the first when the two corporations have common individual shareholders but neither corporation has any ownership interest in the other corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: Despite the element of common shareholder identity, sister corporations are separate corporations and are unable to exercise control over each other in the manner that a controlling shareholder can; this lack of ability of one corporation to control the conduct of its sister corporation precludes application of the piercing-the-corporate-veil doctrine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hamilton v. Young Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts will not pierce the corporate veil based solely on a showing of common ownership and management.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Booking agent availed itself of the privilege of conducting activities in forum state, thus subjecting it to jurisdiction in injured traveler's suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under alter ego law in New York, allegations of complete ownership, common officers and personnel, and shared office space, without more, are insufficient to impose a subsidiary's contractual liability on its parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Estate of parent LLC succeeded to LLC's membership in special-purpose vehicle LLC, so automatic dissolution was not triggered for lack of members.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Riot Games, Inc. v. Suga PTE, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Total ownership and shared management personnel are alone insufficient to establish the requisite level of control to meet the unity of interest prong for alter ego liability under California law.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS  Jurisdiction. Vietnamese company committed an intentional act for exercise of personal jurisdiction by advertising and distributing infringing game in United States.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors weighing in favor of finding that entities are alter egos include overlap in staff, officers, and directors, absence of arms-length dealing, blurred lines of corporate control, and intermingled financial transactions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re PA Co-Man, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether parent corporation dominates over its subsidiary, as required to hold parent corporation liable for actions of subsidiary under Delaware law, include stock ownership, overlap of officers and directors, source of financing, responsibility for day-to-day operations, arrangements for payment of salaries and expenses, and origin of subsidiary's business and assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee's assignee asserted plausible claim to avoid pre-bankruptcy foreclosure sale of substantially all of debtor's assets for actual fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the factors that may be relevant to a finding of complete domination over a corporation that supports piercing the corporate veil include: the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; and other factors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Shopman's Local Union 502 Pension Fund v. Samuel Grossi & Sons, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Substantially identical ownership of two purportedly separate enterprises may be found, for purposes of determining whether the enterprises are in fact merely components of a single enterprise, where two enterprises are owned by members of the same family.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Proposed amendment to allege claims for single employer and alter ego plausibly alleged that companies were a single employer in ERISA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Shopman's Local Union 502 Pension Fund v. Samuel Grossi & Sons, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The common management factor, for purposes of determining whether two purportedly separate entities are in fact merely components of a single enterprise, requires the plaintiff to plead that key management functions at two separate entities were performed by the same group of people.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Proposed amendment to allege claims for single employer and alter ego plausibly alleged that companies were a single employer in ERISA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Butler Motors, Inc. v. Benosky
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil under the theory of the alter ego doctrine, courts will consider additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used, (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees, (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar, and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Amendments to Motor Vehicle Dealer Services Act as to charging document preparation fees did not expressly permit charging of fees of $200 or less.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under the enterprise theory for piercing the corporate veil to reach a corporation's affiliated entities, two or more corporations are treated as one because of [1] identity of ownership, [2] unified administrative control, [3] similar or supplementary business functions, [4] involuntary creditors, and [5] insolvency of the corporation against which the claim lies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: The fact that two companies have one-hundred percent common ownership is, alone, an insufficient basis for applying the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Buffalo Xerographix, Inc. v. Hartford Insurance Group
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts generally presume that directors holding positions with both a parent and a subsidiary are wearing their subsidiary hats, not their parent hats, when they act for the subsidiary; to overcome this presumption, a plaintiff must show that the directors were acting in their capacities as parent-company directors, and not as subsidiary directors, when they committed the relevant acts.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Property. Insured businesses could not sue subsidiary insurers' parent for subsidiaries' denial under property policies of claims related to COVID-19 pandemic.

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that weigh in favor of a finding that two entities are alter egos include overlap in staff, officers, and directors, absence of arms-length dealing, blurred lines of corporate control, and intermingled financial transactions.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Jurisdiction. Maritime vessel operator made prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction over Dubai company and Singapore company sufficient to defeat motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Peterson v. Colony American Finance Lender LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a parent corporation is not liable for the acts of its subsidiary merely because it owns, and votes, a majority of the subsidiary's stock or shares common shareholders, directors or officers with the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Lender that entered revolving loan agreement with transferee was neither initial transferee nor entity for whose benefit the transfers were made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, common officers and/or directors, and public identification of one corporation as the other's subsidiary, do not, without more, support the conclusion that subsidiary is its parent's alter ego or agent for the transaction of its business.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Title: Dill v. Rembrandt Group, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division VI.
Headnote: Commonality of officers and directors alone is not a basis to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Horizontal veil piercing was not supported where no evidence supported finding that sister corporations were alter egos of common owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Transparent GMU v. George Mason University
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: The mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not a sufficient justification for a court to disregard their separate corporate structure.
Document Preview: EDUCATION  Records. Privately held nonprofit corporation established to raise funds for the benefit of university was not subject to Virginia Freedom of Information Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors indicating that a corporation is the alter ego of another may include the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mou v. SSC San Jose Operating Company LP
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Among the factors to be considered in applying California "alter ego doctrine" are: (1) comingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, (2) holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, (3) identical equitable ownership in the two entities, (4) use of the same offices and employees, and (5) use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Pleading. Former nursing home resident failed to state claim for violation of California's UCL, predicated on alleged violations of various California and federal statutes and regulations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: When a corporation functions as an entity in the normal manner contemplated and permitted by law, there is nothing insidious in stockholder control, interlocking directorates, or identity of officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: United States ex rel. Fadlalla v. DynCorp International LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Courts consider the following factors to assess the strength of the unity of interest between the parent company and a subsidiary, as required to support piercing the corporate veil to hold parent company liable for subsidiary's misconduct: identity of ownership, commonality of officers and directors, the financial relationship between parent and subsidiary, whether the two maintain separate books, records, offices, and the like, and whether property of one is used by the other as essentially its own.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relators stated plausible FCA claim against contractor that provided translation services to US Army in Middle East under fraudulent inducement theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mills v. Ethicon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, in determining whether a subsidiary is acting as an agent of the parent, the court must consider four factors: (1) whether the subsidiary is doing business in the forum that would otherwise be performed by the parent, (2) whether there is common ownership of the parent and subsidiary, (3) whether there is financial dependency, and (4) whether the parent interferes with the subsidiary's personnel, disregards the corporate formalities, and/or controls the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Patient's complaint asserting negligence claims under Pennsylvania law failed to satisfy notice pleading requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mills v. Ethicon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Fact that the parent and subsidiary share the same brand is insufficient to impute alter ego status under New Jersey law.

Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Ohio law permits one corporation to own all of the stock of another corporation and employ common officers and directors, as well as other personnel, without risking shareholder liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dealers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil in suits against manufacturing corporation and its parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Factors for determining applicability of single-business-entity exception to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) identity of ownership; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in interest of that corporation; (5) corporate financing; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) causing incorporation of affiliated corporation; (8) payment of salaries and expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by affiliated corporations; (10) use of property; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by employees; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Landowner's complaint stated claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >

Headnote: Separate corporate forms will not be disregarded under Delaware law merely upon a showing of common management or whole ownership.
