Title: Lieberman v. Corporacion Experienca Unica, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: On a claim under Pennsylvania law to pierce the corporate veil, control through the ownership of shares does not fuse the corporations, even when the directors are common to each; moreover, even where dual officers and directors make policy decisions and supervise activities at the other company, liability does not exist unless a party can present facts showing that, despite the general presumption to the contrary, the officers and directors were acting in their capacities as officers and directors for the wrong company when they committed those acts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Initial capitalization of corporation that owned and managed resort did not support piercing the corporate veil under alter ego theory of liability.

Title: Lieberman v. Corporacion Experienca Unica, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Intertwining of corporations and their principals did not support piercing the corporate veil under alter ego theory of liability under Pennsylvania law, where corporation at issue adhered to formalities such as conducting board and shareholder meetings, maintaining insurance, filing tax returns, electing officers, titling assets in corporate name, keeping books and records, and producing audited financial statements.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Initial capitalization of corporation that owned and managed resort did not support piercing the corporate veil under alter ego theory of liability.

Headnote: Common ownership alone is insufficient to disregard the corporate form pursuant to the alter ego doctrine under California law.

Title: In re Pocius

Title: In re Atomica Design Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Elements of "single entity theory" of piercing corporate veil under Pennsylvania law include an identity of ownership, unified administrative control, similar or supplementary business functions, involuntary creditors, and insolvency of the corporation against which the claim lies.

Title: In re Atomica Design Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The single entity theory of piercing corporate veil under Pennsylvania law applies where two or more corporations share common ownership and are, in reality, operating as a corporate combine.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee lacked standing to assert Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under the federal common law test for piercing the corporate veil, liability is not imposed on a parent corporation for the acts of its subsidiary merely because a parent company's directors also serve as directors of a subsidiary; however, veil-piercing is appropriate when a parent so dominated the subsidiary that it had no separate existence or to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, or when recognition of the corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability for a crime.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator alleged nationwide scope of scheme with sufficient particularity in FCA action against physician advisor company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Adtile Technologies Inc. v. Perion Network Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Agency test that district courts use in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, such that a parent corporation may be held responsible for its subsidiary's actions, considers the degree of control which the parent exercises over the subsidiary by examining factors including extent of overlap of officers and directors, methods of financing, the division of responsibility for day-to-day management, and the process by which each corporation obtains its business; no one factor is either necessary or determinative, and it is the specific combination of elements which is significant.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal or general jurisdiction over Israeli corporation that did not advertise in forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Keg Restaurants Arizona, Inc. v. Jones
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: Factors proving substantially total control by a parent corporation over a subsidiary, as could allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent liable for acts of subsidiary, include common officers or directors, the parent's financing of the subsidiary, the parent's payment of the subsidiary's salaries and other expenses, the subsidiary's failure to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence, the similarity of the parent's and the subsidiary's logos, and the opposing parties' lack of knowledge of the subsidiary's separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Contract appointing franchisor as franchisee's agent regarding restaurant project was supported by consideration, even if not in form of money.

Title: Airbus DS Optronics GmbH v. Nivisys LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Substantially total control, as an element of an alter ego claim under Arizona law, may be proved by a number of factors, including stock ownership by the parent; common officers or directors; financing of subsidiary by the parent; payment of salaries and other expenses of subsidiary by the parent; failure of subsidiary to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence; similarity of logo; and plaintiff's lack of knowledge of subsidiary's separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor pleaded sufficient factual allegations to establish unity of control by parent corporation over subsidiaries.

Title: Semperit Technische Produkte Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Hennessy
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, a duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or an exercise of the control that stock ownership gives to stockholders.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. Texas had personal jurisdiction over Austrian manufacturer of high pressure hydraulic hose.

Title: Albuquerque Facility, LLC v. Danielson
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, where corporations share common officers or directors, that is one piece of evidence, although it is not enough in itself, that can show too close a relationship between the corporations, as required to support an alter ego claim.

Title: Continental Cas. Co. v. Symons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, where a court is asked to decide whether two or more affiliated corporations should be treated as a single entity, the alter-ego analysis considers whether similar corporate names were used; there were common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce veil and hold shareholders liable for crop insurance business buyers' fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to related corporations.

Title: DBT Yuma, L.L.C. v. Yuma County Airport Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: The factors to determine whether one corporate entity has substantial total control over another, as could support imposition of alter ego vicarious liability on entity with control, include whether one entity owned stock in the other entity, whether the two entities shared common officers or directors, whether one entity financed the other entity or paid the other entity's employees salaries or other expenses, whether one entity failed to maintain the formalities of corporate existence, whether the two entities shared similar logos, and whether one entity did not know it was a corporate entity separate from the other entity.

Title: Norfolk Southern Ry. Co. v. National Union Fire Ins. of Pittsburgh, PA

Headnote: Under West Virginia law, the mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not a sufficient justification for a court to disregard their separate corporate structure, and mutuality of interest is not sufficient either, without the countermingling of funds or property interests, or prejudice to creditors; rather it must be shown that the corporation is so organized and controlled as to be a mere adjunct or instrumentality of the other.

Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC

Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Alter ego relationship with claimant of attached ship was not shown.

Title: Capmark Financial Group Inc. v. Goldman Sachs Credit Partners L.P.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York and Delaware law, the separate corporate existences of parent and subsidiary will not be set aside merely on a showing of common management of the two entities, nor on a showing that the parent owned all the stock of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Reorganized debtors seeking to recover insider preferences failed to adequately allege elements for veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Capmark Financial Group Inc. v. Goldman Sachs Credit Partners L.P.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: That a subsidiary shares employees, officers, and directors with a parent does not permit the corporate form to be disregarded.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Reorganized debtors seeking to recover insider preferences failed to adequately allege elements for veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. v. Kolon Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Alter ego status cannot be established under New Jersey law by overlapping boards of directors alone.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Summons. Mailing provision of rule governing service of a criminal summons was not a component of effective service.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Washington Federal Sav. v. Van Engelen
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, August 2012 Term.
Headnote: Common control of a corporation and a limited-liability company by two individuals did not convert the corporation and the limited-liability company into a single entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Lender was not required to remind guarantors of existence of guaranty agreement before extending later loans.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Tanfield Engineering Systems, Inc. v. Thornton
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Even if the parent owns all of the subsidiary's stock and the two entities share common management, this does not operate as a merger of the two corporations into a single entity; corporate identity is not disregarded unless it is shown that one corporation is a mere instrumentality or agency or adjunct in that sense, or as a sham or is used in fraud, by the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent's full ownership of and common officers with subsidiary did not establish that subsidiary was parent's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether construction group was corporation's alter ego precluded summary judgment on claim to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil on the alter ego theory, the court considers whether: (1) similar corporate names were used, (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees, (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar, and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether construction group was corporation's alter ego precluded summary judgment on claim to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: For closely-held corporations, overlap in ownership, officers, and directors and use of common office space, address, and telephone numbers are not enough to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor's domination of corporations and use of those corporations to commit wrong permitted piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Carlton Energy Group, LLC v. Phillips
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that company was an alter ego of defendant company; defendant company's president, secretary/treasurer, and sole director was the general manager of company, and the two company names were used interchangeably in contracts and communications with multiple parties.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. Evidence supported damages award of $66.5 million to investor in natural gas project on tortious interference with contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Cameron v. Olin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, parent corporation and its subsidiary are treated as separate and distinct legal persons even though parent owns all shares in subsidiary and enterprises have identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Limitations. Texas statute of repose did not apply in products liability action against gun manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Union Ins. Co. v. Hull & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, mere identity of ownership and corporate management is not alone sufficient to permit a piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Arbitration and Appraisal. Dispute between insurer and insurance agency did not fall within the scope of an arbitration provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pan-American Products & Holdings, LLC v. R.T.G. Furniture Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, the application of the alter ego doctrine must be exercised reluctantly and cautiously; it is not enough that the stock in two corporations is held by the same individuals and that those two corporations share the same officers and directors.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Furniture designer's breach of contract claim against furniture retailers was not preempted by Copyright Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Moll Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In deciding, for alter ego purposes, whether corporation and its stockholder(s) operated as single economic unit, Delaware courts consider any: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of corporation at time; (5) siphoning of corporate funds; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) fact that corporation is merely facade for the operations of its dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Lenders' secured claims could not be recharacterized as equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, the fact that one person controls two corporations is not sufficient to make the two corporations and the controlling stockholder the same person under the law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Under New Hampshire law, corporation was not liable for the negligence of its sister corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hach Co. v. Hakuto Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Having common directors or officers is generally a prerequisite to piercing the corporate veil for personal jurisdictional purposes, but it is not sufficient in and of itself.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Buyer made out colorable claim of personal jurisdiction over seller's Japanese parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: West Ridge Group, LLC v. First Trust Co. of Onaga
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Two separate corporations with common parent could not be treated as single entity under Colorado law by mere fact of common ownership.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Term pro rata in promissory note referred to ratio of values of property, rather than ratio of mere acres.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The alter ego test encompasses a host of factors, including: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, (3) the failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same, (4) the holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and the confusion of the records of the separate entities, (5) the identical equitable ownership in the two entities, the identification of the equitable owners thereof with the domination and control of the two entities, identification of the directors and officers of the two entities in the responsible supervision and management, sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by one individual or the members of a family, (6) the use of the same office or business location, the employment of the same employees and/or attorney, (7) the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation, the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization, (8) the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation, (9) the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, (10) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, (11) the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity, (12) the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another, (13) the contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of a corporate entity as a shield against personal liability, or the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions, and (14) and the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Res judicata did not prohibit amendment of judgment to add debtor, under alter ego theory, who was successful in underlying arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lake City Janitorial, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: While having common officers and directors is generally a prerequisite to piercing the corporate veil, this factor is insufficient to justify disregarding the corporate form because it does not, in itself, show that corporation is really dummy or sham for dominating personality, but only that there was opportunity to create unity of interest.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Common law fraud claim against corporations' owner was not preempted by ERISA or LMRA and was pled with enough particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: One corporation dominated and controlled other corporation, and thus corporate veil of dominating corporation could be pierced to hold it liable under New York law for debts of dominated corporation, where those corporations did not adhere to corporate formalities, they had overlapping owners, officers, directors, and personnel, they did not deal with each other at arm's length and were not independent profit centers, dominated corporation had inadequate capitalization based on its conceded insolvency, and they shared office space and equipment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego could be jointly and severally liable for all damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Moncrief Oil Intern., Inc. v. OAO Gazprom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, a duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or an exercise of the control that stock ownership gives to stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have jurisdiction over Russian natural gas company, in trade secret and tortious interference action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Lee v. Arnan Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Closely associated corporations, even ones that share directors and officers, will not be considered "alter egos" of each other if: they were formed for different purposes, neither is a subsidiary of the other, their finances are not integrated, assets are not commingled, and the principals treat the two entities as separate and distinct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Construction companies owned by same individual were not alter egos of each other.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Vanderbilt Mortg. and Finance, Inc. v. Flores
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Corpus Christi Division.
Headnote: To determine whether parent corporation has complete control over subsidiary, for purposes of applying alter ego doctrine under Texas law, courts examine whether: (1) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (2) parent finances subsidiary; (3) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (4) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (5) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (6) daily operations of the corporations are not kept separate; (7) directors of subsidiary act in primary and independent interest of parent; and (8) alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arms' length.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Manufactured home purchasers had standing to sue under Texas fraudulent lien statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Larco, Inc. v. Strebeck
Court: Court of Appeals of Arkansas.
Headnote: All corporations, regardless of the fact that the holders of stock and the officers of the corporation are identical, are separate and distinct legal entities, and thus, it follows that, in the absence of facts on which liability can be predicated, one such corporation is not liable for the debts of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court clearly erred in finding that corporations were jointly and severally liable for commissions owed to employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Larco, Inc. v. Strebeck
Court: Court of Appeals of Arkansas.
Headnote: The facts that two corporations are practically under the control of the same persons, who are the owners of a large majority of the stock, and that the two corporations have intimate business relations do not prove that the two corporations are in fact one and the same.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court clearly erred in finding that corporations were jointly and severally liable for commissions owed to employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. v. The ADS Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, when analyzing the domination and control element, a court considers: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed; (2) whether the capitalization is adequate; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Controlling corporation to produce products that infringed patent was not inducement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Test to determine alter ego status is whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Essential inquiry under an alter ego analysis is whether there was a bona fide discontinuance and a true change of ownership or merely a disguised continuance of the old employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the eighteen factors a court must look at in determining whether to apply single business enterprise (SBE) theory to fuse either affiliated or unaffiliated corporations for jurisdictional purposes include: whether one corporation has sufficient ownership interest in another to give it actual working control, whether common directors or officers exist, whether a unified administrative control apparatus is present, whether the business functions of the companies are similar or supplementary, whether the directors of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation or instead in the interest of another corporation, whether one corporation finances or pays the salaries and expenses of another corporation, whether one corporation is inadequately capitalized or receives no business other than that given to it by another corporation, whether a corporation uses the property of another corporation as its own, complies with corporate formalities, or keeps common employees or offices with another corporation, and whether financial transactions suggest that two companies that are separate in form are in fact a single enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Common ownership is not dispositive in determining whether related companies constitute a single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law even when the common ownership amounts to complete ownership, such as when two affiliated companies are wholly owned subsidiaries of a single parent corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re England Motor Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: General rule of law in Mississippi is that two or more corporations maintain their distinct legal identities even though the same individual may own stock in the several corporations and even though such corporations may have the same person as officers.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Substantive consolidation of parent company's case with those of its subsidiaries did not create setoff mutuality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations suggesting some overlap between operations of parent corporation and its subsidiaries, including claims that parent and subsidiaries were considered as a whole in credit agreement and substantial overlap of officers and directors, were not, without more, sufficient to impose alter ego liability on the parent under Minnesota or Indiana law for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Class Actions. Insureds could not fairly or adequately represent putative class, barring class certification in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brookridge Funding Corp. v. Aquamarine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Although common ownership of the stock of two or more corporations together with common management, standing alone, will not give rise to liability under Massachusetts law on the part of one corporation for the acts of another corporation or its employees, additional facts may be such as to permit the conclusion that an agency or similar relationship exists between the entities, particularly (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fish buyer was not unjustly enriched at secured lender's expense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gordon v. Greenview Hosp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: Fact that a subsidiary corporation is wholly owned by the parent corporation or that corporations have same directors and officers does not suffice to show that the two are alter egos.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Presence of hospital's director's offices in Tennessee was insufficient to justify exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, wholly-owned subsidiaries may share officers, directors, and employees with their parent, without requiring the court to infer, for purposes of veil-piercing, that the subsidiary is a mere instrumentality for the parent and without requiring the court to conclude that those officers and directors were not functioning properly.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Unsecured creditors committee failed to establish that piercing debtor's corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: It is entirely appropriate for directors of a parent corporation to serve as directors of its subsidiary, and that fact alone may not serve to expose the parent corporation to liability for its subsidiary's acts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Unsecured creditors committee failed to establish that piercing debtor's corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: the disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, common office space or telephone numbers, the degree of discretion demonstrated by the allegedly dominated corporation, whether dealings between the entities are at arm's length, whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and the payment or guaranty of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; but no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts look to several non-exclusive factors to determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, addresses and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Saba Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, although no one factor is dispositive, ten factors may be considered in determining the sufficiency of parent domination over the subsidiary for purposes of piercing the corporate veil: (1) absence of corporate formalities and paraphernalia, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) movement of funds for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space and contact information, (6) limited amount of business discretion exercised by the subsidiary, (7) lack of arms' length dealings between the parent and the subsidiary, (8) failure to treat relevant entities as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the subsidiary's debts by the parent, and (10) use by the parent of the subsidiary's property as if the property were owned by the parent.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee satisfied fraud pleading rule in asserting actual fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, proof of identity of shareholders or of corporate directors and officers or of domination by parent of its subsidiary's affairs will not alone justify treatment of the two as one business unit, nor will parent's ownership of 100% of subsidiary's stock.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil on alter ego theory, Texas courts look to the total dealings of corporation and the parent/shareholder, including: (1) whether parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) have common stock ownership; (3) have common business departments; or (4) file consolidated financial statements; (5) whether parent finances the subsidiary; (6) whether parent caused incorporation of the subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital; (8) whether parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) whether subsidiary has any business except through parent; (10) whether parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) whether daily operations of the two corporations are kept separate; and (12) failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Board of Managers of 195 Hudson Street Condominium v. Jeffrey M. Brown Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under New York law, courts consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether alleged dominator deals with corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) intermingling of property between alleged dominator and corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Condominium association board's claim against holding company was precluded by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: New York Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Perimeter Interiors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Two businesses are alter egos if they have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Corporation did not have to pay contributions for payments to president, precluding pension funds' recovery in ERISA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Helm v. Alderwoods Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: In order to prove that a parent corporation is directly liable for the acts of its subsidiaries, a plaintiff must do more than show that the parent and subsidiary share a board of directors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Court had personal jurisdiction over non-resident parent company based on actions of local subsidiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gass v. Anna Hosp. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: The use of common officers and directors does not render one corporation liable for the obligations of another.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Venue. Personal representative of patient's estate failed to join hospital's parent corporation in good faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant to determining whether a corporation's form should be respected include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Pleading. Allegations were sufficient to sustain claims for aiding and abetting apartheid against automotive manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Having common directors and officers is a normal business practice of a multi-national corporation and absent complete control it is no justification to labeling a subsidiary a mere department of the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Service of subpoena on American subsidiary of Israeli bank was not effective against parent bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Overlapping officers and directors are intrinsic to a parent-subsidiary relationship, and such overlap is not determinative as to whether the subsidiary is a mere department of the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Service of subpoena on American subsidiary of Israeli bank was not effective against parent bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Jones ex rel. Jones v. Enterprise Leasing Company-Southeast
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Common officers and/or directors and public identification of one corporation as the other's subsidiary do not, without more, support the conclusion the subsidiary is its parent's alter ego or agent for the transaction of its business.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligent Entrustment. Car rental agency's parent corporation was not liable to injured motorist on theory of negligent entrustment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, when two entities with common ownership fail to follow legal formalities when contracting with each other, this is tantamount to declaring that they are indeed one in the same, for veil-piercing purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Renaissance Leasing, LLC. v. Vermeer Mfg. Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: The mere identity of members of officers of two companies does not result in an identity of interest between the two entities, so as to confer standing; each company is a distinct legal entity with the right to own property, sue and be sued, contract, and acquire and transfer property. V.A.M.S. §§ 347.061, 347.069.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Limited liability company lacked standing to assert contract breach claim against seller of equipment it allegedly acquired.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant to determining whether a corporation's form should be respected include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Commodity Futures. Market manipulation claim under Commodity Exchange Act was not stated against CEO of investment advisory company.

Title: Classic Maritime Inc. v. Limbungan Makmur SDN BHD
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a company is the alter ego of another, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil, a court considers the following factors, among others: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm"s length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner asserted valid maritime claim against guarantor of charter contracts, supporting attachment of $20,457,047.72.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Sun Microsystems Inc. v. Hynix Semiconductor Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Fact that parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary shared two board members, or that parent shared some supervision of finance and pricing decisions did not justify any inference of agency so as to subject parent to liability for subsidiary's actions.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Pricing. Summary judgment in favor of parent corporation was precluded on price-fixing conspiracy claim based on agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Middlesex Retirement System, LLC v. Board of Assessors of Billerica
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Common ownership and common management, alone, generally will not permit disregard of the formal barriers between separate legal entities, pursuant to doctrine of corporate disregard.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Real property owned by limited liability company created by governmental unit was not exempt from taxation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Arctic Ocean Intern., Ltd. v. High Seas Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When considering whether to pierce a corporate veil based on allegations of alter ego liability, courts may consider the following factors: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Eleven months of failed attempts at locating funds subject to Rule B maritime attachment rendered court without jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Minno v. Pro-Fab, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: A corporation's veil may not be pierced in order to hold a second corporation liable for the corporate misdeeds of the first when the two corporations have common individual shareholders but neither corporation has any ownership interest in the other corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee of subcontractor could not pierce corporate veil to hold sister company liable for unsafe work conditions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Minno v. Pro-Fab, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: Despite the element of common shareholder identity, sister corporations are separate corporations and are unable to exercise control over each other in the manner that a controlling shareholder can; this lack of ability of one corporation to control the conduct of its sister corporation precludes application of the piercing-the-corporate-veil doctrine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee of subcontractor could not pierce corporate veil to hold sister company liable for unsafe work conditions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gateway I Group, Inc. v. Park Ave. Physicians, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Indicia of a situation warranting veil-piercing include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord's allegations were sufficient to state claim that medical groups assumed assignment of lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The use of common officers and directors, or the sharing of office space, without more, does not render one corporation liable for the obligations of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Troyk v. Farmers Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Factors for the trial court to consider in applying alter ego doctrine include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; no one characteristic governs, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Premiums. Premium in statute requiring insurance policy to state the premium, includes service charge imposed for payment of stated insurance premium for term policy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Western States Wholesale Natural Gas Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Parent corporation may review and approve major decisions, place its own directors on its wholly owned subsidiary's board, and share offices and staff with subsidiary without being considered subsidiary's alter ego.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Jurisdiction. Natural gas company's forum contacts could not be attributed to parent corporation, as its agent, for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether complete domination exists, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Telenor Mobile Communications AS v. Storm LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Contempt. Sanction of $100,000 per day, doubling every 30 days until shareholder complied with arbitration award, was appropriate.

Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Corporations are not liable for each other's obligations merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; there must also be evidence of abuse, or injustice and inequity, meaning not a subjective perception of unfairness by an individual judge or juror, but rather, fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations can not be held liable for each other's obligations merely because they are part of a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Capital Technology Information Services, Inc. v. Arias & Arias Consultores
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent corporation, as required for exercise of jurisdiction over parent corporation, merely because of: (1) stock ownership; (2) a duplication of some or all of the directors or officers; or (3) an exercise of the control that stock ownership gives to stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Personal jurisdiction could be exercised over wholly-owned subsidiary fused with its parent corporation.

Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant under New York law to determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of fluids; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.

Title: Ketchem v. American Acceptance, Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, while no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors, and officers, may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debtor stated claim under FDCPA for improperly seeking attorney fees for representation by related entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the separate corporate entities of two corporations may not be disregarded merely because one owns the stock of another; the principle that a corporation is a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders, directors, and officers applies even where one corporation wholly owns another and the two have mutual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that debtor was alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, while having common officers and directors is generally a prerequisite to piercing the corporate veil, this factor is insufficient to justify disregarding the corporate form because it is a common business practice that exists in most parent and subsidiary relationships.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that debtor was alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To determine "alter ego" status in situation where new employer is merely disguised continuance of the old, court asks whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; no one of these factors is controlling but rather analysis is flexible, and court evaluates all relevant factors together and can find alter ego status even if not all of them are present.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Electrical contractor whose president signed letters of assent was bound by CBAs expressly incorporated by reference therein.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Sandoval v. American Building Maintenance Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Factors for ascertaining whether one company so dominates or controls another company such that liability must be imputed to first company include: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) centralized control of labor relations; (3) common management; and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Alleged sexual harassers lacked actual authority to make significant changes in employee status.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Galvan v. Caviness Packing Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: In determining if a company is the alter ego of another, district courts consider a "laundry list" of factors, including whether or not the two companies have common stock ownership, common directors or officers, common business departments, file consolidated tax returns or financial statements, are jointly financed, are incorporated together, if one operates with grossly inadequate capital, if salaries and expenses of one are paid by the other, if all business of one is provided by the other, if property of one is used by the other as its own, if daily operations are not kept separately, and if one company does not observe the basic corporate formalities.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Several plaintiffs in representative action could not maintain retaliation claims against their employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Dewey v. Volkswagen AG
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: To determine if a subsidiary is acting as an agent of the parent under New Jersey law, courts consider (1) whether the subsidiary is doing business in the forum that would otherwise be performed by the parent, (2) whether there is common ownership of the parent and subsidiary, (3) whether there is financial dependency, and (4) whether the parent interferes with the subsidiary's personnel, disregards the corporate formalities, and or controls the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. United States subsidiary was an agent by law of manufacturer for purpose of service of process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: K.C. Properties of N.W. Arkansas, Inc. v. Lowell Inv. Partners, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: All corporations, regardless of the fact that the holders of stock and the officers of the corporation are identical, are separate and distinct legal entities; and it follows that, in the absence of facts on which liability can be predicated, one such corporation is not liable for the debts of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Statute did not allow minority LLC member to bring breach of fiduciary duty claim against members of management LLC.
