Title: U.S. ex rel. Wilkins v. North American Const. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, twelve factors to be assessed when determining whether a subsidiary is the alter ego of its parent are: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements and tax returns; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; and (12) subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Allegations of hidden costs did not meet requirements of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bestfoods v. Aerojet-General Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Courts generally presume that the directors are wearing their subsidiary hats and not their parent hats when acting for the subsidiary.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Corporation's oversight of subsidiary was within norms, defeating CERCLA cost recovery claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: MAG Portfolio Consult, GMBH v. Merlin Biomed Group LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors in whether veil-piercing is appropriate include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Successor companies could not be compelled to arbitrate under agreement they were not party to.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Russell v. Enterprise Rent-A-Car Co. of Rhode Island
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: To determine whether parent corporation and its subsidiary maintained separate corporate identities for alter ego analysis, district court examines factors that demonstrate whether corporate formalities have been observed, including whether parent corporation and its subsidiary were separately incorporated, had separate boards of directors, maintained separate financial records, and had separate facilities and operating personnel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer's non-resident parent corporation was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: One Pacific Towers Homeowners' Ass'n v. HAL Real Estate Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Courts will not imply an overt intent to disregard the corporate form from the presence of common directors, shareholders, or a common business address.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Holding corporation and its subsidiaries were declarants under the condominium act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Government of Virgin Islands, Bureau of Internal Revenue v. Lansdale
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix.
Headnote: Some factors relevant to piercing the corporate veil under California law include commingling funds and other assets, unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, treatment by individual of corporation's assets as his own, holding out by individual that he is personally liable for corporation's debts, identical equitable ownership in two entities, identification of equitable owners, directors and officers thereof with domination and control of two entities, sole ownership of all of stock in corporation by one individual or members of family, failure to adequately capitalize corporation, total absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for single venture or business of individual, disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate assets in one and liabilities in another, or use of corporation as subterfuge of illegal transactions, and formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporations' acts and omissions could be attributed to owners to satisfy Virgin Islands' long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Smotherman v. Texaco Exploration and Production, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Factors to consider in applying alter ego doctrine to subsidiary corporation include: (1) common stock ownership; (2) common directors or officers; (3) common business departments; (4) filing of consolidated financial and tax statements; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of two corporations are not kept separate; (12) subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings; or (13) directors and officers of subsidiary act independently in the interest of that company, or whether they take their orders from parent and act in parent's interest.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Texas corporation was fraudulently to destroy diversity jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Singer Co., N.V.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Common ownership alone is insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Licenses. Implied license to use patent arose on equitable estoppel theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: To determine whether one corporation completely controls another, for purposes of piercing corporate veil, court considers whether (1) parent owns all or most of subsidiary's stock, (2) corporations have common directors or officers, (3) parent finances subsidiary, (4) parent causes incorporation of subsidiary, (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) parent pays subsidiary's expenses or losses, (7) subsidiary lacks its own substantial business or assets, (8) parent's corporate papers describe subsidiary as department or division, (9) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own, (10) subsidiary's directors or executives take orders from parent in parent's interest, or (11) subsidiary fails to observe legal formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gammill v. Lincoln Life and Annuity Distributors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Jackson Division.
Headnote: Factors in whether corporate veil may be pierced under Mississippi law include whether: (1) parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers "subsidiary" is referred to as such or as department or division; (9) subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in subsidiary's interest but take direction from parent; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mere fact of parent-subsidiary relationship was insufficient to establish alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Soerries v. Dancause
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, sole ownership of a corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends, but rather there must be evidence of abuse of the corporate form, and plaintiff must show that the defendant disregarded the separateness of legal entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties, records or control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support verdict piercing corporate veil in dramshop case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Sigros v. Walt Disney World Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Common ownership coupled with common management of two or more corporations will not give rise to liability of one corporation for the acts of another without additional facts indicating the existence of an agency or similar relationship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Affiliated corporation acted as agent for resort owner for purposes of Massachusetts' long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: The following factors may be considered in determining whether a group of entities constitute a "single business enterprise" for purposes of imposing common liability, although factors are not exhaustive and no single factor is dispositive: (1) corporations with identity or substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation; (5) corporation financing another corporation; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) corporation causing the incorporation of another affiliated corporation; (8) corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; (10) corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: It is considered a normal attribute of ownership that officers and directors of a parent corporation serve as officers and directors of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Factors that New York courts consider in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are as follows: (1) whether corporate formalities were observed; (2) whether capitalization was adequate; (3) whether funds were put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) whether corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporation is treated as independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were his/her own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, incidents of common ownership and management, standing alone, are not enough to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Medina v. Four Winds Intern. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, parent corporation and subsidiary's unity of ownership and interlocking directorates, standing alone, are not sufficient basis upon which to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Daimler-Benz Aktiengesellschaft v. Olson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts must examine all relevant circumstances to determine whether parent and subsidiary should be considered separate or joined; some factors that may be considered include whether distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are maintained, whether daily operations are separate, whether formal barriers between management of the two entities are erected, whether consolidated tax returns are filed, whether operating capital is financed by parent or borrowed from other sources, whether subsidiary's stock is owned by parent, whether the two share common officers and directors, extent to which separate books and accounts are kept, whether both have common departments of businesses, whether they have separate meetings of shareholders and directors, whether officer or director of one corporation is permitted to determine policies of the other, whether those with whom corporation comes into contact are apprised of their separate identity, and extent to which contracts between parent and subsidiary favor one over the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Texas court had personal jurisdiction over German car manufacturer.

Title: Williams v. Vanaria
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division, District Court Department, Northern District.
Headnote: Even the identity of stockholders and the control of the new corporation do not operate to merge the old and the new corporations or to make either the agent of the other.-Williams v. Vanaria.
Document Preview: This is an action against a corporate employer and individual officers of the corporation to recover payment allegedly due under the plaintiff's employment agreement for expenses he incurred. The record indicates that individual defendants Steven and Robert Vanaria were officers and directors of defendant Vanaria Contracting Co., Inc. (Vanaria), a Massachusetts corporation primarily engaged in the construction business of commercial site excavation. At some point in the mid 1980's, plaintiff Robert Williams became employed by Vanaria as a truck driver. He received an hourly wage, plus gasoline and other expenses for a truck that he drove for the company and between his home and Vanaria job sites. The plaintiff's wages and expense reimbursements were at all times paid by Vanaria corporate checks drawn on Vanaria corporate accounts. The plaintiff was listed as an employee on Vanaria's books, and the required taxes, insurance and other payroll deductions were taken by...

Title: Oxford Capital Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether assets of parent corporation may be levied upon to satisfy tax liabilities of subsidiary, factors to consider include: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; (12) subsidiary does not observe corporate formalities. 26 U.S.C.A. § 7426.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Judge failed to apply proper burden-shifting analysis to levy.

Title: In re SunSport, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: If two corporations have an identity of corporate officers and shareholders, and in addition they commingle their assets and business affairs, court may conclude that the technical legal separateness of the two entities should be ignored.

Title: Dewhurst v. Telenor Invest AS
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Stock ownership and the sharing of directors are insufficient grounds in themselves to justify disregarding the corporate form.

Title: Retzler v. Pratt and Whitney Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, sole ownership of stock and common directors and officers between parent and subsidiary are only some of the factors to be considered in determining whether or not the corporate fiction should be disregarded and the shareholders held liable.

Title: De Castro v. Sanifill, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate form, courts normally conduct a highly fact-specific inquiry, including, inter alia, consideration of: the extent to which a subsidiary may have disregarded corporate formalities; the degree of control exercised by the parent over the day-to-day operations of the subsidiary; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; and whether the subsidiary was adequately capitalized, and adequacy of capital is determined within the context of the relevant corporate purposes and activities.

Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, as will allow corporate veil to be pierced under New Jersey law, courts apply the traditional common law factors, including the presence in both corporations of the same officers, directors, and shareholders, financial support of the subsidiary's operations by the parent, whether the property of the subsidiary is used by the parent corporation as its own, the failure of a subsidiary to observe the formal requirements attributable to its operation, and the involvement of the parent's corporate officers in the day-to-day business of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Transportation broker brought suit in state court against freight forwarders, alleging breach of contract. After action was removed, and order was entered with respect to discovery disputes, 181 F.R.D. 229, defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Arcara, J., adopted the report and recommendation of Foschio, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) fact that transportation broker had failed to obtain license from Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) to perform brokering services did not render agreement unenforceable; (2) fact issues as to whether contractual agreement existed, and if so, nature of relationship created, precluded summary judgment; and (3) broker failed to establish basis to pierce corporate veil of forwarder which was not party to agreement. Report and recommendation adopted, and motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors to aid in determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced, for jurisdictional purposes are: (1) common ownership, (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent, (3) the degree to which the parent interferes in the selection of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formality, and (4) the degree of the parent's control over the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies; first factor, common ownership, is essential to the assertion of jurisdiction over a foreign related corporation, while the other three factors are "important."

Numerous counterclaims and cross-claims were asserted. Conner, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) affiliates were subject to personal jurisdiction pursuant to doing business jurisdictional statute because they were acting as mere departments of parent corporations which were present in New York; (2) affiliates transacted business in New York within the meaning of New York's long-arm statute; (3) action would not be dismissed on the ground of forum non conveniens; (4)...

Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, degree of control necessary for finding parent corporation is alter ego of subsidiary is not mere majority or complete stock control but such domination of finances, policies and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal; thus, one-hundred percent ownership and identity of directors and officers are, even together, an insufficient basis for applying the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil
Document Preview: Guest at hotel in Mexico sued corporate manager and its parent corporation for negligence in connection with drowning death of her husband. In accordance with recommendations of magistrate judge, the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Orlando L. Garcia, J., dismissed action. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, DeMoss, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) liability was not imputable to parent corporation under either the alter ego or single business enterprise doctrine, and (2) district court had neither specific nor general jurisdiction over hotel's corporate manager. Affirmed.

Title: Siebert v. Bleichman
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: When several corporations have agents who manage a business so that the public is under the impression that they are all one and the same, a corporation should be bound by their representations and should not benefit from the confusion that emanates from their corporate complexities.

Title: Doe v. Gelineau
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: The mere fact that a person holds an office in two corporations that may be dealing with each other and that have offices in the same building, without more, is not enough to make them identical in contemplation of law.

Title: Toshiba America Medical Systems, Inc. v. Mobile Medical Systems, Inc.

Headnote: The identity rule for piercing the corporate veil primarily applies to prevent injustice in the situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of the existence of common owners, officers, directors or shareholders and because of the lack of observance of corporate formalities between the two entities.

Title: In re Plantation Realty Trust
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veil may be pierced in order to impute liability among differing corporate entities: (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of that intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Title: Architectural Iron Workers Local No. 63 Welfare Fund v. United Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Determination of whether two ostensibly separate business entities share common management, as part of inquiry into whether one is alter ego of the other, emphasizes common control over hiring and firing of employees as well as other daily management decisions.
Document Preview: Union-administered employee benefit funds sued employer and employer's nonunion parent corporation under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), alleging employer's failure to make contributions required under collective bargaining agreement, and seeking contributions from parent as alter ego of employer. Parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Guzman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that parent in creating subsidiary did not have intent to avoid collective bargaining obligations. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Conservatorship of Prom v. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining if parent corporation controls subsidiary to such an extent that separate corporate identity of subsidiary should be disregarded are (1) common stock ownership, (2) overlapping directors and officers, (3) combined use of corporate offices, (4) capitalization of subsidiary by parent, (5) financing of subsidiary by parent, (6) control of subsidiary's stock by parent, (7) use of the subsidiary's property by parent, (8) intercorporate loans, (9) parental incorporation of subsidiary, (10) consolidated tax returns, (11) independent decision making by subsidiary, (12) independent decision making by directors of subsidiary, (13) observance of formal corporate legal requirements, (14) contracts between subsidiary and parent, and (15) fraud or injustice to third parties.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Process. Japanese corporation did not transact business in Wisconsin, for purposes of process statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bostick v. Schall's Brakes and Repairs, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To determine whether a successor corporation has been established as an "alter ego" of a former corporation and, thus, may be held liable for the former corporation's debts and liabilities, a court must analyze the following factors with respect to the two entities: (1) centralized control of labor relations; (2) common management; (3) interrelation of operations; and (4) common ownership and financial control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Fact questions precluded summary judgment in action to establish putative successor's liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Glover v. Heart of America Management Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In determining whether sufficient integration exists to treat corporations as single, integrated "employer" such that corporations are liable for employment decisions of other, court must consider whether there is: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) common management; (3) centralized control of labor relations; and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: Former restaurant employee brought action against former employer, co-worker, company that managed umbrella of restaurants, corporation which owned restaurants under umbrella, alleging Title VII sex harassment and retaliation, and common law intentional infliction of emotional distress. On all defendants' motion for summary judgment, except co-worker, the District Court, Vratil, J., held that: (1) employee established prima facie case of retaliation; (2) claimed distress from harassment was not so severe, genuine, and extreme as to constitute intentional infliction of emotional distress; and (3) corporation which owned restaurants under was not employer, under integrated enterprise theory. Motion granted in part, and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: West Virginia Highlands Conservancy, Inc. v. Public Service Com'n of West Virginia
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: It is entirely appropriate for directors of a parent corporation to serve as directors of its subsidiary, and that fact alone may not serve to expose the parent corporation to liability for its subsidiary's acts.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Industry Regulation. Public Service Commission could not review sale of land by public utility holding company's relative.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Miners, Inc. v. Alpine Equipment Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: "Enterprise entity theory" or the "single entity theory" of piercing the corporate veil applies when two or more corporations share common ownership and are, in reality, operating as a corporate combine.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations lacked identity of ownership necessary to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Miners, Inc. v. Alpine Equipment Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under "single entity theory" of piercing the corporation veil, two or more corporations are treated as one because of identity of ownership, unified administrative control, similar or supplementary business functions, involuntary creditors, and insolvency of the corporation against which the claim lies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations lacked identity of ownership necessary to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Miners, Inc. v. Alpine Equipment Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporations did not have "identity of ownership" necessary to pierce corporate veils under "single entity theory," even though same shareholder controlled 60% of the stock of each corporation, since the remaining 40% of the respective corporations was not owned by the same individuals or entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations lacked identity of ownership necessary to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: AT & T Global Information Solutions Co. v. Union Tank Car Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, one corporation may own all of the stock of another corporation and employ common officers and directors, as well as other personnel, without risking veil piercing.
Document Preview: Potentially responsible parties (PRPs) who entered consent order with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) concerning cleanup of solvent reclamation site brought contribution action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) against subsidiary and grandparent corporations concerning alleged disposal of subsidiary's waste at site. On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Holschuh, J., held that: (1) evidence that subsidiary created toxic waste and had it deposited at site supported imposition of arranger liability against subsidiary under CERCLA; (2) Ohio law would apply to issue of piercing corporate veil of grandparent company; and (3) evidence that grandparent company exercised dominion and control over subsidiary, that piercing of corporate veil was necessary to prevent injustice, and that subsidiary would have been liable in CERCLA contribution action if subsidiary had not been dissolved by grandparent, supported piercing...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary, parent must exercise complete domination and control in the matter; stock control, interlocking directors, and interlocking officers are in and of themselves insufficient facts to justify imposition of such liability on parent, but control by parent over subsidiary's everyday operations will render parent liable for subsidiary's acts.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Parent of manufacturing subsidiary was equitably estopped from denying that it manufactured product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Satellite Cable Services, Inc. v. Northern Electric Co-op., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Mere fact that one corporation owns all or a majority of the stock of another, or that two corporations have common officers or directors, will not render a parent automatically answerable for acts of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: City's community antenna television system (CATV) provider brought action against rural electric cooperative and its subsidiary, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and damages for interference with contractual and prospective contractual relations. The Circuit Court, Fifth Judicial Circuit, Day County, Myles J. DeVine, J., enjoined electric cooperative and subsidiary from offering cable television service, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Konenkamp, J., held that: (1) amendment removing statutory restrictions on electric cooperatives' competition with CATV providers in municipalities required injunction be set aside; (2) electric cooperative was entitled to be member of cooperative formed to bring television signals to rural areas and small towns; (3) electric cooperative could not offer television service, under former statutory scheme, by merely creating another cooperative singly consisting of its own subsidiary; and (4) to extent rural electric cooperative was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pirelli Armstrong Tire Corp. v. Titan Tire Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, despite common officers and common address, corporate veil of subsidiary would not be pierced to reach parent company, where subsidiary observed corporate formalities, maintained appropriate corporate records, maintained arm's length relationship with parent company, and was adequately capitalized.
Document Preview: Tire manufacturer brought action against buyer of its plant and buyer's parent company alleging violations of federal trademark laws and Illinois Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, deceptive trade practices, unfair competition, and breach of asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. On parties' cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was not warranted; (2) trademarks were valid; (3) manufacturer's claims were not barred by doctrines of estoppel or laches; (4) defendant infringed and diluted manufacturer's trademarks; (5) defendant unlawfully passed off its tires as those of manufacturer; and (6) defendant breached asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. Judgment for tire manufacturer against competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, Massachusetts courts consider twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) insufficient capitalization for purposes of the corporate undertaking; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) nonpayment of dividends; (7) insolvency of corporation at the time of the transaction; (8) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant shareholders; (9) nonfunctioning of officers and directors other than the shareholders; (10) absence of corporate records; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Cranberry supplier, who had not received payment, brought action against buyer, buyer's controlling shareholder, and company to which buyer had delivered the cranberries, asserting claims under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA), for misrepresentation, and for violations of the Massachusetts Fraudulent Conveyance Act and the Massachusetts Unfair Trade Practices Act.  The District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) supplier was not entitled to PACA trust protection; (2) alter-ego theory did not apply, so as to impose liability for debt on either shareholder or transferee company; (3) shareholder was not liable for any misrepresentation; and (4) shareholder's transfers of property were not fraudulent conveyances. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Richfood, Inc. v. Jennings
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not sufficient justification for court to disregard their separate corporate structure.
Document Preview: Food distributor and its wholly-owned subsidiary insurance company brought action seeking reimbursement of insurance premium refund from former shareholders of grocery store corporation, of which food distributor had also been shareholder, following sale of grocery store corporation.  The Circuit Court, Hanover County, Richard H.C. Taylor, J., granted summary judgment for former shareholders, and food distributor and insurance company appealed. The Supreme Court, Kinser, J., held that: (1) release agreement, in which food distributor released former shareholders from any and all claims in connection with grocery store corporation, clearly and unambiguously applied only to claims that accrued prior to its execution; (2) alleged wrongful conduct of shareholders in withholding insurance premium refund did not transpire until after execution of release agreement, and thus was not subject to release; and (3) insurance company's status as wholly-owned...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Docudata Records Management Services, Inc. v. Wieser
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Parent company and its subsidiary maintain their independence even though same persons are directors or managers of both corporations or even though most or all capital stock of subsidiary corporation is owned by its parent corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Neither transfer of corporation's stock to new holding company nor merger of wholly-owned subsidiary into corporation constituted sale of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Docudata Records Management Services, Inc. v. Wieser
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Regardless of stock ownership or interlocking directorship, courts will not ignore separate legal identities of corporations, unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violation of anti-trust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Neither transfer of corporation's stock to new holding company nor merger of wholly-owned subsidiary into corporation constituted sale of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Today's Child Learning Center Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Critical factors in making determination as to alter ego status of successor corporation include who has active or substantial control as well as similarities that exist between two businesses; courts should consider whether old and new corporations share substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers and supervision, as well as ownership.
Document Preview: Corporation brought wrongful levy action against government. Following bench trial, the District Court, Newcomer, J., held that: (1) corporation was mere continuation or successor in interest of corporate taxpayer, and, thereby liable for taxpayer's federal employment taxes, and (2) corporation was alter ego of taxpayer. Judgment entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Olympic Financial Ltd. v. Consumer Credit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the factors to consider in determining whether two or more corporations have been operated as a single business enterprise include whether the corporations had: (1) common employees; (2) common record keeping; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) a common business name; (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another; (7) undocumented transfers between corporations; (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between the corporations; (9) the same officers; (10) the same shareholders; and (11) the same telephone number.
Document Preview: Finance company sued automobile seller for breach of consignment contract under which seller sold repossessed automobiles, and also against other dealers with which finance company had master dealership agreements. On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Atlas, J., held that: (1) seller and other dealers were not operated as single business entity; (2) there was no actual fraud by seller; and (3) there was no fiduciary duty on part of seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Regency Holdings (Cayman), Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation's ownership of all shares of subsidiary does not make subsidiary's assets those of parent.
Document Preview: Avoidance. Chapter 11 debtor's corporate control over subsidiary and over subsidiary's subsidiary did not permit it to recover, for benefit of its own creditors, preferential or fraudulent transfers of subsidiaries' assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: F.D.I.C. v. Refco Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, factors that courts apply in deciding whether to disregard the separate nature of corporation and corporate subsidiary, not all of which must be present for corporate veil to be pierced, are: (1) whether parent corporation owns all or a majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) whether parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent finances subsidiary; (4) whether parent subscribes to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) whether subsidiary' is referred to as such in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers; (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary fail to act independently in interests of subsidiary; and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are disregarded.
Document Preview: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), in its capacity as bank's receiver, brought suit against securities broker and its related corporate entities, seeking to hold them liable for broker's alleged role in Ponzi scheme perpetrated upon bank by its investment advisor/manager.  On cross-motions for summary judgment or partial summary judgment, to bifurcate alter ego claims, to impose Rule 11 sanctions, and to authorize calling of fact witness, the District Court, Kane, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) material fact questions precluded entry of summary judgment on proximate cause and damages issues, on securities fraud and racketeering claims, and on false representation and other common law claims; (2) prior determination, in lawsuit to impose constructive trust on funds which investment advisor/manager had caused to be transferred to customer from its securities brokerage account, that investment advisor was agent authorized to transfer funds and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, in deciding whether to penetrate corporate form, court will consider: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) nonpayment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Suppliers brought action against, inter alia, vice president of corporation that owed them money and company that was erroneously represented as the imminent purchaser of the corporation, alleging breach of contract and fraud. Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ponsor, J., adopted the opinion of Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) company was not liable for corporation's debts; (2) statute of frauds barred suppliers' breach of contract claim against company; (3) suppliers did not confer measurable benefit on company, as required for quantum meruit claim; (4) fact questions precluded summary judgment on misrepresentation claims against vice president of corporation and company; (5) vice president of corporation was not agent of company; (6) fact questions precluded summary judgment on estoppel claims against company; and (7) fact questions precluded summary judgment on unfair and deceptive trade practices claims against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Abdel-Fattah v. Pepsico, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Courts will not disregard separate legal identities of corporations on basis of stock ownership or interlocking directorship.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Parent's 100% ownership of subsidiary's stock corporation did not make it liable for subsidiary's alleged negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Jeanneton v. Hilton Intern.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico's "single entity" or "common control" doctrine, parent corporation and its subsidiary will only be regarded as one for purposes of finding the former liable if it is determined that: (1) their operations are significantly interrelated; (2) there is common management; (3) there is joint control over labor relations; and (4) there is joint proprietorship or financial control.
Document Preview: Hotel employee brought action against hotel and its parent corporation alleging, inter alia, breach of employment contract.  On motion by hotel and parent corporation for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Casellas, J., held that parent corporation could not be held liable for hotel's alleged breach of employment contract. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Conner v. ContiCarriers and Terminals, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Ownership of 100% of stock and commonalty of officers and directors are not alone sufficient to establish "alter ego" relationship between two corporations.
Document Preview: CIVIL PROCEDURE - Jurisdiction. Barge operator did not have continuous and systematic contacts necessary to maintain general personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination under Colorado law of whether subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent includes evaluation of whether parent owns all or majority of subsidiary's capital stock, corporations have common directors or officers, parent finances subsidiary, parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, parent pays salaries, expenses, or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division in papers of parent or statements of officers, directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently but take direction from parent, and formal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: User of computer keyboard, who was Colorado resident, brought products liability action in federal district court in New York along with other plaintiffs against manufacturer of keyboard and manufacturer's parent corporation.  After action was severed and transferred, the United States District Court for the District of Colorado, Lewis T. Babcock, J., 900 F.Supp. 240, granted parent's motion for summary judgment and also granted manufacturer's motion to dismiss.  User appealed, and the Court of Appeals, Logan, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under New York choice of law principles, Colorado law applied to substantive claims and to issue of whether corporate veil could be pierced; (2) user could not pierce corporate veil and hold parent liable; (3) parent was not manufacturer for purposes of Colorado Products Liability Act; (4) New York borrowing statute requiring action to be timely both in New York and in state where action arose was applicable; and (5)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego analysis is very fact intensive and centers around several factors which involve whether the two enterprises share substantially identical management, business purposes, operations, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership; no one factor is determinative and, thus, alter ego status may be established where one or more of the elements is missing.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  Companies moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ashman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) companies lacked unlawful intent necessary to find first company alter ego of second company, for purposes of funds' claims against first company under alter ego theory; (2) material issue of fact as to whether second company under-reported hours worked and, therefore, owed contributions to funds precluded summary judgment for second company; and (3) evidence was insufficient to raise genuine issue of material fact as to first construction company's alter ego status...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: NEC Technologies, Inc. v. Nelson
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: To establish alter ego doctrine plaintiff must show that defendant disregarded separateness of legal entities by commingling on interchangeable or joint basis or by confusing otherwise separate properties, records, or control, or by showing that disregard of corporate entity made it mere instrumentality for transaction of other entity's own affairs and that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations no longer exist; evidence must be such that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Warranties. Warranty on television set excluding consequential damages was not procedurally or substantively unconscionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: National Soffit & Escutcheons, Inc. v. Superior Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Second corporation was not alter ego of first corporation, so as to allow piercing of corporate veil under Indiana law and enforcement against second corporation of judgment covering first corporation, even though both corporations were in same business and shared same president and vice president; there was no indication of undercapitalization of second corporation or failure to observe separate corporate formalities, directors and shareholders of second corporation had not been involved in wrongdoing leading to judgment in question, and second corporation's purchase of $700 of first corporation's tools at fair market value did not constitute sufficient commingling of assets.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against second corporation, to enforce state court judgment obtained against first corporation.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana, Robert L. Miller, Jr., J., granted summary judgment for second corporation and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Bauer, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) second corporation was not alter ego of first corporation, so as to allow for piercing of corporate veil, even though corporations had some officers in common and were in same line of business, and (2) second corporation was not successor of first corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Giuliano v. Nations Title, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts law did not permit the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts to pierce corporate veil of California parent corporation so that district court could assert jurisdiction over California parent corporation, even though there was intermingling of corporate officers and some evidence that parent corporation had considerable control over its subsidiary, where there was no adequate showing of "pervasive control" by officers of parent corporation and no evidence that parent corporation's participation produced fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against title insurance company and its California-based parent, alleging breach of contract, unfair and deceptive trade practices and conversion.  Parent moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Young, J., held that: (1) there was no basis for assertion of direct jurisdiction over parent, based on parent's doing business in Commonwealth, and (2) corporate veil would not be pierced, even though there were indications that officers of parent had exercised some control over subsidiary's activities. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Montclair Homes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors tending to show shareholder domination and control, of kind which may permit piercing of corporate veil under New York law, include absence of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; use of corporate funds for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlapping ownership, officers, directors and personnel; common office space, addresses and telephone numbers for corporate entities; and payment or guaranty of debts of corporation by owners or other related corporate entities.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporate veil would be pierced to hold corporate principal personally liable for Chapter 7 debtor's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc. Dealerships Relations Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Allegation that various related entities used consolidate financial statements and had interlocking directorates would be insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil in the absence of any suggestion that subsidiary was incorporated for fraudulent purpose, that it was not adequately capitalized, or that any factor would justify disregarding corporate entity on equitable grounds.
Document Preview: Automobile dealers brought antitrust, RICO, Dealer Day in Court Act (DDCA), and state law claims against competing dealers, distributor, manufacturer, and executives of the manufacturer and distributor.  Actions were consolidated. On motions to dismiss, the District Court, Motz, Chief Judge, held that: (1) dealers who alleged that competing dealers paid bribes to executives of manufacturer and distributor to receive increased allocation of automobiles stated claim against distributor under RICO; (2) manufacturer could be held liable on the basis of actions taken by executives who were executives of both the distributor and the manufacturer; (3) RICO claim against competing dealer was stated on the basis of participation in enterprise but not on the basis of investment in or participation in activities of enterprise; (4) claim was stated against attorneys based on alleged participation in enterprise; (5) allegations did not establish...

Title: Salazar v. Coastal Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego is often established by evidence showing a blending of identities, or a blurring of lines of distinction between corporations, and important factors in making a determination of alter ego include the identity of shareholders, directors, officers, and employees, or failure to distinguish in ordinary business between different entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Texas choice of law provision applicable despite performance in Ecuador.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gundle Lining Const. Corp. v. Adams County Asphalt, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary is alter ego of parent, under Texas law, court considers whether: parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership, parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers, parent and subsidiary have common business departments, parent and subsidiary file consolidated and financial statements and tax returns, parent finances subsidiary, parent caused incorporation of subsidiary, subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital, parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary, subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent, parent uses subsidiary's property as its own, and daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate.
Document Preview: Texas subcontractor brought suit against contractor's surety in state court, seeking to recover on payment bond.  Suit was removed to federal district court where surety filed third-party complaints against Pennsylvania contractor, affiliated corporation and owner of the two corporations, claiming that it was entitled to recover all amounts paid to plaintiff from third-party defendants as indemnitors.  Following settlement between subcontractor and surety, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Lynn N. Hughes, J., granted summary judgment to surety, and third-party defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Robert M. Parker, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court had jurisdiction over contractor; (2) jurisdiction was lacking as to other third-party defendants; (3) district court properly denied contractor's motion to transfer venue; and (4) surety paid subcontractor's claim against payment bond in...

Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, factors which trial court considers in deciding whether to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary include: whether parent owns most of capital stock of subsidiary; whether parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers; whether parent finances subsidiary; whether parents subscribed to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise caused its incorporation; whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; whether parent pays salaries and other expenses and losses of subsidiary; whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; whether subsidiary is described in papers of parent corporation or in statements of its officers as mere department or division of parent; whether parent uses property of subsidiary as its own; whether directors or executives of subsidiary act independently in interest of subsidiary or simply take their orders from parent; and whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary are observed.
Document Preview: Creditors of insurance agency which had filed for Chapter 7 relief brought adversary proceeding against corporate lender which had financed management's acquisition of stock of agency, seeking to hold corporate lender liable for agency's debts on corporate instrumentality theory.  Creditors also asserted claims against lender for its alleged conversion of insurance premiums which should have been paid to them, tortious interference with their contractual relations with insurance agency, and negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. On lender's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Battey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporate lender which financed borrower's acquisition of stock of insurance agency did not exercise such actual, participatory and total control over business of agency that it could he held liable for agency's debts to third party creditors on corporate instrumentality theory; (2) creditors failed to show that lender had converted...

Title: Holland v. High-Tech Collieries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Application of alter ego doctrine requires analysis of several factors, including common ownership, interrelation of operation, common management and centralized control of labor relations.
Document Preview: Trustees of 1992 Benefit Plan, which was established pursuant to National Coal Industry Retiree Health Benefit Act, sued mine operator and related corporations for unpaid premiums.  Operator and related corporations brought third-party complaint against mine owner, seeking to enforce contract which allegedly required owner to reimburse operator for retiree benefits.  Owner counterclaimed for monies advanced to operator to cover health care costs.  On motions for summary judgment by Plan and owner, the District Court, Keeley, J., held that: (1) Act did not violate due process clause; (2) Act did not violate takings clause; (3) beneficiaries of pension plan were properly assigned to operator; (4) operator, rather than owner, was employer of miners, for purposes of determining liability under Act; (5) related corporations were related persons jointly and severally liable to employees; (5) contract between...

Title: Kasprzak v. American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Merely showing blending of activities between corporate parent and subsidiary, such that they may have had some or all of same directors or officers, filed consolidated income tax returns, shared same corporate logo, conducted intercorporate business, or officed in same building, is not alone sufficient to make parent liable.
Document Preview: Insureds brought state-court action against life insurer and its corporate parent, alleging misrepresentation in sales of policies issued by insurer. Defendants removed. On insureds' motion to remand for lack of diversity, the District Court, Cobb, J., held that clear and convincing evidence showed that insureds fraudulently joined parent in effort to defeat diversity as jurisdictional basis for removal, and thus removal was proper, where there was no evidence to support disregarding corporate separateness of insurer and parent. So ordered.

Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Cotter
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether successor corporation is alter ego of its predecessor, courts consider several factors: whether they have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: Fund trustees filed action to examine books of alleged sole proprietorship operated by former president of dissolved corporate employer to assess appropriate multiemployer benefit plan contributions.  Defendants filed motion seeking relief from default judgment allowing funds to examine defendants' books.  The District Court, Bucklo, J., held that: (1) ten-year statute of limitations for breach of written contracts under Illinois law applied to action; (2) district court had jurisdiction over action; (3) bankruptcy court's rejection of claim for contribution brought by funds did not bar action on res judicata grounds; (4) corporate employer never adequately rejected collective bargaining agreement in bankruptcy proceeding; and (5) audit was authorized to determine whether former president of dissolved corporation could be liable for contributions that corporation owed to plans. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Thomas Berkeley Consulting Engineer, Inc. v. Zerman
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Mere fact of similar ownership and control does not in and of itself authorize piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether corporate veil should be pierced.

Title: Kilvert v. Tambrands Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere overlap in management does not reflect corporate dominance sufficient to infer parent corporation's direct control over all acts of its subsidiary, for purposes of parent corporation's liability for acts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Citizens of the United Kingdom brought product liability suit against Delaware corporation which had designed and tested tampons manufactured by English subsidiary and used by English decedent, who died from toxic shock syndrome (TSS).  On motion to dismiss on ground of forum non conveniens, the District Court, Sand, J., held that: (1) England rather than the United States had the stronger public interest in resolution of the matter; (2) private factors weighed in favor of dismissal, particularly in light of defendant's inability to implead the English manufacturer, over whom the Court lacked personal jurisdiction, and (3) plaintiffs did not make sufficient showing of financial hardship to warrant determination that England was inadequate alternative forum though experienced toxic-shock litigation attorney in England had refused to handle the matter under new conditional-fee system and despite plaintiffs' risk of having to assume defendant's legal expenses if...
