Title: Grease Monkey Intern., Inc. v. Godat
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: In the eyes of the law, two different corporations are two different persons, even if one corporation is sole shareholder of the other.
Document Preview: REAL ESTATE - Specific Performance. Sales contract was incomplete and therefore not subject to specific performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Powers v. Fox Television Stations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors relevant in determining whether subsidiary is merely "alter ego" of its parents include (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of corporations as if it were its own. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332(c)(1).
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit in state court, alleging that defendant corporation terminated his employment in violation of New York State human rights law and New York City Administrative Code, and defendant removed case to federal court based on diversity.  On plaintiff's motion to remand, the District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) defendant carried its initial burden of demonstrating that California was its principal place of business, and (2) plaintiff failed to prove that defendant was alter ego of its New York parent companies, and thus that New York should be defendant's imputed location for jurisdictional purposes. Motion to remand denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, whether parent corporation should be held liable for acts of its subsidiary based on alter ego doctrine, involves considering whether parent corporation owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers, parent corporation finances subsidiary, parent corporation subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation, in papers of parent corporation, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division, directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent corporation, formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Worker brought products liability action against corporation, and corporation's former subsidiary that manufactured computer keyboard, for injuries suffered from use of allegedly defective keyboard, corporation moved for summary judgment, and former subsidiary moved for dismissal.  The District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary; (2) corporation was not manufacturer of keyboard; and (3) worker's action against former subsidiary accrued when she knew she was injured and knew cause of her injury. Motions granted.

Title: Warner v. Hillcrest Medical Center
Court: Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Showing of common board of directors and unity of corporate purpose is insufficient to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Sanctions. Counsel was sanctioned for filing and maintaining claims as against certain medical malpractice defendants.

Title: U.S. v. Funds Held in Name or for Ben. of Wetterer
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated by individual or another corporation so as to warrant piercing of the corporate veil under New York law, trier of fact should consider the following factors: absence of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlap in ownership; common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated company; whether corporations deal with each other at arms length; whether allegedly dominated corporation is treated as independent profit center; payment of debts and guarantees by parent for benefit of subsidiary; and whether subsidiary uses property of parent as if it were its own, but many of these factors are inapplicable when issue is dominion by an individual rather than another corporation.
Document Preview: Guatemalan not-for-profit corporation objected to report and recommendation of United States Magistrate Judge Chrein striking, on ground that corporation was alter ego of individual who was fugitive as to indictments in United States, corporation's claim to certain bank accounts held in its name or in the name of the individual, allegedly for its use and benefit, which were seized by United States. The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) in the Second Circuit, district court can, in the exercise of its discretion and in the appropriate circumstances, apply the disentitlement doctrine in a civil forfeiture proceeding to the claim of a corporation alleged to be the alter ego of a fugitive; (2) under federal common law choice-of-law principles, New York and Texas were the jurisdictions whose laws and policies were implicated to the greatest extent; (3) under the laws of either New York or Texas, piercing the corporate veil was warranted on alter ego theory;...

Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union, AFL-CIO, CLC v. Alden Corrugated Container Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether a corporation may be held liable for actions of another corporation under Massachusetts law include common ownership; pervasive control; confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; thin capitalization; nonobservance of corporate formalities; absence of corporate records; no payment of dividends; insolvency at time of litigated transactions; siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; non-functioning of officers and directors; use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Unions brought action against employers alleging violation of Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) in connection with plant closing. The District Court, Robert B. Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) employer's layoff of 30 employees on one date and 24 additional employees within 90 days of first layoff was a mass layoff under WARN Act; (2) two corporations and a holding company were a single employer for purposes of WARN Act; and (3) District Court would not exercise its discretion to reduce amount of liability and penalty to be assessed against employers for failure to give notice of mass layoffs as required by WARN Act. Judgment in favor of plaintiffs.

Title: Walls by Walls v. Allen Cab Co., Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Corporation is ordinarily an entity, separate and apart from its stockholders, and mere ownership of part or majority of stock of one corporation by another along with officers serving in both corporations is not sufficient to establish domination and control.
Document Preview: Employee. Finding that worker was employee of bank was not erroneous.

Title: Walls by Walls v. Allen Cab Co., Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Subsidiaries may have some common directors so long as there are no common employees and there is no commonality of corporate existence.
Document Preview: Employee. Finding that worker was employee of bank was not erroneous.

Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary may be found to be alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, court considers, inter alia, whether: parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent and subsidiary have common business departments; parent and subsidiary file consulted financial statements and tax returns; parent finances subsidiary; parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; daily operations of two corporations are not kept separate; subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against sole shareholder of major supplier of breast implants.  Shareholder, which had never itself manufactured or distributed breast implants, moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pointer, Chief Judge, held that genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on corporate control and direct liability claims. Motion denied.

Title: Markham v. Fay
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, 12 factors which should be considered in deciding whether to penetrate corporate form are: common ownership; pervasive control; confused intermingling of business assets, or management; thin capitalization; nonobservance of corporate formalities; absence of corporate records; no payment of dividends; insolvency at time of litigated transaction; siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholder; nonfunctioning of officers and directors; use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholder; and use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy filed interpleader action with regard to proceeds from sale of nursing homes held in name of debtor and mortgaged by corporation and trusts, after United States asserted interest in proceeds as holder of judgment based upon responsible person liability against president of corporation and settlor of trusts for nursing homes' unpaid withholding taxes.  The District Court, Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) memorandum of decision on summary judgment was law of case as to timeliness of government's claims and as to which law applied; (2) under Massachusetts law, corporation and trusts were not alter egos of president of corporation and settlor of trust, for purposes of veil piercing; (3) Internal Revenue Service (IRS), as creditor of settlor of trusts, was entitled as matter of law to such portion of interpled fund as represented proceeds from sale of nursing homes, as assets of trusts; and (4) declaration...

Title: Simplicity Pattern Co., Inc. v. Miami Tru-Color Off-Set Service, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Sublessee was mere instrumentality and alter ego of related corporation, as the latter dominated the affairs of the former, which domination caused wrong to sublessor by stopping payment of rent and breaching lease; there was an absence of formalities and paraphernalia of corporate existence of sublessee, it was inadequately capitalized, there was an overlap in ownership, officer, directors and personnel, there were common addresses and telephone numbers, sublessee's debts were paid by related corporation and related corporation used sublessee's property.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Dissolved corporate sublessee was mere instrumentality and alter-ego of related corporation.

Title: Edward D. Gevers Heating & Air Conditioning Co. v. R. Webbe Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division One.
Headnote: Evidence of use of corporate identity to defraud creditor is transfer by debtor corporation of its property to second corporation when both are controlled by same person.
Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. Petition seeking to have sole officers, directors and shareholders of corporation held liable for debts of corporation sufficiently pleaded alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Desjardins v. Van Buren Community Hosp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Maine law requires something more than overlap in corporations' directors for adversary of one corporation to pierce veil and reach the other.
Document Preview: Discharged employee who had previously obtained judgment against hospital sought to hold hospital district liable thereon, on theory that hospital district was judicially estopped from claiming that it was separate entity from hospital or that sufficient basis existed for piercing corporate veil in order to hold hospital district liable for hospital's debt.  The United States District Court for the District of Maine, Morton A. Brody, J., denied employee's request to hold hospital district legally responsible for hospital's debt, and employee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Boudin, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) hospital district was not judicially estopped from claiming that it was separate entity from hospital, and (2) mere fact that trustees of hospital district automatically became directors of hospital, and that hospital district owned property and equipment used by hospital, did not provide sufficient basis for piercing corporate veil to hold hospital...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brown v. Automotive Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Among factors that court considers in deciding whether two affiliated corporations may be regarded as a "single business enterprise" are: whether corporations have identity or substantial identity of ownership; common directors or officers; whether corporations share unified administrative control; intercorporate financing; inadequate capitalization; whether one corporation has caused incorporation of another affiliated corporation; one corporation's payment of salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; one corporation's receipt of business only from other corporation; corporations' use of each other's property; noncompliance with corporate formalities; common employees; common offices; centralized accounting; undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and whether there has been excessive fragmentation of single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: Liquidation. Casualty insurer and insurance premium finance company were a single business enterprise, all of whose assets could be administered by liquidator of insurer.

Title: Banco Urquijo, S.A. v. Signet Bank/Maryland
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Sharing common director will not create fiduciary duty between two corporations.
Document Preview: Two Spanish banks sued three American banks and one Japanese bank, all of which were creditors of bankrupt shoe company, alleging unjust enrichment, fraudulent misrepresentation, fraudulent concealment, and negligent misrepresentation in violation of Maryland law based on claim that American bank misled Spanish banks as to creditworthiness of shoe company. Title: Branch on Behalf of Maine Nat. Bank v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Corporations are treated as separate legal entities and are not responsible for debts of other corporations, even though they share common shareholders or officers.
Document Preview: Takings. Cross-guarantee provisions of FIRREA, by holding bank liable for debts of sister bank, effected compensable taking.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Langone v. C. Walsh Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: To determine whether two or more business entities comprise single employer, such that they are jointly and severally liable for each other's debts, court applies four factors, no one of which is controlling, of interrelation of operations, common management, centralized control of labor relations, and common ownership; single employer status is marked by absence of arm's length relationship found among unintegrated companies.
Document Preview: Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) funds brought action against two moving companies for unpaid contributions.  On motions by funds and companies for summary judgment, the District Court, Zobel, J., held that: (1) collective bargaining agreement requiring one company to contribute to ERISA funds did not exonerate it of responsibility, under alter ego and single-employer theories, for contributions owed by second company; (2) one moving company was alter ego of the other; and (3) companies were single employers liable for each other's debts. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Langone v. C. Walsh Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Ultimate question in determining whether two or more business entities comprise single employer, such that they are jointly and severally liable for each others' debts, is whether there is joint control of critical matters at policy level.
Document Preview: Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) funds brought action against two moving companies for unpaid contributions.  On motions by funds and companies for summary judgment, the District Court, Zobel, J., held that: (1) collective bargaining agreement requiring one company to contribute to ERISA funds did not exonerate it of responsibility, under alter ego and single-employer theories, for contributions owed by second company; (2) one moving company was alter ego of the other; and (3) companies were single employers liable for each other's debts. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Deutsche Credit Corp. v. Case Power & Equipment Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department A.
Headnote: Mere fact that corporations have same officers does not make one liable for acts of other.
Document Preview: Credit company sued equipment company for conversion of excavator in which credit company had perfected security interest.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. CV 9030669, Marilyn A. Riddel, J., entered summary judgment for credit company and awarded damages.  Equipment company appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Voss, J., held that: (1) creation of security interest was not attributable to seller from which equipment company bought excavator, and thus equipment company took excavator subject to credit company's perfected security interest; (2) trial court was within its discretion in not allowing equipment company additional time to conduct discovery; but (3) credit company was not entitled to attorney fees on appeal. Affirmed.

Title: Select Creations, Inc. v. Paliafito America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Circumstances which may be considered when deciding whether alter ego liability exists under California law include: identical equitable ownership in two entities; identification of equitable owners with dominion and control of two entities; use of same office of business location; employment of same employees and attorneys; use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality, or conduit for single venture or business of individual or another corporation; concealment and misrepresentation of identity of responsible ownership, management, and financial interest; failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities; use of corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity; and use of corporation as subterfuge for illegal transactions.
Document Preview: Following evidentiary hearing in proceedings to collect judgment entered based upon violation of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) by toy industry, the District Court, Warren, J., held that, inter alia: (1) transferees of interests of judgment debtors were joined as parties, and (2) federal receiver was empowered to collect assets anywhere in United States. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hystro Products, Inc. v. MNP Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Stock control and existence of common officers and directors are generally prerequisites to piercing of the corporate veil under Illinois law, although these factors alone will not suffice.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate parent, seeking to hold parent responsible for payment for goods received by parent's subsidiary.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, J.P. Stadtmueller, J., entered judgment in favor of seller, and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Illinois law, parent's veil of limited liability would be pierced, and (2) seller was not precluded from piercing corporate veil on grounds of waiver or estoppel. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Jiffy Lube Intern., Inc. v. Jiffy Lube of Pennsylvania, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, fact that two corporations shared directors and officers alone is not evidence of alter-ego liability if corporate formalities continue to be observed.
Document Preview: Automobile lubricating service center franchisor brought action against franchisee, alleging trademark infringement and unfair competition. Franchisee counterclaimed and brought third-party action against second franchisee and motor oil company, alleging, inter alia, fraudulent inducement to enter into franchisor-franchisee relationship, intentional interference with contractual relationship, conspiracy, and racketeering.  Plaintiffs and third-party defendants moved for summary judgment on counterclaim and third-party complaint.  The District Court, Van Antwerpen, J., held that: (1) under Maryland law, franchisee's release of franchisor in asset transfer agreement covered all of franchisee's claims against franchisor and second franchisee; (2) under Pennsylvania law, franchisee failed to show that company was liable for actions of franchisor on alter-ego theory on franchisee's claims for breach of contract, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Global Credit Services, Inc. v. AMISUB (Saint Joseph Hosp.), Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Existence of interlocking directors is not, in and of itself, sufficient without direct evidence of specific manipulative conduct to warrant piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Company which contracted with hospital for collection of its overdue patient accounts brought action against individual and corporate defendants for breach of contract and for interference with company's business relationship with hospital.  The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Caporale, J., held that company failed to make prima facie case that corporate defendants engaged in joint operation of the hospital. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mitchell v. K.C. Stadium Concessions, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: As general rule, two separate corporations are to be regarded as distinct legal entities, even if stock of one is owned partly or wholly by other.
Document Preview: Fire Policy. Fact that lessee and lessor declined to rebuild following fire did not relieve insurer of its obligation to pay replacement costs to lessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Paglin v. Saztec Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Circumstances to consider under Missouri law in determining whether parent corporation "controls" subsidiary, for purposes of alter ego liability, are that parent owns all or most of subsidiary's capital stock; parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent finances subsidiary; parent subscribes to all of subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation; subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary; subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; in papers of parent or statements of its officers, subsidiary is described as department, division of parent, or its business or financial responsibility is referred to as parent's own; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take their orders from parent and the latter's interest; and formal legal requirements of subsidiary are not observed.
Document Preview: Acquired corporation and its former president brought action against acquiring corporation, its parent corporation which was also majority shareholder in acquiring corporation, and officers and directors alleging breach of asset purchase agreement and employment agreement, tortious interference with contract, and fraud.  Defendants moved for summary judgment and plaintiffs moved to amend complaint.  The District Court, Stevens, Chief Judge, held that: (1) rule governing voluntary dismissal of an action did not permit plaintiffs to voluntarily dismiss one of several claims; (2) plaintiffs were entitled to amend complaint to dismiss racial discrimination claims; (3) issues of material fact existed as to extent of parent corporation's control over its subsidiary and whether parent exercised control over subsidiary for unlawful purpose, precluding summary judgment on claim to impose alter ego liability; (4) genuine issues of material fact...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Rollins Leasing Corp. v. Director, Div. of Taxation
Court: Tax Court of New Jersey
Headnote: "Sister corporation" is defined as two corporations having common or substantially common ownership by same shareholders.
Document Preview: Corporate Business Tax. Corporate taxpayer borrowed directly from its parent and thus, taxpayer had to include loan in its net worth and could not deduct interest on loan to extent prohibited by Corporation Business Tax Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Determining whether parent corporation's control and domination requires court to disregard corporate form, under New York law on piercing corporate veil, requires examination of a number of factors involving interactions between parent and subsidiary, including absence of formalities, inadequate capitalization, overlap in ownership, officers and directors, common office space, whether corporations deal at arm's length and are treated as independent profit centers, and payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group.
Document Preview: Franchisee brought suit to compel parent corporation of franchisor to satisfy judgment obtained against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement, pursuant to arbitration.  Piercing the corporate veil was denied by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 802 F.Supp. 1006, and franchisee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that piercing of corporate veil was appropriate as franchisor had ceased to function as separate entity and its operations and assets had been absorbed into parent, and act constituting breach of franchise agreement was taken in the name of the parent. Reversed and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Slottow v. American Cas. Co. of Reading, Pennsylvania
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, corporate form may be disregarded when there is unity of interest and ownership between two corporations and inequitable result would follow if corporations were treated as separate entities.
Document Preview: Bank brought suit against insurer under officers' and directors' liability policy, after insurer refused to reimburse bank for amount it had paid to settle suit against itself and officer. Insurer counterclaimed, seeking declaration of lack of liability.  The United States District Court for the Central District of California, Manuel L. Real, Chief Judge, held for bank and imposed punitive damages, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Kozinski, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) insurer was obligated to reimburse bank for officer's share of liability; (2) bank's allocation of 96% of settlement to officer was not made in good faith; and (3) bank was not entitled to award of punitive damages. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Opinion at 1 F.3d 912 superseded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Newtowne, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, more than mere identity of shareholders between corporations is required for court to ignore their separate corporate identities.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. court could not ignore debtor's and sister corporation's separate corporate identities for purpose of deciding whether debtor received reasonably equivalent value for alleged fraudulent transfer in satisfaction of sister corporation's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Laborers' Pension Trust Fund Detroit and Vicinity v. Lange
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining if one company is alter ego of another company, question is whether two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: Unions brought action under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) to enforce arbitration award granted under collective bargaining agreement. Cross motions for summary judgment were made.  The District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) owner of corporate employer was collaterally estopped from denying personal liability; (2) separately formed corporation was alter ego of corporate employer; and (3) unions were entitled to attorney fees and costs incurred in ERISA enforcement action. Arbitration award enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, under Connecticut law using "identity test" plaintiff must demonstrate that there was such unity of interest and ownership that independence of corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary corporations did not have same identity, as needed to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut law, where subsidiary maintained separate business transactions, bank accounts, and records, parent and subsidiary were incorporated in different states and in different decades, each had its own directors and officers and maintained its own records, subsidiary's financing was not obviously inadequate, and subsidiary was not shown to have acted solely for interests of parent.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Ciprotti v. United Inns, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Fact that corporations share corporate officers and mailing address is insufficient basis for piercing corporate veil or for finding that one corporation is a shell.
Document Preview: Service of Process. Corporate defendant was not effectively served.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Graphics Communications Intern. Union, Local 121-C v. Southern Coupon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego status is found when two corporations have substantial identity of management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, and supervision, as well as ownership.
Document Preview: Labor union brought action against corporation and its purported predecessor, seeking to enforce arbitration award entered against predecessor.  On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Propst, J., held that: (1) Alabama's ten-day statute of limitations for appealing arbitration awards applied to arbitration of union member's grievance pursuant to collective bargaining agreement; (2) arbitration award was enforceable; but (3) fact issues remained as to whether corporation was alter ego of its alleged predecessor, precluding summary judgment. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Stephens v. American Home Assur. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Neither common directorships nor sharing of officers is sufficient to show failure to observe corporate formalities for purposes of piercing corporate veil under Kentucky law.
Document Preview: Actions were brought by liquidator of insolvent reinsurer seeking coverage from certain retrocessionaires and premiums from companies which had ceded insurance risks to reinsurer, and defendants in two of the actions impleaded reinsurer's parent corporation and certain officials of Kentucky Department of Insurance.  On various motions for determination of defenses, for summary judgment, to vacate or to reconsider, and to dismiss, the District Court, Martin, J., held that: (1) New York law applied to determining validity of retrocession agreements though reinsurer was Kentucky corporation and insolvency proceeding was in Kentucky; (2) defense of fraud and remedy of rescission for fraudulent inducement of retrocession contracts were not rendered unavailable as matter of New York law by mere fact of insolvency proceedings; (3) no basis was shown for piercing parent corporation's corporate veil; (4) partial summary judgment granted by state court...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pulte Home Corp., Inc. v. Ply Gem Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, common officers and directors in parent and subsidiary does not destroy separate identity of either corporation.
Document Preview: Builder brought action against manufacturers and sellers of allegedly defective plywood used in builder's homes.  On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Kovachevich, J., held that: (1) fact issues precluded summary judgment on builder's claim for punitive damages; (2) builder had standing to sue defendants for damages; (3) Florida law applied to builder's contract claim; (4) fact issues precluded summary judgment on builder's fraud claim; (5) builder was required to identify source of plywood to recover on strict products liability claim; (6) economic loss doctrine did not preclude builder from recovering on its tort claims; and (7) parent corporation could not be held vicariously liable for actions of subsidiary. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Union Pacific Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Although several corporations have the same stockholders or officers, or both, their several identities are not destroyed.
Document Preview: Parent corporation operated as management holding company for railroad sought refund of federal taxes paid pursuant to Railroad Retirement Tax Act, subject to offset for taxes under Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) and Federal Unemployment Tax Act.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment and government's motion for summary judgment or partial summary judgment, the Claims Court, Horn, J., held that corporation was not under common control with railroad and thus fell outside scope of term employer as defined in Railroad Retirement Tax Act. Plaintiff's motion granted; defendant's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. O'Neill
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Court of Appeals considers four factors in determining whether entities are alter egos of one another: centralized control of labor operations, common management, interrelation of operations, and common ownership and financial control; no factor is controlling and all need not be present.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of two of its orders entered in connection with meat plant's closing, reopening and subsequent permanent closing. The Court of Appeals, D.W. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) fraudulent concealment exception applied to toll running of limitations period applicable to unfair labor practice complaint until date unions received testimony of indicted company official that majority shareholder of original employer was heavily involved in new corporations operating plant and, thus, NLRB properly allowed reinstatement of previously dismissed charge; (2) NLRB's finding that corporations which took over operation of plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices, was supported by evidence; and (3) piercing of corporate veil so as to hold majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices was justified. Orders enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. Fire Ins. Co. v. Allied Towing Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may not be pierced solely because of an overlap of corporate officers and directors.
Document Preview: In an action arising out of collision involving a tug, a tow, and a Navy ship, owner of tow and its insurance company filed suit against owner of tug and United States.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Robert G. Doumar, J., found both tug and Navy ship at fault for collision and apportioned liability equally between owner of tug and United States, awarded damages, but declined to award prejudgment interest.  Appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Luttig, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) remand was required to enable district court to make more specific determinations for purposes of determining whether to rely on tow's insured value as measure of value, and (2) identity of officers and directors of tug owner and tow owner was not alone sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil, and, thus, denial of prejudgment interest was an abuse of discretion. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: United Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Progress Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: "Identity" rule applies primarily to prevent injustice in situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of existence of common owners, officers, directors or shareholders and because of lack of observance of corporate formalities between the two entities.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought suit to recover money owing for electrical work performed on construction project, as well as to set aside alleged fraudulent conveyance to wife of president of corporation that owned land.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Waterbury, Pellegrino, J., entered judgment in favor of subcontractor on suit against corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor on project, but refused to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on either president or his wife.  Subcontractor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Norcott, J., held that: (1) president's wife was bound, no less than other defendants, by admission in answer, and (2) corporate veil should have been pierced to hold president personally liable on debt. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock of subsidiary, interlocking directorates, common shareholders and similar names will not suffice, by themselves, to pierce corporate veil under Puerto Rico law; rather, factors such as inadequate financing, comingling of assets and control of day-to-day operation of subsidiary are considered crucial in removing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Korson v. Independence Mall I, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will not deprive several corporations of their distinct entities merely because those corporations have stockholders and officers in common.
Document Preview: Lessees brought breach of contract action against lessors.  The Twenty-Fourth Judicial District Court, Parish of Jefferson, M. Joseph Tiemann, J., dismissed one defendant, and lessees appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Elora C. Fink, J. pro tem., held that complaint did not state basis for disregarding corporate form or finding that corporate defendant was a lessor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gatecliff v. Great Republic Life Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona, In Banc.
Headnote: Under alter ego theory parent corporation's "substantially total control" may be proved by showing, among other things: stock ownership by parent; common officers or directors; financing of subsidiary by parent; payment of salaries and other expenses of subsidiary by parent; failure of subsidiary to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence; similarity of logo; and plaintiff's lack of knowledge of subsidiary's separate existence.
Document Preview: Insureds brought action against parent insurer for breach of contract and bad faith in connection with cancellation of group health policy.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. C555986, John Foreman, J., dismissed complaint, and insureds appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 154 Ariz. 502, 744 P.2d 29, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Superior Court, Stephen A. Gerst, J., entered summary judgment in favor of insurer.  Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals affirmed in memorandum decision.  Review was accepted. The Supreme Court, Cameron, J., held that questions of fact precluded summary judgment as to parent insurer's liability under alter ego theory, instrumentality theory, and direct liability theory. Decision of Court of Appeals vacated, decision of trial court reversed, and case remanded. Corcoran, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, fact that two corporations have been incorporated by same party and have same officers does not mean that corporations are interchangeable.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, No. C862033A, granted mortgage company leave to intervene and declaratory relief it sought.  SBA appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 888 F.2d 1344, vacated and remanded with directions.  On remand, the District Court, Richard C. Freeman, J., made supplemental findings of fact.  The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: That corporation president owned corporation through his ownership of corporation's parent and that he was sole director and controlled all corporation's business decisions were insufficient by themselves to allow finding that corporation was president's alter ego under Georgia law.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.
