Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: That corporation shared offices, stationary, and employees with its parent, which was owned by corporation's president, did not, by itself, compel conclusion that corporation and its president were one and the same under Georgia law.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, No. C862033A, granted mortgage company leave to intervene and declaratory relief it sought.  SBA appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 888 F.2d 1344, vacated and remanded with directions.  On remand, the District Court, Richard C. Freeman, J., made supplemental findings of fact.  The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Atlantic Tobacco Co. v. Honeycutt
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Corporate president's wife did not exercise requisite degree of control over activities of two corporations to justify piercing corporate veil with respect to her; wife believed that she was secretary of the two corporations but was not sure, and there was nothing to suggest that she exercise any control over the operations of the corporations' business as result of that capacity.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against individual owners of two corporations to recover debt allegedly owed.  The Superior Court, Nash County, Napolean Barefoot, J., directed verdict in favor of defendants, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Duncan, J., held that: (1) corporate president's wife did not exercise requisite degree of control over activities of two corporations to justify piercing corporate veil with respect to her, but (2) evidence was sufficient to raise jury question on issue of whether it was appropriate to disregard corporate entities with respect to president and sole shareholder. Affirmed in part; reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Tryit Enterprises
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Some of relevant similarities in determining whether multiple business entities should be treated as single business enterprise under Texas law are corporate office that pays bills for affiliates, each affiliate is charged with proportional share of main office expense, and situations in which principals have overlapping ownership among business entities, operate from same office, use same telephone number and post office box, have centralized accounting, and refer to all companies by single name. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 24.03 (1986).
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtors, which were a corporation and general and limited partnership holding franchises for television and appliance rental stores, filed complaint seeking to set aside allegedly fraudulent conveyances.  The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) debtors failed to show that there was in fact a creditor existing holding allowable unsecured claim, as required for debtors to have standing under Bankruptcy Code to succeed to alleged right of creditor to avoid transfer under Texas Fraudulent Conveyance Act; (2) debtor corporation and partnerships would be treated as single entity, for purpose of determining whether debtors did not receive fair consideration under the Act; and (3) debtors received fair consideration, and thus, loan transaction could not be avoided as fraudulent conveyance. Judgment for defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Phillips Petroleum Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, separate corporate existence will not be set aside merely on showing of common management or whole ownership, but only in interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, public wrong, or equitable considerations among members of corporation require it.
Document Preview: Shareholders brought action challenging target corporation's settlement with tender offeror.  The District Court, 697 F.Supp. 1344, granted summary judgment in favor of target corporation, its board of directors, and offeror, and shareholders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 881 F.2d 1236, affirmed in part, vacated in part and remanded.  On remand, the District Court, Murray M. Schwartz, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) material question of fact, regarding materiality of tender offeror's representation that it would not sell stock back to target corporation unless other shareholders were given opportunity to sell stock back on same terms, precluded entry of summary judgment for tender offeror on Rule 10b5 claims; (2) material question of fact, whether tender offeror's corporate parent had created tender offeror for purpose of participating in takeover attempt and whether parent had so dominated actions of tender offeror to reduce them...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Archem, Inc. v. Simo
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Identity of corporate officers is one consideration favoring piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Manufacturer sued salesman regarding independent distributorship agreement alleging misrepresentation, unjust enrichment, and breach of contract.  Salesman counterclaimed alleging breach of contract, abuse of process, and corrupt business influence.  The Bartholomew Circuit Court, Suzanne F. Trautman, J., entered judgment for salesman on his breach of contract and abuse of process claims.  Manufacturer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Robertson, J., held that: (1) financial documents of manufacturer's parent corporation were admissible in assessing punitive damages against manufacturer; (2) trial court erred in admitting video taped deposition of salesman's witness when manufacturer's attorney was unable to attend deposition; (3) award of punitive damages against manufacturer was not excessive; and (4) evidence supported salesman's breach of contract and abuse of process claims. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Blanton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, fact that companies were commonly owned and often act in concert toward similar goals did not rise to level of complete disregard of corporate entity which would allow corporate veil to be pierced on grounds of alter ego.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 debtors objected to claim of Arizona Department of Revenue for gross receipt taxes incurred by corporation owned by one debtor while corporation performed two family housing rehabilitation contracts at Air Force base in Arizona. The Bankruptcy Court, Larry E. Kelly, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Texas law applied to determine whether corporate veil should be pierced; (2) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate form was resorted to as means of invading existing legal obligation, was inapplicable; (3) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporation was mere alter ego of debtor, was inapplicable; and (4) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate entity of corporation and its related entities were used as means of perpetrating fraud, was inapplicable. Objection granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pebble Cove Homeowners' Ass'n, Inc. v. Fidelity New York FSB
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary, parent must exercise complete domination and control; stock control, interlocking directors and interlocking officers are in and of themselves insufficient to justify imposition of liability on parent, but control by parent of subsidiary's everyday operations will render parent liable for subsidiary's acts.
Document Preview: Breach of contract action was brought against, inter alia, wholly owned subsidiary's corporate parent.  The Supreme Court, Nassau County, DiNoto, J., granted summary judgment for parent, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary would not be pierced where complaint failed to adequately allege means by which parent controlled its wholly owned subsidiary, and documentation submitted in opposition to summary judgment motion was devoid of evidentiary facts to support allegations that parent totally controlled everyday operation of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Lowell Staats Min. Co., Inc. v. Pioneer Uravan, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Fact that sole shareholder of corporation and corporation shared some common officers and directors was insufficient to allow corporate veil piercing under Colorado law.
Document Preview: Independent mining contractor brought breach of contract action against corporate owner of mining property.  Property owner brought action against contractor to recover overpayments for ore deliveries under contract and contractor brought third-party claim against sole shareholder of property owner and against shareholder's subsidiary.  Actions were consolidated and removed to federal court.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, John L. Kane, Jr., J., granted directed verdict motions of sole shareholder and subsidiary on claims in third-party complaint, jury returned verdict against property owner on counterclaim and on breach of contract claim awarded damages.  The District Court, 645 F.Supp. 254, denied contractor's motion for prejudgment interest.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Brorby, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil of mining property owner could not be pierced to render sole...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: State of N.C. ex rel. Long v. Alexander & Alexander Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Raleigh Division. .
Headnote: Ownership by one corporation of stock in another is not sufficient legal basis, in and of itself, to disregard corporate entities, even where two corporations share directors and officers.
Document Preview: North Carolina Commissioner of Insurance, in his capacity as rehabilitator of insolvent insurance company, brought RICO action against various defendants whose unfair and deceptive acts had allegedly caused insurance company to become insolvent.  Defendants moved to dismiss, and plaintiff moved for leave to amend and to dismiss counterclaims.  The District Court, Terrence William Boyle, J., held that: (1) burden of preparing new defenses and conducting additional discovery that defendants would have to bear if plaintiff's motion for leave to amend complaint was granted did not constitute prejudice sufficient to warrant denial of leave to amend; (2) defendants' counterclaims against Commissioner solely in his capacity as rehabilitator of insolvent insurance company were not claims against state, for Eleventh Amendment or sovereign immunity purposes; and (3) corporate parent lacked standing to assert, as counterclaim to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Horowitz v. Schneider Nat., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of parent corporation, even though president of parent owned capital stock of subsidiary, parent handled subsidiary's revenues and paid subsidiary's expenses from them, parent caused subsidiary's incorporation through merger of other companies, and president of subsidiary reported to employee of parent; parent did not itself own stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary did not have common officers or directors, parent did not finance subsidiary with its funds, subsidiary did not have grossly inadequate capital, parent did not pay salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary with its funds, subsidiary did not do substantially all its business with parent, papers of parent did not refer to subsidiary as department or division, and subsidiary observed formal legal requirements of incorporation.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, joined by subsidiaries, moved for partial summary judgment in suit against them.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment as to parent corporation's liability under Wyoming law for negligence of subsidiary under theory of retained control, and (2) subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of parent. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 708 F.Supp. 1573.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Total Care Health Industries, Inc. v. Department of Social Services
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Fact that one person was shareholder, officer and director of two corporations does not by itself warrant disregarding separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Medical supply corporation brought Article 78 proceeding to review determination of Department of Social Services which withheld Medicaid payments to it to offset overpayments made to another defunct corporation which had been owned and operated by same shareholder operating petitioner.  The Supreme Court, Queens County, Kassoff, J., granted the petition and reversed the determination.  Department appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) there was no evidence to demonstrate that shareholder had used petitioner to transact personal business or as alter ego of now defunct corporation which would warrant piercing corporate veil, and (2) fact that one person was shareholder, officer and director in two corporations does not by itself warrant disregard of separate corporate entities. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pan Eastern Exploration Co. v. Hufo Oils
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, mere fact that corporations shared interlocking directorates and officers would not permit court to pierce corporate veil, on ground that corporations were mere "alter egos" of each other, where all of corporate formalities were maintained.
Document Preview: Natural gas company and its wholly owned subsidiary filed suit against oil producers and other defendants based on defendants' alleged conversion of natural gas belonging to plaintiffs.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, Chief Judge, entered judgment on jury verdict which rejected all of parties' claims, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) finding that managers of gas company and its wholly owned affiliate had consented to independent oil producer's alleged conversion of affiliate's gas, by signing agreement to purchase oil producer's casinghead gas even though they suspected that producer had obtained gas by high-level perforation of gas formations to which affiliate held rights, was sufficiently supported by evidence, and (2) consent continued, at very latest, until plaintiffs filed suit against producer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Western Washington Laborers-Employers Health & Sec. Trust Fund v. Harold Jordan Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's ownership of stock in sister corporations could not justify disregarding corporate entities for purposes of creditor suit unless fraud was being worked upon creditor.
Document Preview: Trust sought to recover judgment it had obtained against defunct corporation against its sister corporation on theories of fraudulent conveyance, corporate disregard, and successor corporation liability.  The Superior Court, Snohomish County, Robert C. Bibb, J., granted summary judgment in corporation's favor on fraudulent conveyance claim, and entered judgment in its favor on remaining claims after trial.  Trust appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webster, J., held that: (1) fraudulent conveyance claim was barred by limitations; (2) sister corporation and sole shareholder of both corporations were not liable to trusts on theory of corporate disregard; and (3) sister corporation had no liability on theory it was mere continuation of defunct judgment debtor corporation under successor corporation theories. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Western Washington Laborers-Employers Health & Sec. Trust Fund v. Harold Jordan Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: One corporation's grant of credit to another, without more, is not grounds for applying doctrine of corporate disregard, notwithstanding fact that one person dominates both corporations, as long as domination was exerted upon each as separate concern.
Document Preview: Trust sought to recover judgment it had obtained against defunct corporation against its sister corporation on theories of fraudulent conveyance, corporate disregard, and successor corporation liability.  The Superior Court, Snohomish County, Robert C. Bibb, J., granted summary judgment in corporation's favor on fraudulent conveyance claim, and entered judgment in its favor on remaining claims after trial.  Trust appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webster, J., held that: (1) fraudulent conveyance claim was barred by limitations; (2) sister corporation and sole shareholder of both corporations were not liable to trusts on theory of corporate disregard; and (3) sister corporation had no liability on theory it was mere continuation of defunct judgment debtor corporation under successor corporation theories. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hideca Petroleum Corp. v. Tampimex Oil Intern., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego may be established by evidence showing blend of identities, or blurring of lines of distinction, both formal and substantive, between two corporations or between an individual and a corporation, and in determining alter ego factors such as identity of shareholders, directors, officers, and employees, failure to distinguish an ordinary business between two entities, and failure to observe proper formalities, are important.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract arising out of aborted international crude oil transaction.  The 234th District Court, Harris County, Ruby Sondock, J., entered judgment for seller of crude oil and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Levy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic crude oil company was individually liable on contract because it was acting for undisclosed or partially disclosed principal, and substituted its own responsibility for, or pledged its own responsibility in addition to, that of its principal; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was alter ego of oil company operating in international markets; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was liable for damages for negligent misrepresentation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Environmental Tectonics Corp., Intern. v. W.S. Kirkpatrick & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In determining whether the subsidiary is instrumentality of parent corporation so that two should be treated as one, factors to be examined include ownership of subsidiary's stock, identity of officers and directors of corporations, financial arrangements of corporations, responsibility over day-to-day operations of subsidiary and payment of subsidiary's salaries and expenses.
Document Preview: Corporation engaged in manufacture and sale of aircraft equipment and facilities brought action against corporate competitors and individuals, seeking damages in connection with award of contract with government of Nigeria, which was allegedly procured in violation of antitrust and racketeering laws.  Defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Lechner, J., held that: (1) allegations that competitors engaged in mail and wire fraud and committed bribery were insufficient to establish pattern of racketeering activity, and (2) act of state doctrine precluded action. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McKinney v. Gannett Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Separate corporate status of parent corporation and its subsidiary will generally be recognized, even where parent corporation owns all shares in subsidiary and two enterprises share directors and officers.
Document Preview: Former owner of newspaper brought action against corporation which purchased newspaper after sale alleging breach of contract of employment, and seeking rescission of contract of sale.  The District Court entered judgment in favor of former owner, and allowed former owner to elect rescission 60 days after judgment became final, and all parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 694 F.2d 1240, dismissed appeals.  The United States District Court for the District of New Mexico, Santiago E. Campos, J., entered final judgment in favor of former owner, and all parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Chief Judge, held that: (1) dismissal of newspaper's counterclaim against former owner for breach of employment contract was proper; (2) newspaper organization breached employment contract by frustrating former owner's contractual powers of editorial control and right to hire and fire; and (3) district court did not abuse its...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Phoenix Canada Oil Co. Ltd. v. Texaco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Fact that officers and directors are common to boards of both parent and subsidiary does not by itself indicate agency relationship under Delaware law.
Document Preview: Canadian corporation brought action against international oil companies for breach of contract and unjust enrichment in connection with contract assigning two oil companies right to develop petroleum concession in Ecuador. The District Court, Roth, J., held that: (1) corporation could not recover under theory of unjust enrichment under Ecuadorian law for future production rights under assignment contract from oil companies who sold their interests to Ecuadorian government at net book value; (2) oil companies were required to pay royalties in accordance with official Ecuadorian government tax reference price in effect at time production was commenced, and not government royalty valuation in effect at time assignment contract was executed; and (3) Canadian corporation was entitled to prejudgment interest from date of service at legal rate of interest in effect in Ecuador during pendency of action. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Duff v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A subsidiary is an instrumentality of parent corporation if parent corporation holds all or most of capital stock of subsidiary, finances subsidiary, subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, and uses property of subsidiary as its own, both corporations share common directors or officers, and subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, has substantially no business except with parent corporation, is described as a department or division of parent, and has directors or executives who take their orders from parent corporation.
Document Preview: Employee of alleged instrumentality of railroad brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act to recover for injuries allegedly sustained during course of employment.  The Circuit Court, Jefferson County, C. W. Callaway, J., granted railroad's motion for summary judgment, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that question whether employer was an instrumentality of railroad so as to make injured individual an employee of railroad for purposes of Federal Employers Liability Act because railroad owned all of employer's stock and paid salaries of its workers and because employer did over 99 percent of its business with railroad and had a director who was an officer of railroad was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Sumner Realty Co. v. Willcott
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Findings that shareholders of first corporation owned all stock in second corporation, that some officers of first corporation were also officers of second corporation, and that second corporation rented office space from first corporation and used same warehouse for storage were insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil absent evidence that one corporation was dummy or sham for the other and that observance of separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Lessor of offset duplicator press filed complaint for unpaid rent and writ of replevin to recover press or judgment for purchase price of press, and attorney's fees.  Lessee counterclaimed for compensatory and punitive damages and attorney's fees.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, Clayton R. Williams, J., dismissed lessor's complaint and found for lessee on counterclaim, awarding him compensatory and punitive damages, and attorney's fees.  Lessor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Harrison, J., held that: (1) remand was required for application of Missouri law under lease's choice of law provision where counterclaim award was based exclusively on Illinois usury law, and (2) identity of shareholders and some corporate officers, as well as rental of office space and warehouse storage, were insufficient factors to justify piercing corporate veil. Reversed in part, and vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Sprouse v. North River Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Two corporations, which were controlled by substantially the same officers, nevertheless were to be treated as separate entities, where corporations were separate and had chosen to register separately in North Carolina.
Document Preview: Mortgagors, mortgagees, and trustee under deed of trust brought action to recover proceeds of fire policy, and insurer counterclaimed for indemnity from trustee on grounds that trustee failed to enforce foreclosure under power of sale.  The Superior Court, Buncombe County, Frank W. Snepp, J., entered summary judgment in favor of plaintiffs, dismissed counterclaim, and ordered insurer to pay trustee's attorney fees, and insurer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Eagles, J., held that: (1) mortgagors, who remained in possession but were removing their belongings after ten-day period following foreclosure sale had expired, had insurable interest in home, which was destroyed by fire; (2) original mortgagee, which reacquired debt from its assignee after fire loss, acquired assignee's right to fire proceeds; (3) trustee, who could not legally compel high bidder at foreclosure sale to perform, was not liable to insurer for his failure to compel high bidder...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re S I Acquisition, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Although no single circumstance or factor is generally conclusive on issue of separate existence between parent corporation and its subsidiaries or sister corporations, for purposes of piercing corporate veil, general checklist of circumstances and facts tending to show that one corporation exercised substantial or total domination over subsidiary or affiliate include payment of expenses by one for the other, common officers and/or directors, stock ownership by parent, and failure of subsidiary to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Debtor in possession filed motion to show cause of why creditor should not be held in contempt for serving interrogatories on debtor's nonbankruptcy codefendants, its parent corporation and principal, in state court action based on piercing the corporate veil theory. The Bankruptcy Court, R. Glen Ayers, Jr., J., held that creditor's action against debtor's parent corporation and principal of both corporations seeking to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory was not property of the bankruptcy estate and was not a claim assertable by debtor or trustee, so that automatic stay provision did not apply to prevent creditor bringing such action from filing and serving interrogatories upon nonbankruptcy codefendants of debtor in action to pierce corporate veil. Motion to show cause denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Wade v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Sole stockholder of corporations operated both firms in such a way that it was apparent that firms were nothing more than dummies used by him to conduct his own personal business, and could be disregarded as separate entities.
Document Preview: In proceeding for judgment requiring payment to judgment debtor of debt due to judgment debtor, appeal was taken from so much of judgment of the Supreme Court, Nassau County, Meade, J., as dismissed proceeding, and cross-appeal was taken from so much of judgment as required money deposited in escrow to remain so deposited pending outcome of action which would determine right to that money.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that successor of judgment debtor was responsible for debtor's liability. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: 3-D Elec. Co., Inc. v. Barnett Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Court will not disregard separate legal entities of corporations merely because one owned stock in other or because of interlocking directorships unless such relationship is being used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violation of antitrust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: Texas electrical contractor brought breach of contract action against Tennessee general contractor based on construction work done on motel in Colorado.  The Fourteenth Judicial District Court, Dallas County, John McClellan Marshall, J., sustained Tennessee general contractor's special appearance and dismissed suit for lack of jurisdiction, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Maloney, J., held that: (1) commonality of officers of two general contractors, evidence that they officed in same building, and showing that general contractors were related in some way was not enough to establish degree of control necessary for one general contractor's activities in Texas to be attributable to defendant general contractor; (2) mere fact that same individual owned stock in both general contractors was not enough to hold two corporations acted as one; and (3) defendant general contractor did not have minimum contacts needed to assert personal...

Title: 3-D Elec. Co., Inc. v. Barnett Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Ownership of 100% of stock and commonality of officers and directors are not alone sufficient to establish alter ego relationship between two corporations.
Document Preview: Texas electrical contractor brought breach of contract action against Tennessee general contractor based on construction work done on motel in Colorado. Title: 3-D Elec. Co., Inc. v. Barnett Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Commonality of officers, evidence that corporations officed in same building, and showing that corporations were related in some ways was not enough to establish alter ego relationship between corporations so as to attribute to one corporation activities of second corporation in Texas, where two corporations filed separate tax returns, kept separate books and records, did not subcontract work between them, and one was not subsidiary of other.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Municipal Bldg. Authority of Iron County v. Lowder
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: For one corporate entity to be alter ego of another, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation no longer exists and observance of corporate form must sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or cause inequitable result to follow.
Document Preview: County and its municipal building authority brought action against county officials, seeking declaratory relief and writ of mandamus to compel county officials to carry out their alleged duties in connection with county's plan for financing construction of new jail facility.  The District Court, Iron County, George E. Ballif, J., upheld actions of county, and the county officials appealed.  The Supreme Court, Zimmerman, J., held that: (1) debt of municipal housing authority for which county was not responsible was not subject to debt restrictions of Constitution; (2) county did not violate constitutional article providing that legislature shall not authorize any county to lend credit to any private individual or corporate enterprise; and (3) municipal building authority was not a special commission within purview of constitutional article denying legislature power to delegate to special commission power to perform municipal functions; and...

Title: Conan Properties, Inc. v. Mattel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Among factors court should consider in determining whether to "pierce the corporate veil" are whether parent corporation owns all or most of capital stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers, parent corporation finances subsidiary, parent corporation subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, parent corporation pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, and directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary, but take their orders from parent corporation in latter's interest.
Document Preview: In trademark infringement action plaintiff sought leave to file third amended complaint, and defendant sought leave to amend answer to filing counterclaim. The District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., held that: (1) defendant was entitled to join certain additional counterclaim defendants; (2) defendant sufficiently pled cause of action under Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act; and (3) plaintiff was entitled to file third amended complaint to state RICO cause of action. Ordered accordingly.

Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: One hundred percent ownership and identity of directors and officers are, even together, insufficient basis for applying alter ego theory to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be used in determining whether subsidiary is alter ego of its parent include whether parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership, common directors or officers, and common business departments; whether parent and subsidiary filed consolidated financial statements and tax returns; whether parent finances subsidiary; whether parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; whether subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; whether parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; whether subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; whether parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; whether daily operations of two are kept separate; and whether subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Oman Intern. Finance Ltd. v. Hoiyong Gems Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Mere fact that two corporations were owned and operated by same individual, without more, is not sufficient to justify disregard of corporate identities.
Document Preview: Lender brought action seeking to hold Rhode Island corporation liable as guarantor on debt subsequent to default by debtor that was owned by New York corporation.  The District Court, Selya, J., held that: (1) Rhode Island corporation did not guaranty debt; (2) Rhode Island corporation was not liable for debt as mere continuation or extension of New York corporation; and (3) fact that Rhode Island corporation and New York corporation were owned by same individual did not warrant disregard of separate corporate identities and imposition of liability on Rhode Island corporation for alleged debt of New York corporation. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Jenkins v. Judith Sans Internationale, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Two separate corporations, although both owned by same sole shareholder, are separate and distinct entities.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit for damages sustained as result of receiving certain cellulite treatments.  The Fulton Superior Court, Fryer, J., granted summary judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that: (1) absent evidence of abuse of corporate form, no issue as to piercing corporate veil was presented, and (2) defendant was not jointly and severally liable with corporation which owned and operated salon. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Jenkins v. Judith Sans Internationale, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Defendant corporation owned by same individual as corporation which operated beauty care salon in which plaintiff was allegedly injured was not jointly and severally liable, where, contrary to plaintiff's assertion, defendant did not train personnel working in salon and corporations' businesses were completely separate.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit for damages sustained as result of receiving certain cellulite treatments.  The Fulton Superior Court, Fryer, J., granted summary judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that: (1) absent evidence of abuse of corporate form, no issue as to piercing corporate veil was presented, and (2) defendant was not jointly and severally liable with corporation which owned and operated salon. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Vucci v. Meyers Bros. Parking System, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard corporate entities of corporations which are affiliated through common stock ownership, domination by one corporation of the other corporation's finances, policies, and practices should be considered, under the totality of circumstances.
Document Preview: Customer of parking lot brought action against several defendants for personal injuries sustained when guardrail in parking lot collapsed, allegedly due to improper repair of damage caused when insured motorist had collided with it. The Superior Court, Providence County, Almeida, J., entered final judgment for customer against insurer and parking lot owner, and insurer appealed.  The Supreme Court, Shea, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to carry case to the jury on issue of insurer's liability; (2) evidence about claims adjustor's employer's apparent authority to act on insurer's behalf was admissible; (3) allowing questions and requests that assumed corporate identity shared by insurer and claims adjustor's employer was not abuse of discretion; (4) admission of expert testimony on the issue of customer's future earning capacity was not error; (5) domination by one corporation of the other corporation's finances, policies...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: For purpose of disregarding corporate entity of affiliated corporations, affiliated corporation relationship existed between shareholder's wholly owned corporation and other corporation in which shareholder owned 50% of stock.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: For purpose of disregarding corporate entity of affiliated corporations, analysis of domination need not be narrowly limited to control over particular transaction attacked where affiliated corporation is without separate and distinct corporate identity and is operated as mere shell, created to perform function for dominant corporation or common shareholders.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Rule with regard to piercing corporate veil is broad enough to encompass both situations where there is direct stock ownership of subsidiary corporation by parent, and stock control exercised through mutual shareholder.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where there is evidence of common corporate ownership and actual working control as in case of affiliated corporations, taken together with other factors suggesting domination of finances, policy or business practice, including but not limited to undercapitalization, disregard of corporate formalities and insolvency, jury instruction on instrumentality rule as enunciated in case law is adequate.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Title: Parker v. Bell Asbestos Mines, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: As indicia of control of a subsidiary by the parent, courts tend to look to such matters as shared officers and directors and the extent of the parent's domination of the subsidiary's policies, practices, and finances, and no one factor is alone dispositive.
Document Preview: Certain defendants in asbestos litigation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Fullam, J., held that material fact issues existed precluding summary judgment on issue of whether movants, which had never themselves mined, sold or supplied asbestos or asbestos products, could be held liable for plaintiffs' or their decedents' exposure to asbestos in course of employment, precluding summary judgment. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Texas Oil & Gas Corp. v. Hagen
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary is wholly owned by parent and there is identity of management does not justify disregarding the corporate entity of the subsidiary, but where management and operations are assimilated to the extent that subsidiary is simply a name or a conduit through which parent conducts its business, corporate fiction may be disregarded in order to prevent fraud and injustice.
Document Preview: Royalty owners brought action against gas lessee, based on breach of contract, failure to market gas with good faith and reasonable diligence, and fraud by misrepresentation and concealment.  Judgment for royalty owners was rendered by the 276th District Court, Camp County, William R. Porter, J., and lessee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cornelius, C.J., held that: (1) lessee breached contract by virtue of sham sales transactions with its wholly owned subsidiary, used to deprive owners of their rightful royalties, and purported sale at the wells could therefore be disregarded and true sale taken as being off premises at plants of third parties; (2) data proffered by royalty owners was sufficient to allow the trial court to find market value of the gas, though remand was required to determine whether the market value exceeded the maximum price allowable by the Natural Gas Policy Act; (3) gas lessor's breach of confidential relationship with...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: North American Plastics, Inc. v. Inland Shoe Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether corporation constitutes an instrumentality of another are: (1) parent corporations owns all or a majority of the capital stock of the subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers; (3) parent corporation finances the subsidiary; (4) parent corporation subscribes to all the capital stock of the subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with the parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation; (8) a subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division in the papers of the parent corporation and in the statements of its officers; (9) directors or executives of the subsidiary do not act independently in the interests of the subsidiary but take direction from the parent corporation; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as a separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Upon defendant's motion to dismiss or for summary judgment in suit seeking to recover balance due from subsidiary on an open account, the District Court, Biggers, J., held that commonality of ownership and officers of parent and subsidiary corporations was not sufficient for application of the piercing doctrine for purposes of establishing long-arm jurisdiction against New York parent corporation. Motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Southern Elec. Supply Co. v. Raleigh County Nat. Bank.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Where both corporations controlled by single individual served separate purpose although businesses were related, neither corporation was undercapitalized, none of funds of either corporation were commingled, and neither corporation controlled the other, neither corporation was alter ego of other.
Document Preview: Corporation which saw its deposit transferred by bank and used as setoff for matured indebtedness of second corporation controlled by same individual brought action against bank for conversion of funds.  The Circuit Court, Raleigh County, Thomas Canterbury, J., entered judgment in favor of bank, and an appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, Harshbarger, J., held that bank had no explicit or implicit authority to transfer funds from corporation's account to second corporation's account and then set off those funds against second corporation's matured indebtedness. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Application of Crespo
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Except in exceptional circumstances, the law respects separate corporate identities, even where one corporation may wholly own another or share the same principals.
Document Preview: Proceeding, denoted by injured bus passenger as a motion to amend a notice of claim, ostensibly sought to change in the original notice of claim the designation of the corner at which passenger was allegedly injured. Proceeding...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Landry v. St. Charles Inn, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will not deprive several corporations of their distinct identities merely because those corporations have stockholders and officers in common.
Document Preview: Hotel guest brought action against innkeeper and owner of hotel parking lot in which she was assaulted and robbed.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Revius O. Ortique, J., awarded plaintiff $20,000, and defendants appealed.
