Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McKibben v. Mohawk Oil Co., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Where parent corporation owned all of subsidiary's stock, subsidiary's directors and officers were same as parent's, subsidiary was financed by parent, parent caused subsidiary's incorporation, subsidiary was undercapitalized, had no employees, was passive corporation, did not have letterhead and parent used subsidiary's property as its own, subsidiary was parent's mere instrumentality, and thus subsidiary's corporate veil was properly pierced.
Document Preview: In action by mining claim owners against mining lease assignee and joint venture-subsidiary, the Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, Christopher R. Cooke, J., entered judgment for defendants, and owners appealed.  The Supreme Court, Burke, C.J., held that: (1) defendants' acceptance was untimely, and thus correspondence between parties' attorneys did not result in accord and satisfaction; (2) owners had alleged action for waste; (3) Supreme Court adopted view of Restatement (Second) of Torts that owners' future possessory interest in ore at time of defendants' alleged conversion was sufficient for owners to maintain action for conversion; (4) owners' claims of intentional dilution of ore and unworkmanlike mining were timely under applicable statute of limitations; (5) subsidiary's corporate veil was properly pierced; (6) owners' interrogatory, which required defendants to state legal theory along with citations to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Audit Services, Inc. v. Harvey Bros. Const.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: For entities to be alter egos, there must be centralized control of labor relations, common management, interrelation of operations and common ownership and financial control, but all factors need not be present.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the District Court of the Fifth Judicial District, Beaverhead County, Frank Blair, J., which declared compliance agreements entered into between unions and an employer void.  The Supreme Court, Gulbrandson, J., held that: (1) the evidence established that the employer ratified the compliance agreements; (2) letters sent by the employer to the unions withdrawing from the agreements were evidence that the employer intended to be bound, under the terms of the agreements, until the agreements expired; and (3) noncompliance with the terms of the compliance agreements was not sufficient to establish repudiation. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Moffett v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in showing that management and operations of subsidiary and parent corporation are so assimilated that subsidiary is simply conduit through which parent conducts its business include whether the two file consolidated income tax returns; whether operating capital is financed by parent or borrowed from other sources; extent to which separate books and accounts are kept; whether they both have common departments of businesses; whether they have separate meetings of shareholders and directors; whether an officer or director of one corporation is permitted to determine policies of the other; and whether there are any other facts which also indicate that subsidiary is a mere conduit.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against tire company for damages sustained when pickup truck overturned, allegedly from failure of right rear tire.  The 261st District Court, Travis County, Pete Lowry, J., entered judgment in favor of defendant company, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Brady, J., held that: (1) where plaintiffs' objections to jury charge were based on refusal of trial judge to submit plaintiffs' requested special issues to jury, objections did not preserve error based on such refusal since failure, to submit requests separately from objections to trial court's charge resulted in requests being waived; (2) where there was no endorsement of Refused by the trial court of any of three requested special issues, none were signed officially by trial judge, and there was no formal bill of exceptions in the record, error based on trial court's refusal to submit special issues was not preserved; and (3)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: D.L. Auld Co. v. Park Electrochemical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Ownership of all of subsidiary's stock, by itself, is insufficient reason to disregard distinct corporate entities, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against parent corporation and subsidiary. The District Court, Glasser, J., held that: (1) facts were insufficient to warrant disregarding corporate entity of subsidiary, and (2) genuine issue of material fact existed with respect to whether parent corporation, primarily through its president, played such a major role in business discussions with plaintiff in attempting to resolve patent dispute that it became an actor directly in transaction and was therefore jointly liable with subsidiary, precluding summary judgment. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Williams Plaza, Inc. v. Sedgefield Sportswear Div. of Blue Bell, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Facts that corporations had common ownership and that one was a wholly owned subsidiary of the other were not alone sufficient to allow a jury to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Unsecured creditor of subsidiary corporation brought action to reach the assets of the parent corporation to satisfy the subsidiary's debt on its account with the creditor.  The State Court, Houston County, Paul C. Armitage, J., entered judgment in favor of the creditor, and the parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Shulman, P.J., held that, evidence that corporations had common ownership, that one was a subsidiary of the other, that acquisition of the subsidiary corporation may have been in the interest of the parent corporation, and that the two corporations had a joint obligation on a bank note was insufficient to raise a jury question as to whether the corporate veil should be pierced to hold the parent corporation liable for the unsecured debt of the subsidiary corporation, absent proof that funds of the subsidiary corporation were misappropriated or misused. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Angelo Tomasso, Inc. v. Armor Const. & Paving, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Identity rule for piercing corporate veil primarily applies to prevent injustice in the situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of existence of common owners, officers, directors or shareholders and because of the lack of observance of corporate formalities between the two entities.
Document Preview: Suits were brought against guarantors of corporate accounts, and guarantors impleaded a third-party defendant alleging that the corporation was in reality a sole proprietorship owned, controlled and operated by the third-party defendant and was the alter ego of third-party defendant.  The actions were brought in the Superior Court in the Judicial District of Hartford-New Britain at Hartford and referred to Charles S. House, State Referee, who granted third-party defendant's motion for judgment of dismissal, and guarantors appealed. The Supreme Court, Arthur H. Healey, J., held that: (1) fact that individual is not stockholder, officer or director of corporation would not prevent court from imposing liability on individual by piercing the corporation veil if the evidence demonstrated the requisite level of control and otherwise satisfied the instrumentality or other applicable test; (2) in the instant case, although there was evidence that third-party...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Schmid v. Roehm GmbH
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Fact that two corporations may have stockholders or officers in common or that one is parent of other, or that parent selects from its own directors and officers, the majority of directors of other, or that parent finances subsidiary, is, without more, insufficient to warrant treating two corporations as one.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover damages for injuries sustained allegedly as a result of defective safety devices on gun. Plaintiff moved to strike defenses of defendants, one defendant moved for summary judgment and another defendant moved to dismiss and plaintiff cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, O'Connor, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporation was not liable to plaintiff as corporation was not in chain of distribution and was, in fact, not in existence at time gun was manufactured and imported into United States and was not alter ego of manufacturer, and (2) where plaintiff failed to serve process on defendant within 90 days as provided by Kansas law, action was barred by two-year statute of limitations. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: International City Bank and Trust Co. v. Morgan Walton Properties, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are treated as separate legal entities notwithstanding fact that they have common shareholders and officers, or that one corporation owns stock in the other.
Document Preview: Makers appealed from judgments entered by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida, Winston E. Arnow, Chief Judge, in mortgage foreclosure proceedings. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) notes payable on demand or two years after date were payable on demand and, in absence of demand, two years after execution; (2) formal demand was not necessary prior to commencing suit; (3) evidence was sufficient to support determination that there was no issue of material fact regarding existence of seven-year joint venture or financing contract; and (4) denial of makers' motion for new trial, which was premised upon allegedly prejudicial statements made by bank's counsel in closing argument, was not abuse of discretion. Affirmed. See also 612 F.2d 227;404 So.2d 1059.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: New Sheridan Hotel & Bar, Ltd. v. Commercial Leasing Corp., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: Before one corporation may be held liable for acts of another corporation, there must be such a close relationship between the two companies that one is, in essence, an instrumentality of the other; factors which enter into this determination include, inter alia, stock ownership of one corporation by the other, management decisions by one corporation for the other, and amount of business which one company has apart from its business with the other.
Document Preview: Lessee of telephone system brought action against lessor to rescind the lease agreement, and lessor counterclaimed to accelerate payments required under the lease and to recover attorney fees. The District Court, San Miguel County, Jerry Lincoln, J., entered judgment for lessor on both the complaint and counterclaim, and lessee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coyte, J., held that: (1) lessor was not responsible for any representations or warranties made by installer, from whom it had purchased the system, to lessee; (2) trial court did not err in accelerating payments due under terms of lease when lessee failed to make required payments; and (3) since no objection was timely made, lessee had no basis to complain as to amount of attorney fees awarded to lessor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Chicken Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: "Shared" officers and directors raise a strong inference of domination of subsidiary by its parent and indicate "common direction and supervision."
Document Preview: Subsidiaries of a defendant in chicken antitrust litigation filed a motion for clarification, asking the court to rule that they were entitled to recover as members of settlement classes, and asking the court to rule that they had opted out of the class settlement in the event court found them not entitled to class membership because of affiliation with or ownership by their parent.  The District Court, O'Kelley, J., held that three subsidiaries of a defendant were not entitled to participate in the settlement fund, since they were not sufficiently independent of their parent to warrant participation; they shared officers and directors, raising a strong inference of parental domination, and they were completely owned by their parent. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Kwick Set Components, Inc. v. Davidson Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere fact that some or all of stockholders or officials of two corporations are identical or because one corporation dominates the other does not, of itself, destroy corporate identity or merge one into other, but such factor, combined with apparent scheme of dominant corporation to avoid payment of subservient corporation's debts while benefiting from use of goods causing such debt, indicates lack of separate corporate purpose or existence on part of subservient corporation.
Document Preview: Company brought action against allegedly subservient corporation doing business as allegedly dominant corporation and against such corporations' president for failure to pay debt on open account. The Circuit Court, Russell County, Paul Jack Miller, Jr., J., dismissed corporate president as party defendant and entered judgment against corporations, and dominant corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Beatty, J., held that: (1) in view of evidence that both allegedly dominant and subservient corporations had same president and board of directors and that dominant corporation purchased goods through name of defunct subservient corporation and used such goods to perform contracts, combined with apparent scheme of dominant corporation to avoid payment of subservient corporation's debts while benefiting from use of goods causing debt, evidence permitted finding that subservient corporation had become mere instrumentality of dominant corporation and that justice required court to look...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Russell v. Birmingham Oxygen Service, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Even though single individual wholly owned both corporations and it was him with whom defendants dealt, it did make a difference whether parent corporation or its wholly owned subsidiary enforced noncompetition agreement with defendants, in that parent corporation, which entered agreement with defendants, must enforce its own rights and privileges. Const. § 240; Code 1975, § 10–2A–20(2).
Document Preview: Suit was brought in which plaintiffs sought damages for breach of contract and injunctive relief. The Circuit Court, Madison County, Thomas N. Younger, J., granted injunction restraining defendants from engaging in respiratory therapy care business or competing with plaintiffs for seven years, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Torbert, C. J., held that: (1) where parent corporation was not engaged in respiratory care business, plaintiffs could not be in competition with it and thus they did not violate contract not to compete; (2) where it was apparent from face of contract that wholly owned subsidiary was not a third-party beneficiary, it had no standing to enforce contract in court; and (3) where there was no act or statement by parent corporation, which did not engage in respiratory care business, evidencing intention to assign noncompete agreement to its wholly owned subsidiary, which did engage in such business, there was no assignment of agreement and thus...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Application of Sbarro Holding, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Stock ownership in several corporations by same person is not basis for ignoring separate entities.
Document Preview: Holding company brought proceeding to stay arbitration on ground that the only agreement which provided for arbitration was between franchisees and franchisor, a subsidiary of plaintiff. The Supreme Court, Arthur S. Hirsch, J., held that: (1) contract requiring arbitration of disputes between subsidiary and its franchisees applied to parent, where parent controlled business which had grown out of family business, family members were still active real principals, and funds were transferred from one entity to another, and (2) showing of fraud was not necessary to require parent corporation to submit to arbitration, although it had not signed arbitration executed by subsidiary. Application to stay arbitration denied and application of franchisees for order joining other related corporations granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Pearl-Wick Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Stock control, interlocking directors and officers, and the like are in and of themselves insufficient for the court to disregard the individuality of parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: Debtor commenced adversary proceeding against, among others, sellers and prior owners of its corporate parent to recover the proceeds of a policy on the life of one of its directors and officers. On cross motions for summary judgment, the Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, J., held that provision of agreement, in which corporation acquiring all the outstanding common stock of debtor's corporate parent agreed to maintain in force and effect a policy on the life of a director and officer of the debtor payable to the debtor's corporate parent to secure any unpaid balance owed the owners and sellers of debtor's corporate parent, did not constitute an assignment of the policy, which was solely owned by the debtor; thus, the policy was the property of debtor's estate and debtor, the designated beneficiary, was entitled to the proceeds therefrom as debtor in possession. Summary judgment for debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Main Bank of Chicago v. Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: Use of common officers and directors does not, of itself, render one corporation liable for obligations of another.
Document Preview: Corporate obligee sued obligors on a note and obligors counterclaimed against a subsidiary of the obligee and against the obligee itself seeking recovery on the lease with the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Walter J. Kowalski, J., rendered judgments on directed verdicts for the obligee and obligors appealed. The Appellate Court, 88 Ill.App.3d 28, 43 Ill.Dec. 681, 410 N.E.2d 681, affirmed in part and reversed in part. Obligors appealed. The Supreme Court, Underwood, J., held that: (1) parol evidence was inadmissible to establish an oral agreement to make payment on the note contingent on the subsidiary's obligations under the lease; (2) the corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold obligee liable on the lease; (3) a jury question existed as to the amount due under the lease; and (4) the obligee was entitled to recover from obligors the portion of the attorney fees attributable to recovering on the note itself, but not that portion attributable to the balance...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Southern States Co-op., Inc. v. Dailey
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not a sufficient justification for a court to disregard the separate corporate structure, nor is mutuality of interest, without the countermingling of funds or property interest, or prejudice to creditors, sufficient.
Document Preview: Tax commissioner appealed from the Circuit Court, Kanawha County, Thomas E. McHugh, J., which reversed in part an administrative decision of the State Tax Commissioner, in which assessment of business and occupation tax against agricultural cooperative association was affirmed in part. The Supreme Court of Appeals, McGraw, J., held that: (1) agricultural cooperative association and its affiliated cooperatives were each persons within meaning of definitional section of chapter governing business and occupation tax, and as such gross receipts from transfers between them were subject to business and occupation tax, and (2) transfer of goods from agricultural cooperative association to its local associated cooperatives was an activity engaged in or caused to be engaged in with the object of gain or economic benefit, either direct or indirect, within meaning of business and occupation tax. Reversed in part and remanded.

Title: General Const. Co. v. Tyonek Timber, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Subsidiary would not be treated as same entity as its parent, although 50% of subsidiary's stock was owned by parent and parent financed subsidiary's acquisition of equipment, some of which was used to haul material involved in subsidiary's action, where remainder of stock was owned by two directors who were not officers, directors or employees of parent and there was no showing that subsidiary had grossly inadequate capital, that parent had paid salaries, expenses or losses of subsidiary, that subsidiary was held out as division of parent, that president of subsidiary took orders from parent, or that formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate corporation were not observed.
Document Preview: Subsidiary of corporation which had engaged contractor to build dock sued contractor to recover for material it had moved to dock area. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Ketchikan, Thomas E. Schulz, J., entered judgment for subsidiary and contractor appealed. The Supreme Court, Matthews, J., held that subsidiary would not be treated as same entity as its parent, although 50% of subsidiary's stock was owned by parent and parent financed subsidiary's acquisition of equipment, some of which was used to haul material involved in subsidiary's action, where remainder of stock was owned by two directors who were not officers, directors or employees of parent and there was no showing that subsidiary had grossly inadequate capital, that parent had paid salaries, expenses or losses of subsidiary, that subsidiary was held out as division of parent, that president of subsidiary took orders from parent, or that formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate corporation were...

Title: In re Washington Medical Center, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Where debtor's subsidiary was incorporated and maintained as separate corporate entity, had its own board of directors and officers, maintained separate books and records, functions were distinct and separate from those of its parent and separate identity was clear to public at large, subsidiary was not mere instrumentality and thus alter ego of debtor notwithstanding that there were instances of some intervention by debtor in affairs of subsidiary. Bankr.Act, §§ 1-72, 301 et seq., 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 1-112, 701 et seq.
Document Preview: Parent debtor timely objected to claim of subscription health service on ground that liability for amount claimed was solely liability of wholly-owned subsidiary. The Bankruptcy Court, Roger M. Whelan, J., held that: (1) evidence did not justify conclusion that subsidiary was mere instrumentality and thus alter ego of debtor corporation; (2) there was no clear indication or inference that parent intended to expressly contract with subscription health service, separate and apart from its subsidiary, nor was there any probative evidence that indicated that subscription health service intended that separate contract with parent on matter of service's overpayments to subsidiary for services rendered to its subscribers was to be entered into; and (3) debtor was equitably estopped to deny assumption of contract of subscription health service and subsidiary for repayment of subsidiary's debts to service as result of overpayments by service for medical services subsidiary rendered to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Soanes v. Baltimore & O. R. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, facts that there were interlocking directorates and executive officers between subsidiary and parent railroad corporation, that both accepted service at the same address, and that train master of subsidiary used business cards naming parent but not subsidiary did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, particularly in light of fact that subsidiary had its own employees, separate labor agreements, its own tax status, and several corporate directors who were unaffiliated with parent.
Document Preview: In personal injury action arising when child was struck by train, plaintiff moved to strike affirmative defense of failure to join indispensable party. The District Court, Bramwell, J., held that: (1) under New York law, facts that were interlocking directorates and executive officers between subsidiary and parent railroad corporation, that both accepted service at the same address, and that train master of subsidiary used business cards naming parent but not subsidiary did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, particularly in light of fact that subsidiary had its own employees, separate labor agreements, its own tax status, and several corporate directors who were unaffiliated with parent, and (2) thus, since judgment rendered without presence of subsidiary would be inadequate, subsidiary was an indispensable party, and it was necessary that action be dismissed where subsidiary could not be joined without destroying diversity jurisdiction. Motion to strike denied; and dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Northern Illinois Gas Co. v. Total Energy Leasing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Generally, stock control and common officers and directors are prerequisites to piercing corporate veil, but such factors alone are not sufficient.
Document Preview: Utility which had furnished natural gas to subsidiary sued parent corporation seeking to pierce the corporate veil. Utility moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Flaum, J., held that: (1) applicable Turner factors were present in proper combination to conclude that subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) the two remaining elements necessary to pierce corporate veil were present, i. e., fraud or wrong by the parent through the subsidiary in stripping subsidiary of its assets and unjust loss or injury to the utility in view of insolvence of the subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Adams v. Associates Corp. of North America
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Ordinarily, several corporations retain their distinct identities notwithstanding fact that they have stockholders and officers in common or that one corporation owns stock in the other.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the 15th Judicial District Court, Lafayette Parish, Lucien C. Bertrand, Jr., J., which required it to pay termination benefits to a former employee of a wholly owned subsidiary's wholly owned subsidiary. The Court of Appeal, Guidry, J., held that employee of wholly owned subsidiary of wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation, which administered all personnel policies and programs for the several corporations and which sold employee's employer, would be treated as an employee of parent corporation and was therefore entitled to termination pay under provision of parent's human resources policy authorizing termination pay for reduction in staff. Affirmed. Swift, J., filed dissenting opinion and voted to grant a rehearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Adams v. Associates Corp. of North America
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Court will look beyond mere technical separate entity of corporations where one corporation, by stock control of another, interlocking directors, and having same general executive officers, operates the other corporation as a mere agency or instrumentality of the dominant corporation in furtherance of business of dominant corporation and as part of one system and in such a case, if subservient corporation incurs an obligation growing out of its operations under such relationship and enforcement of that obligation is only available and effective against dominant corporation, court will ignore fiction of separate, corporate legal existence of the two corporations and hold the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the 15th Judicial District Court, Lafayette Parish, Lucien C. Bertrand, Jr., J., which required it to pay termination benefits to a former employee of a wholly owned subsidiary's wholly owned subsidiary. The Court of Appeal, Guidry, J., held that employee of wholly owned subsidiary of wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation, which administered all personnel policies and programs for the several corporations and which sold employee's employer, would be treated as an employee of parent corporation and was therefore entitled to termination pay under provision of parent's human resources policy authorizing termination pay for reduction in staff. Affirmed. Swift, J., filed dissenting opinion and voted to grant a rehearing.

Title: C M Corp. v. Oberer Development Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Stock control and common officers and directors are generally prerequisites to piercing the corporate veil; however, those factors are not sufficient by themselves to invoke the doctrine for such factors are common business practice and exist in most parent and subsidiary relationships.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs, corporations which were in the business of offering expert advice to communities wishing to construct nursing homes, brought suit for breach of contract and breach of warranty against construction contractor and its corporate parent. After jury found that corporate existence of subsidiary was pierced during the relevant period and that corporate parent was responsible for obligations of subsidiary and its predecessors, the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Thomas R. McMillen, J., granted defendants' motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Kilkenny, Senior Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, held that where there was no evidence that defendant subsidiary or its predecessors were shells or sham corporations during period when plaintiffs and their assignors were dealing with them nor was there any evidence of wrong suffered by plaintiffs, defendant parent corporation could not be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Village Press, Inc. v. Stephen Edward Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: Fact that one person controls two corporations is not sufficient to make two corporations and the controlling stockholder the same person under the law.
Document Preview: Creditor brought suit against two corporations and their controlling stockholder for monies due under an agreement. The Superior Court, Merrimack County, Johnson, J., entered judgment against both corporations and stockholder individually, and reserved and transferred stockholder's exceptions. The Supreme Court, Brock, J., held that evidence, which failed to establish that controlling stockholder suppressed fact that his businesses were incorporated, that he made any agreement to hold himself personally responsible for his corporations' debts or that he used corporate entities to promote his own personal business, was insufficient to hold controlling stockholder personally liable for debts of two corporations which he controlled. Exceptions sustained; judgment against stockholder in individual capacity vacated.

Title: Luckett v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors determinative of whether a subsidiary is a mere alter ego of a parent corporation include whether parent owns all the stock, commonality of directors and officers, whether parent finances subsidiary, whether parent causes subsidiary's incorporation, whether subsidiary is inadequately capitalized, who pays salaries or expenses, whether subsidiary has business dealings with others, independence of officers and directors, compliance with legal requirements such as record keeping, whether subsidiary has full board of directors and whether subsidiary has any assets other than those transferred by the parent.
Document Preview: Action was brought against United States corporation and its subsidiary, a Singapore corporation, to recover for injuries which plaintiff sustained when crane cable snapped on board a drilling rig on which he was employed in Singapore. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Ralph G. Thompson, J., granted summary judgment as to parent and granted subsidiary's motion to dismiss, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) although parent furnished management team for subsidiary it could not be said that subsidiary was a mere alter ego of the parent so as to hold parent liable for any negligence of subsidiary employee, especially absent showing of fraud or inequitable conduct in use of separate corporate structures; (2) material fact issue existed as to liability of parent based on doctrines of respondeat superior and loaned servant; and (3) in personam jurisdiction could not be asserted over subsidiary...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: City of Independence v. Bob McLaughlin Const. Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Ordinarily, separate corporations, notwithstanding a common identity of officers, are separate and distinct legal entities.
Document Preview: City brought action against two corporations seeking damages for breach of contract and seeking reimbursement for services rendered to one of the corporations. Before trial, the city voluntarily dismissed its cause of action against one corporation and the Circuit Court, Division 16, Jackson County, William J. Peters, J., entered judgment in favor of the city against the other corporation. The former corporate defendant gave notice of appeal. The Court of Appeals, Somerville, J., held that appellate jurisdiction did not extend to the merits where the named appellant was not the corporation actually aggrieved by the judgment even though the same individual was president of both corporations. Appeal dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Andrew Martin Marine Corp. v. Stork-Werkspoor Diesel B.V.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Because corporations are legal entities entitled to a presumption of separateness, their legal identities should not be lightly disregarded, even if one corporation owns all the stock of another.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover for allegedly negligent repair of vessel's engines. The District Court, Sear, J., held that: (1) separate identity of various entities associated with the plaintiff would be disregarded, so that plaintiff was bound by arbitration clause in the work repair order, even though it had not signed that agreement, and (2) agreement covered claims which sounded in tort as well as contract. Motion to stay granted.

Title: Andrew Martin Marine Corp. v. Stork-Werkspoor Diesel B.V.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Complete ownership of capital stock of the subsidiary by the parent is not dispositive of the issue of whether the corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover for allegedly negligent repair of vessel's engines. The District Court, Sear, J., held that: (1) separate identity of various entities associated with the plaintiff would be disregarded, so that plaintiff was bound by arbitration clause in the work repair order, even though it had not signed that agreement, and (2) agreement covered claims which sounded in tort as well as contract. Motion to stay granted.

Title: In re County Green Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Overlapping ownership is not sufficient reason in and of itself to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: On appeal by mechanics lienors from judgment of bankruptcy court holding invalid liens on certain property owned by bankrupt debtor, the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, James C. Turk, Chief Judge, 438 F.Supp. 701, reversed and remanded, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) decision to pierce corporate veil of general contractor depended largely on resolution of questions of fact, and thus decision of bankruptcy court not to pierce corporate veil should not have been reversed unless clearly erroneous; (2) overlapping ownership of bankrupt debtor and general contractor was not sufficient reason in and of itself to pierce corporate veil of contractor; (3) amendment of contract with contractor which took over when first contractor defaulted to take into account work in place did not provide reason to set aside corporate entity of contractor by inferring basic injustice from unconscionably low contract price; and (4) decision...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Norton v. Integral Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Generally, courts will not because of stock ownership or interlocking directorship disregard the separate legal identities of corporations, unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violation of antitrust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: Former employee appealed from action of 155th District Court, Fayette County, Paul Huser, J., which issued a temporary injunction prohibiting him from violating terms of noncompetition covenant entered into with his former employer. The Court of Civil Appeals, O'Quinn, J., held that where corporate employer, which was engaged in the manufacturing and the sale of irrigation cable as well as other products and which obtained contractual agreement from employee not to compete in sales of competitive equipment for three years after termination of employment, underwent structural changes whereby another corporation controlled by majority shareholder of corporate employer was created and designated to take over all sales of irrigation cable, employee could not be enjoined from selling irrigation cable after termination of his employment but could be enjoined from engaging in those business activities in which corporate employer remained involved. Affirmed as modified.

Title: Bonanza Hotel Gift Shop, Inc. v. Bonanza No. 2
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Mere showing that one corporation is owned by another, or that the two share interlocking officers or directors, is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego; it must further be shown that the subsidiary corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is in fact a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation; nor is mere mutuality of interests sufficient to make such a showing without evidence of a commingling of funds or property interests, or of prejudice to creditors.
Document Preview: In action seeking to hold parent corporations liable for obligations of subsidiary, the Eighth Judicial District Court, Clark County, Michael J. Wendell, J., entered judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Mowbray, C. J., held that doctrine of alter ego was not applicable to hold corporations liable for obligations of their subsidiary where separate corporate books and accounts were kept, separate directors' meetings were held with full corporate formalities observed, corporations had independent headquarters and separate business responsibilities and operations, and there was no showing that the parent companies had in any way impaired the assets of the subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Branham v. McGinnis
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Where various corporations, substantially owned by one individual, are but instrumentalities through which such individual transacts his business, and where such corporations are used as a cloak or shield to perpetrate a fraud, court of law will examine the whole transaction, looking through corporate forms to the substance of things to protect the rights of innocent parties and to circumvent fraud.
Document Preview: Suit was brought to recover money on ground that defendant had guaranteed repayment of certain sum to plaintiff if codefendant failed to repay the same. The District Court, Douglas County, Patrick W. Lynch, J., affirmed municipal court judgment in favor of plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Kortum, District J., held that: (1) trial court properly disregarded corporate fiction where there was nothing inherent in transaction between plaintiff and defendant which would automatically categorize the transaction as corporate business and where retention of the fiction would have produced injustice and inequitable consequences, and (2) where plaintiff loaned $1,200 to codefendant so that codefendant could pay the same to defendant as a condition of obtaining a new loan from defendant and defendant guaranteed repayment to plaintiff if codefendant failed to pay back the $1,200 or any part thereof, case was not within the statute of frauds since the transaction was not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Continental Bankers Life Ins. Co. of the South v. Bank of Alamo
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee.
Headnote: Generally, corporate entities will be recognized as separate and distinct from their stockholders and in order to disregard the corporate entities requires, in case of parent and subsidiary, more than showing that they have similar corporate names and locations and exercise of dominion through common officers and directors.
Document Preview: Life insurance corporation brought action against bank for payment of certificate of deposit deposited in connection with loan to former parent of the life insurance corporation. The Equity Court, Crockett County, Robert S. Thomas, Chancellor, entered judgment in favor of the bank, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals affirmed and remanded, and certiorari was sought. The Supreme Court, Fones, J., held that: (1) there was no material evidence to support finding that the certificate represented additional security for the loan, and thus bank had no security interest in the certificate, where assertion that it was understanding of the bank that the certificate was security for the loan was incompetent and inadmissible, and (2) the control that the former parent exercised over the insurance corporation was not used to commit fraud, misrepresentation or dishonest or unjust act upon the bank in transactions involved and the bank could not invoke...

Title: Murphy Tugboat Co. v. Shipowners & Merchants Towboat Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N. D. California.
Headnote: A parent corporation is not liable for its subsidiaries' acts simply because the parent owns all the stock of the subsidiaries and shares common officers and directors.
Document Preview: A Sherman Act suit was brought against San Francisco Bay tugboat companies by a former competitor. Following a jury verdict for plaintiff, defendants moved for judgment notwithstanding that verdict or, alternatively, for a new trial. The District Court, William W Schwarzer, J., held, inter alia, that: (1) there was, given the 70 to 80 percent size of defendants' market share, substantial evidence to sustain a finding that defendants together possessed the power to exclude competition or control prices and hence monopoly power in the relevant market; further, there was substantial evidence that defendants willfully acquired or maintained that power, thus justifying the jury's verdict for plaintiff on the monopolization issue; (2) evidence of defendants' practice of refusing to work on vessels with competitors, coupled with other evidence raising an inference of intent to exclude competitors, was sufficient to support the jury verdict of an attempt to monopolize; (3) individual who...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mortgage and Trust, Inc. v. Bonner & Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi.
Headnote: As a general rule, two or more corporations are separate and distinct legal entities, and separate identity of each will not be disregarded in order to impose liability on one corporation for acts of another corporation merely because of overlapping stock ownership, a duplication of some or all of directors or officers, or an exercise of control that stock ownership gives to stockholders.
Document Preview: Contractor brought suit against a number of defendants to establish and foreclose a constitutional and a statutory mechanic's and materialman's lien. The 156th District Court, San Patricio County, Rachel Littlejohn, J., entered joint and several judgment against deed of trust lienholder and purchaser of land at foreclosure sale for outstanding amount found to be due plaintiff under its construction contract, and entered judgment foreclosing plaintiff's mechanic's and materialman's lien on a portion of land secured under deed of trust and defendants perfected appeal. The Court of Civil Appeals, Nye, C. J., held that: (1) evidence that two corporations had overlapping officers and directors and that their offices were in same building did not invoke alter ego theory so as to permit disregard of corporate entities and result in priority of mechanic's lien over deed of trust held by defendant corporation; (2) where plaintiff contractor's mechanic's and materialman's...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Wiedemann v. Cunard Line Ltd.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Fact that cruise shipowner and hotel company were owned by same parent company did not make shipowner liable for acts of hotel company.
Document Preview: Traveler brought suit against cruise ship owner, vacation tour operator and others for injuries sustained during use of beach at resort hotel. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Daniel P. Coman, J., granted motions to quash service of summons and dismissed complaint against shipowner and vacation tour operator, and traveler appealed. The Appellate Court, O'Connor, J., held that: (1) traveler waived issues regarding order quashing service of process on vacation tour operator; (2) fact that shipowner and hotel company were owned by same parent company did not make shipowner liable for acts of hotel company; (3) shipowner had no duty to maintain beach at hotel or to warn traveler of its dangerous condition; (4) acts of shipowner's employees in state did not amount to transaction of business for purposes of shipowner submitting to jurisdiction of state courts, and (5) traveler's pleadings, exhibits and affidavit were not sufficient to show cause of action against shipowner...

Title: Howco Leasing Corp. v. Oregon Lumber Export Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: Absent evidence which would support recovery against one company as "alter ego" of another, fact that stock of the one company might have been owned by owners of the stock of the other did not justify disregard of separate corporate entity.
Document Preview: In an action for delinquent rental payments due under a lease of logging equipment and for rental value of the equipment for a period following expiration of the lease, a judgment in favor of plaintiff was entered by the Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Richard Burke, J., after trial without a jury. Defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Tongue, J., held that: (1) where, whether the action was for trespass to personal property or for claim and delivery or replevin for wrongful withholding of possession of personal property, the claim against one company for rental value of personal property not returned at the expiration of the lease to a second company was based upon allegation and contention that the first-mentioned company had wrongfully withheld possession of the property, plaintiff was not entitled to judgment against the first-mentioned company without proof of demand against such company for return of the property and a refusal to honor such demand, and (2) where plaintiff...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Skouras v. Admiralty Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware,New Castle County.
Headnote: Absent a showing of fraud or that a subsidiary is in fact the mere alter ego of a parent, common central management alone is not proper basis for disregarding separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Stockholder sought order granting him the right to inspect certain books and records of closely held family corporation as well as books of corporation's affiliates. The Court of Chancery, in and for New Castle County, Marvel, Chancellor, held that: (1) technical defect in stockholder's demand could not be permitted to defeat his claim, and (2) where stockholder's primary purpose in obtaining inspection was not to compel a buy-out of his holdings but was to rally support to his battle against what he believed to be corporate acts detrimental to corporation and consequently to himself as minority stockholder of such corporation, he would be granted right to inspect books and records. Order to be entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Rea v. An-Son Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Fact that stockholders or officers of two corporations may be same persons does not operate to destroy legal identity of either corporation.
Document Preview: Texas citizen, who was injured while working aboard a drilling tender vessel in Venezuela, brought suits against an American parent corporation and a subsidiary, which had their principal places of business in Oklahoma, and against Venezuelan subsidiary which moved for dismissal. The District Court, Thompson, J., held that, for purposes of determining its personal jurisdiction over Venezuelan subsidiary, record disclosed that both of the other corporations had exercised sufficient control over Venezuelan corporation to enable court to disregard separate identities of each and to find that their acts might be imputed to Venezuelan corporation to give court jurisdiction under Oklahoma long-arm statute over that corporation which could be said to be doing business in Oklahoma. Motions to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Jabczenski v. Southern Pac. Memorial Hospitals
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2.
Headnote: Existence of mere interlocking directorates between defendant corporation organized for profit and defendant nonprofit corporation, each incorporated with a specific legitimate purpose, did not justify disregarding of corporate identities where no evidence showed that the dominant corporation controlled and used the other as a mere tool in carrying out its own plans and purposes.
Document Preview: Prepaid health plan physicians sued individual and corporate defendant for breach of trust and misrepresentations. The Superior Court of Pima County, Cause No. 155168, James C. Carruth, J., entered summary judgment in favor of the defendants and the plaintiff physicians appealed. The Court of Appeals, Howard, J., held that: (1) a material question of fact existed as to whether there was the creation of a trust with respect to deferred compensation plan; (2) defendant corporate officers could be held liable for conversion of trust assets; (3) there was evidence from which it could be inferred that individual defendants made representations which they knew were either untrue or which they had no intention of performing at the time of making, and (4) mere existence of interlocking directorates was insufficient to require disregarding of corporate identities. Affirmed in part, and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bendix Home Systems, Inc. v. Hurston Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, presence of common directors, absent showing that parent corporation manipulated them or that they treated subsidiaries as one with each other and parent company, is not evidence requiring court to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover from a bankrupt corporate buyer money owed from sale by plaintiff of four custom built mobile homes. After refusing plaintiff's request to set aside the separate corporate identities of the defendant, its parent corporation and another subsidiary which had counterclaimed for warranty, service and repair operations on mobile homes, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, Charles R. Scott, J., entered judgment for plaintiff on the principal claim and against the plaintiff on the counterclaim, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) under Florida law, the separate identities of two or more corporations will be disregarded only on a showing that one corporation is the mere instrumentality of the other and that the corporation is a device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes, and (2) where the plaintiff failed to show that the parent corporation exercised an...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hanson Southwest Corp. v. Dal-Mac Const. Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Generally, courts will not disregard separate legal entities because of identity of ownership, directors and officers unless purpose of the relationship is to defeat public convenience, protect fraud, defend crime, or justify wrongs, such as violation of antitrust laws.
Document Preview: Contractor, which contracted with corporation to construct shopping center and which stopped working on center because contractor had not been paid, brought action to recover against corporate owner for breach of contract and to recover against owner's parent corporation on alter-ego theory. The 134th District Court, Dallas County, Charles E. Long, Jr., J., rendered judgment for contractor, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Akin, J., held that: (1) parent corporation was not alter ego of corporate owner so as to permit recovery against parent for owner's breach of contract; (2) contract did not require that contractor's draw requests be approved by an inspecting architect unless financing was obtained through lender and it required an architect's approval; (3) exhibit, which contained record of bills received by contractor for construction project, was not admissible as a business record; (4) damages award was unsupported by the evidence; (5)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Matter of Bowen Transports, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Stock control and common directors and officers are generally prerequisites for application of doctrine permitting the corporate veil to be pierced but those factors are not by themselves sufficient to bring the doctrine into operation.
Document Preview: Creditor appealed from order of the District Court for the Eastern District of Illinois, James L. Foreman, J., which sustained objection of debtor to claim filed by the creditor. The Court of Appeals, Harlington Wood, Jr., Circuit Judge, held that state court proceedings had not resulted in a lien in favor of the creditor on certain amounts being paid to the debtor; that the debtor was not the maker of eight notes which were basis for the judgment against a related corporation; that there was no basis for application of doctrine of piercing the corporate veil so as to permit creditor to recover from debtor amounts which were owed to it from related corporation which had also been involved in bankruptcy proceedings. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Rosenthal v. Leaseway of Texas, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Even if both corporations created by the same individual were sham corporations, creditor of one such corporation, seeking to hold the incorporator personally liable, could not attack corporate existence of that corporation with which it had no dealings and which was not in any way indebted to it.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against two corporations and their incorporator to recover vehicle lease rentals. The 191st Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Spencer Carver, J., rendered judgment against all defendants, and two of them appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, McKay, J., held that incorporator was personally liable where he controlled and managed the lessee corporation in such manner that it became his alter ego and corporate formalities mandated by statute were ignored and that even if the nonleasing corporation was a mere sham its corporate veil would not be pierced since plaintiff had no dealings with it and it was not indebted to plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part.
