Title: Port Chester Elec. Const. Co. v. Atlas
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Mere fact that one person was controlling principal of more than one corporation was insufficient to justify disregarding corporate form, and where such person himself carefully respected separate identities of the corporations, and each corporation was pursuing its separate corporate business, rather than purely personal business of shareholder, corporate veils were not to be pierced.
Document Preview: A subcontractor brought action to recover the amount of its judgment against a contractor from the corporate landower, the controlling principal of the landowner and several other corporations controlled by the same principal. The Supreme Court, Trial Term, Westchester County, George M. Fanelli, J., pierced the corporate veil of the various corporate defendants and granted relief to the subcontractor as a third-party beneficiary. The Appellate Division affirmed, 47 A.D.2d 849, 368 N.Y.S.2d 814. Appeal was taken by permission. The Court of Appeals, Jasen, J., held that the lower courts had placed reliance upon improper theories, but that relief could be granted through converting the plenary action into a special proceeding. The general contractor's right to reimbursement from the property owner, for the amount of a judgment against the property owner, could be enforced by the subcontractor, and, in similar fashion, the subcontractor could enforce any other cause of action that the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Cornwell v. Williams Bros. Lumber Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.
Headnote: In absence of any evidence to contrary, corporations which were located in same building but on different floors leased separately from landlord and which maintained separate banking accounts, separate equipment, separate records and separate insurance and which filed separate tax returns and employed separate personnel on separate payrolls were separate corporations though two out of eight directors were common to the corporations and three of eight shareholders were common to both. Code, § 81A-156(b).
Document Preview: In an action arising out of an automobile collision, defendants moved for summary judgment and the motion was granted by the Fulton County Superior Court, John S. Langford, Jr. J. Plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held that in absence of any evidence to the contrary, corporations which were located in the same building but on different floors leased separately from the landlord and which maintained separate banking accounts, separate equipment, separate records and separate insurance and which filed separate tax returns and employed separate personnel on separate payrolls were separate corporations though two out of eight directors were common to the corporations and three of eight shareholders were common to both. Judgments affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hayes v. Sanitary and Imp. Dist. No. 194 of Douglas County
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Where Nebraska corporation was wholly owned subsidiary of Minnesota corporation, where employees of Nebraska corporation were paid out of payroll account of Minnesota corporation with Nebraska corporation then reimbursing parent company, and where there was almost total interlocking of officers and directors of the two corporations which did maintain separate books and file separate income tax returns, corporate shell would be pierced and separate legal identities dissipated.
Document Preview: Individual and municipal corporation brought suit to recover money paid by annexed sanitary and improvement district to fiscal agent as underwriter of warrants and bonds of district claiming that payments made by district to agent resulted in illegal discounting of price of warrants and bonds. The District Court, Douglas County, Murphy, J., entered judgment against fiscal agents, and agents, et al., appealed. The Supreme Court, McCown, J., held that municipal corporation was not equitably estopped from bringing suit; that where fiscal agent for sale of bonds purchased bonds privately from district at par, district's payment of fee for fiscal services to such purchaser constituted sale of bonds at less than par in violation of statute; and that district could contract to pay fiscal agent's fee for agent's purchase and handling of warrants where warrants were purchased exclusively from contractors to whom district had issued warrants and where warrants issued directly to fiscal...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: International Union, United Auto., Aerospace and Agr. Implement Workers of America (UAW) v. Cardwell Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Ordinarily, several corporations retain their distinct identities notwithstanding that they have stockholders and officers in common or that one corporation owns stock in others, creating subsidiary or affiliated corporations, but concept or fiction of distinct identity will not be recognized where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it a mere agency, instrumentality, agent or alter ego of other corporation.
Document Preview: International and local unions and bargaining unit employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation following failure of employer to meet its pension plan obligations under agreements with unions. The District Court, Theis, J., held that corporate veil would be pierced and parent as well as subsidiary employer would be held liable for the pension fund obligations where subsidiary employer was a mere agent, instrumentality and alter ego of parent, parent's directors, officers and employees, acting within the scope of their employment and authority, intentionally interfered with known contractual rights of unions and directly caused violations of contracts within meaning of the Labor Management Relations Act, and where, in causing such violation, officers and employees of parent and subsidiary acted in concert in manner constituting civil conspiracy; and that where, inter alia, considered conduct of the two corporations was carried on in bad faith and for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: International Union, United Auto., Aerospace and Agr. Implement Workers of America (UAW) v. Cardwell Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation owns all the stock of another and thereby selects from its own directors and officers a majority of all the directors of the other, or that parent finances subsidiary, is without more not sufficient to warrant disregarding the separate entities and treating them as the one, but where from all the facts and circumstances it is apparent that relationship between parent and subsidiary is so intimate the parent's control over the subsidiary is so dominating, and the business and assets of the two so mingled that recognition of distinct entities would result in injustice to third persons, courts will look through the legal fiction of separate entities and treat them as justice requires.
Document Preview: International and local unions and bargaining unit employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation following failure of employer to meet its pension plan obligations under agreements with unions. The District Court, Theis, J., held that corporate veil would be pierced and parent as well as subsidiary employer would be held liable for the pension fund obligations where subsidiary employer was a mere agent, instrumentality and alter ego of parent, parent's directors, officers and employees, acting within the scope of their employment and authority, intentionally interfered with known contractual rights of unions and directly caused violations of contracts within meaning of the Labor Management Relations Act, and where, in causing such violation, officers and employees of parent and subsidiary acted in concert in manner constituting civil conspiracy; and that where, inter alia, considered conduct of the two corporations was carried on in bad faith and for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Unijax, Inc. v. Factory Ins. Ass'n
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Neither ownership of all of the stock of a subsidiary, nor common officers and directors, nor both combined, are sufficient per se to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Parent corporation brought action to recover on business interruption policy for fire loss to paper mill owned by subsidiaries. The Circuit Court, Duval County, Marion W. Gooding, J., entered final summary judgment for insurer and for agent engaged to procure business interruption policy for plaintiff and plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Boyer, C.J., held that the parent and its two subsidiaries being separate entities, and each separately insured under the same policy, each corporation was required to maintain its own action to recover for its own loss; that parent corporation was not doing business through its subsidiaries which were not the mere instrumentality of parent; that parent corporation was not the real party in interest; that insurer's agreement for prelitigation payment would not support parent's claim of estoppel in view of specific provision in the agreement against waiver or modification of any conditions or requirements of policy...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Waff Bros, Inc. v. Bank of North Carolina, N.A.
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where two corporations owned by one individual are so operated that they are mere instrumentalities or alter egos of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the state, or for the purpose of fraud, the corporate entities will be disregarded and the corporations and the shareholder treated as one and the same person.
Document Preview: Holder of judgment lien on tract of land brought action to restrain execution sale of the land under another judgment lien, to have such other judgment lien declared extinguished, or in the alternative, to require foreclosing bank to exhaust other security before proceeding with foreclosure. The Superior Court, Pasquotank County, Russell J. Lanier, J., denied preliminary injunction and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, 25 N.C.App. 517, 214 S.E.2d 261, affirmed and certiorari was granted. The Supreme Court, Lake, J., held that showing that execution sale of property would not produce adequate sums to pay any appreciable portion of plaintiff's judgment claim with interest was a sufficient showing of reasonable apprehension of irreparable harm; that if debtor corporation and corporation to which debtor conveyed the land were so controlled by the sole stockholder as to make transferee the mere alter ego of transferor, transfer of judgment to transferee had the same effect as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Waff Bros, Inc. v. Bank of North Carolina, N.A.
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Mere fact that all of the outstanding shares of stock of each of two corporations are owned by one individual, who is the chief executive officer of each corporation, does not necessarily destroy the corporate entities so as to make the two corporations and the sole stockholder one and the same person in contemplation of the law.
Document Preview: Holder of judgment lien on tract of land brought action to restrain execution sale of the land under another judgment lien, to have such other judgment lien declared extinguished, or in the alternative, to require foreclosing bank to exhaust other security before proceeding with foreclosure. The Superior Court, Pasquotank County, Russell J. Lanier, J., denied preliminary injunction and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, 25 N.C.App. 517, 214 S.E.2d 261, affirmed and certiorari was granted. The Supreme Court, Lake, J., held that showing that execution sale of property would not produce adequate sums to pay any appreciable portion of plaintiff's judgment claim with interest was a sufficient showing of reasonable apprehension of irreparable harm; that if debtor corporation and corporation to which debtor conveyed the land were so controlled by the sole stockholder as to make transferee the mere alter ego of transferor, transfer of judgment to transferee had the same effect as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Umbaugh Builders, Inc. v. Parr Co. of Suffolk, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Suffolk County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: That same two parties were officers, directors, and stockholders of both lessor corporation and lessee corporation would not alter fact that two corporations were separate entities, and a contract made by lessee corporation for construction of race track facility would not bind lessor corporation to pay amount therein specified, even though lessor corporation did consent that improvements contracted for be made.
Document Preview: Contractor brought action to foreclose mechanic's lien against owner on claim arising out of contract with lessee of property for concrete work on grandstand and quarter horse racing facility. The Supreme Court, Suffolk County, Gordon M. Lipetz, J., held that measure of contractor's lien against property and its owner would be value of labor and material added to property rather than set contract price which might have been inflated beyond reasonable value thereof to owner's detriment. Judgment entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Musman v. Modern Deb, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There must be complete domination and control of subsidiary before parent's corporate veil can be pierced; stock control, interlocking directors and officers and the like are in and of themselves insufficient, and the control must actually be used to commit wrong against the plaintiff and must be the proximate cause of the plaintiff's loss.
Document Preview: Action was brought by a discharged general manager-designer for breach of employment contract. Judgment in the amount of $59,187.03 was awarded against the employer and a parent corporation of the employer by the Supreme Court, New York County, Louis I. Kaplan, J. Appeals were taken by the manager-designer and by the employer and its parent. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that where the employment contract contained a provision that, should the manager be discharged without cause, the employer undertook to pay him full compensation and bonuses to the end of term and exonerated him from any obligation to perform services for the employer, such provision fixed exposure of the employer following discharge without cause and removed the case from the ordinary rule requiring mitigation of damages. The mere fact that the contract required the general manager-designer, in the apparel business, to perform reasonable responsibilities and duties for his employer's parent...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gentry v. Credit Plan Corp. of Houston
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, because of duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or because of exercise of control that stock ownership gives to the stockholders; on the other hand, where management and operations are assimilated to the extent that the subsidiary is simply a name or conduit through which the parent conducts its business, the corporate fiction may be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Action was brought against credit company, two of its employees, and two corporations allegedly controlling credit company, seeking to recover damages for unreasonable collection efforts. The Fourteenth Judicial District Court, Harris County, William N. Blanton, Jr., J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part, 516 S.W.2d 471, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Walker, J., held that defendant credit company was, as a matter of law, the alter ego of its parent, the second corporate defendant, and that filing of suit against defendant credit company stopped the running of two-year statute of limitations in favor of defendant parent, which had been joined as a defendant more than two years after the alleged cause of action accrued. Judgment of Court of Civil Appeals reversed, that of trial court affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Westcott Const. Corp. v. Cumberland Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Separate corporate identities may be overlooked where, in addition to common ownership and management there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Bill was brought for declaratory relief in which corporate general bidder sought to establish propriety of bid submitted by it to joint board of water commissioners of two towns. The Superior Court, Norfolk County, Griffin, J., decreed the bid to be valid, and another bidder appealed. The Appeals Court, Armstrong, J., held that the general bid was not invalid on theory that corporate general bidder and corporate subbidder were essentially the same entity so that general bidder was therefore prohibited by statute from listing any other subbidder in general bid. Affirmed.

Title: Westcott Const. Corp. v. Cumberland Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Common ownership and control of two corporations, standing alone, is insufficient to merge them into one or to make either the agent of the other.
Document Preview: Bill was brought for declaratory relief in which corporate general bidder sought to establish propriety of bid submitted by it to joint board of water commissioners of two towns. The Superior Court, Norfolk County, Griffin, J., decreed the bid to be valid, and another bidder appealed. The Appeals Court, Armstrong, J., held that the general bid was not invalid on theory that corporate general bidder and corporate subbidder were essentially the same entity so that general bidder was therefore prohibited by statute from listing any other subbidder in general bid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Call Carl, Inc. v. BP Oil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Notwithstanding the fact that the parent corporation may own all of a subsidiary's stock, and interlocking directorships may exist between the two corporations, if a subsidiary maintains its own books and accounts, and makes its own marketing, purchasing, management and other policy decisions, it cannot be held to be acting as an agent of the parent.
Document Preview: Retail gasoline dealers who had franchise agreements with subsidiary of oil company brought action against the subsidiary and the oil company to recover for alleged violations of federal antitrust laws, alleged breach of contract, alleged fraud and misrepresentation in the execution of franchise agreements, and refusal to allocate gasoline as required by federal regulations. On oil company's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, and improper service of process, the District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that oil company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to be subject to venue and jurisdiction under the antitrust claims in state in which subsidiary transacted business; that oil company exercised sufficient control over the subsidiary to be subject to jurisdiction with respect to the state claims; and that service of process upon the subsidiary was sufficient to effect service on the oil company. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Call Carl, Inc. v. BP Oil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in a case where interlocking directorships exist and there is complete stock ownership of the subsidiary by the parent, it is necessary to find some evidence of conscious control by the parent of a major aspect of the subsidiary's operation.
Document Preview: Retail gasoline dealers who had franchise agreements with subsidiary of oil company brought action against the subsidiary and the oil company to recover for alleged violations of federal antitrust laws, alleged breach of contract, alleged fraud and misrepresentation in the execution of franchise agreements, and refusal to allocate gasoline as required by federal regulations. On oil company's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, and improper service of process, the District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that oil company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to be subject to venue and jurisdiction under the antitrust claims in state in which subsidiary transacted business; that oil company exercised sufficient control over the subsidiary to be subject to jurisdiction with respect to the state claims; and that service of process upon the subsidiary was sufficient to effect service on the oil company. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. v. State Tax Commission of State of Miss.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate fiction is not to be disregarded because of mutuality of corporate names, stockholders and officers, under Mississippi law.
Document Preview: The United States brought suit on behalf of Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians to enjoin the Mississippi State Tax Commission from assessing, collecting, and attempting to collect sales taxes from a construction company which was formed at request of tribal council. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, at Jackson, William Harold Cox, J., entered judgment granting a permanent injunction, and the Commission and the sheriff of Neshoba County appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coleman, Circuit Judge, held that the construction company was an entity separate and distinct from the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians, the group named as beneficiary of the exemption in Mississippi's sales tax statutes, that the United States was attempting to lend its name to a suit on behalf of a private corporation and was not the real party in interest, and that tribal character of Choctaw Indians in Mississippi came to an end when the United States Senate ratified...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Quarles v. Fuqua Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Facts that nonresident parent corporation received monthly financial reports from subsidiary and consulted with its officers, that parent provided financial support, that employment contracts of officers of subsidiary required them to be available in an advisory capacity to parent, that two of parent's staff members were on subsidiary's board of directors, that parent's employee stock purchase plan was available to employees of subsidiary, and that subsidiary was sold as an unprofitable investment did not warrant application of alter ego doctrine for jurisdiction over parent which, unlike subsidiary, had not engaged in any business transactions in the state, where total participation of parent in affairs of subsidiary did not amount to a domination of day to day business decisions of subsidiary. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d)(7), (e), 28 U.S.C.A.; K.S.A. 60–308, 60–308(b).
Document Preview: Class action was brought against a nonresident corporation and others to recover compensatory and punitive damages for fraudulently inducing plaintiffs to enter into training course contracts and enroll in vocational training schools. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, George Templar, J., sustained nonresident corporation's motion to quash and dismiss, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Hill, Circuit Judge, held that district court had no jurisdiction over nonresident corporation, notwithstanding alter ego and agency theories relied upon by plaintiffs. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Reul v. Sahara Hotel
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock and presence of common directors will not alone fuse subsidiary into parent corporation, either for purposes of liability or for purpose of establishing some sort of agency relationship.
Document Preview: Products liability action arising from explosion of chlorine tank. On motion of one defendant to dismiss, the District Court, Singleton, J., held that where defendant California corporation was completely integrated subsidiary of defendant New York corporation, and New York corporation clearly did business in Texas within contemplation of long-arm statute, activities of New York corporation in Texas could be imputed to California corporation and California corporation could be said to be doing business' in Texas for purpose of in personam jurisdiction. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Collins v. Booker
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.
Headnote: Fact that two corporations are incorporated by the same people and have the same officers does not show identity of the two as one corporation.
Document Preview: Automobile owner brought action against operator of taxicab, which had collided with and damaged plaintiff's automobile, and cabbie's insurer seeking recovery for personal injuries, for damage to her automobile resulting in diminution of its market value and, by amendment, sought to recover for loss of use from date of accident to time of verdict and judgment in trover action she had brought against repairman. Defendants moved to strike the amendment. The Superior Court, DeKalb County, Ray C. Norvell, J., sustained motion and ruling was certified for appeal. The Court of Appeals, Eberhardt, P.J., held that though one corporation may own a majority of the stock in another, such fact does not render it liable for the other's negligence, that since automobile was delivered to repairman with consent of both insurer and owner the repairman was entitled to retain possession until he received payment for work and that judgment in trover action was not res...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Fanfan v. Berwind Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Ordinarily, common directors and officers and stock control are prerequisite for the application of the "mere instrumentality" rule.
Document Preview: Puerto Rican seaman injured in the territorial waters of Puerto Rico while working for a Puerto Rico corporate employer brought suit against employer's parent corporation for the alleged Jones Act negligence and unseaworthiness of tug owned and operated by the employer. On parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Broderick, J., held that court would not pierce the corporate veil of the employer, an insured employer under the Puerto Rico Workmen's Accident Compensation Law, and hold the parent company which was uninsured under the Puerto Rico statute liable in absence of showing that the employer was the mere instrumentality of the parent corporation. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Scott-Douglas Corp. v. Greyhound Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Sole ownership of stock and common directors and officers between parent and subsidiary are only some of factors to be considered in determining whether or not the corporate fiction should be disregarded and shareholders held liable.
Document Preview: Actioin for breach of franchise contract and for fraud in inducement of contract. On motion by defendants for dismissal of action as to one defendant and on defendants' motion for summary judgment, the Superior Court, Wright, J., held that where there was no evidence in any way tending to show fraud by a parent corporation except evidence of ownership and common directors and officers, there was a failure to make a case against the parent corporation. The Court also held that the question whether franchisees were justified in their reliance upon representations was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Motion of defendant parent corporation for dismissal granted; motion of remaining defendant for summary judgment denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bay Sound Transp. Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In determining if a subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, factors generally to be considered include, common stock ownership, common directors or officers, financing of subsidiary by parent, incorporation of subsidiary being caused by parent, grossly inadequate capital for subsidiary, payment by parent of salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary's receiving no business except that given by parent, parent's using subsidiary's property as its own and directors or officers of subsidiary not acting independently in interest of subsidiary but taking their orders from parent in the latter's interest.
Document Preview: Income tax refund actions. On remand, 410 F.2d 505, the District Court, Hannay, J., held that evidence failed to establish that evasion or avoidance of federal income taxes, by securing benefit of multiple surtax exemptions, was not the principal purpose motivating separate incorporation of 20 barges and vessels acquired by shipping fleet, with one individual being major stockholder and chief executive officer of all but two of such corporations, with two partnerships and corporations using same office address, with one individual personally soliciting all business and directing services to be performed, with records governing all transactions being maintained by partnerships and intercorporate affairs handled as accounts payable and accounts receivable and only evidence that tax evasion or avoidance was not principal motive being unsupported statements of stockholders and others. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Even ownership of all the stock of the corporation coupled with a common management does not operate as a merger of the two corporations into a single entity.
Document Preview: The trustees in reorganization of a railroad moved to intervene as of right as parties plaintiff and to be given exclusive control of 13 derivative suits, and a holding company cross-petitioned to be realigned as a party plaintiff and to be given exclusive control of all the cases, and the shareholder-plaintiffs who commenced the actions opposed both motions. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Joseph S. Lord, III, J., held, inter alia, that where trustees of property of railroad in reorganization were appointed by reorganization court, none of trustees was officer or director of the railroad or a holding company which was sole stockholder of the railroad, and all actions taken by trustees were subject to approval of the reorganization court, trustees were entitled to exclusive control of the claims asserted on the debtor's behalf in the 13 derivative suits, plaintiffs in such suits would be dismissed, and trustees would be granted leave to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: La Chemise Lacoste v. General Mills, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: That one corporation is wholly owned subsidiary of another and that there may be common directors does not justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action involving rights to certain trademark. Certain defendants moved for dismissal or to be dropped as parties, principal defendant moved for production of documents, and plaintiff moved for protective order and injunction pendente lite. The District Court, Latchum, J., held, inter alia, that defendant corporation's parent corporation and sibling corporations were improperly joined, where complete relief on original pleadings could be granted without them and they were strangers to dispute, despite claimed agreements and relations between them and defendant. Defendants' motion granted and plaintiff's motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gordon Chemical Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: Ownership of stock in several corporations by one person does not create single unit or justify disregard of separate corporations, and it is only if corporation is sham, or is used to perpetrate deception to defeat public policy, that separate corporations can be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action to recover business interruption loss under insurance policy. The Superior Court, Meagher, J., found for one of the insureds, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Spalding, J., held that where business of one corporation insured under business interruption policy was manufacture of polystyrene, policy provisions requiring reduction of loss by complete or partial resumption of operation of the property herein described, whether damaged or not * * *., by making use of other property at the location(s) described herein or elsewhere * * *,, and by making use of stock (raw, in process or finished) at the location(s) described herein or elsewhere, did not compel manufacturer to avoid loss by purchase of polystyrene from others for sale to its sole customer; such would not be resumption of its operations. Order for judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: St. Petersburg Sheraton Corp. v. Stuart
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Ownership by one corporation of all stock of another corporation does not destroy the identity of the latter as a distinct legal entity, nor does fact that stockholders or officers of two corporations are same persons operate to destroy legal identity of either corporation.
Document Preview: Action for burns received by guest at restaurant in hotel during preparation of cherries jubilee brought against corporate owner of hotel and corporation allegedly chargeable with its liabilities. The Circuit Court, Pinellas County, Robert E. Beach, J., entered judgment for compensatory and punitive damages and defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Pierce, Acting Chief Judge, held that chef at restaurant in one defendant's hotel was not grossly negligent in preparing cherries jubilee at banquet when he poured flambe on cherries at time he did not see any fire in pan and plaintiff is not entitled to punitive damages for burns received when the flambe was ignited causing flame to shoot out and strike plaintiff. The Court also held that where the other defendant or a subsidiary was to receive all of stock of hotel corporation, the parent of corporate owner of restaurant, in exchange for defendant's stock, a wholly owned subsidiary of defendant was organized and by bill...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Neither ownership of all stock of subsidiary, nor identity of officers and directors, nor both combined are sufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where corporate parent of subsidiary which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized dummy and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary. Parent's motion for summary judgment granted. See also D.C., 47 F.R.D. 155.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Smith v. City of Lee's Summit
Court: Kansas City Court of Appeals, Missouri.
Headnote: Mere fact that one individual may be executive officer of two or more corporations or even that same individual may have absolute stock control of both does not justify court in disregarding proper legal forms.
Document Preview: Proceeding for writ of certiorari to review grant of rezoning petition. The Circuit Court, Jackson County, James A. Moore, J., affirmed the action of the city and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Howard, J., held that fact that corporation rented office space to city council member who voted in favor of rezoning land owned by another corporation which had some common directors and same chief executive officer did not render zoning ordinance invalid, and that fact that overall zoning ordinance of city provided that any land annexed by city would automatically come under provisions of zoning ordinance and would be classified and used for agricultural purposes until such time as city had opportunity to study and reclassify such annexed areas did not preclude city from granting ten-year permit for use of annexed tract of land as mobile home park. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Rena-Ware Distributors, Inc. v. State
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Mere common ownership of stock, common officers and employees does not justify disregarding separate corporate identities unless a fraud is being worked upon a third person.
Document Preview: Corporate taxpayer contested deficiency assessment for state business and occupation taxes. The Superior Court, Thurston County, Hewitt A. Henry, J., sustained the assessment and the taxpayer appealed. The Supreme Court, Rosellini, J., held that service charges made for the privilege of making deferred payments on merchandise were not part of purchase price of merchandise and, as all servicing of deferred payment accounts was handled entirely within state, under statute taxing business activity within state, tax could be assessed against receipts from service charges arising from sales made outside the state, and that amounts received as compensation for managerial services performed within state for wholly-owned foreign subsidiary were taxable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hubbard v. Capital Southwest Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Waco.
Headnote: Fact that stockholders or officers in parent and subsidiary corporations may be the same persons does not operate to destroy legal identity of either corporation.
Document Preview: Stockholders' derivative action, in which plaintiffs sought judgment against organizing corporation and joint officers and directors for intercorporate indebtedness. The 68th District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered summary judgment in favor of defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Wilson, J., held that where history of organizing and incorporated corporations evidenced constant effort by organizer and its officers to salvage incorporatee and predecessor from insolvency, stockholders of incorporatee were fully informed of steps taken, including intercorporate loans, and actively participated or maintained silence without dissent and inequity or disruption of purpose of legal entity was not otherwise shown, corporate entity would not be disregarded and organizing corporation and joint officers and directors held liable for intercorporate indebtedness, notwithstanding that incorporatee may have been alter ego of organizing corporation....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hubbard v. Capital Southwest Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Waco.
Headnote: Separate legal identities of corporations will not be disregarded because of interlocking directorates or stock ownership unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violations of antitrust laws, protect fraud or defend crime.
Document Preview: Stockholders' derivative action, in which plaintiffs sought judgment against organizing corporation and joint officers and directors for intercorporate indebtedness. The 68th District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered summary judgment in favor of defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Wilson, J., held that where history of organizing and incorporated corporations evidenced constant effort by organizer and its officers to salvage incorporatee and predecessor from insolvency, stockholders of incorporatee were fully informed of steps taken, including intercorporate loans, and actively participated or maintained silence without dissent and inequity or disruption of purpose of legal entity was not otherwise shown, corporate entity would not be disregarded and organizing corporation and joint officers and directors held liable for intercorporate indebtedness, notwithstanding that incorporatee may have been alter ego of organizing corporation....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Country Maid, Inc. v. Haseotes
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Common owners, common directors or common executives alone do not necessitate going behind corporate structure.
Document Preview: Proceedings on motion to dismiss civil antitrust action. The District Court, Body, J., held that where individual defendants were officers and management employees of various corporations that were engaged in one single enterprise, service upon statutory agent for one corporation in Pennsylvania constituted service of antitrust action upon individual defendants even though they did not reside in Pennsylvania, owned no property in Pennsylvania and had residences and places of business outside Pennsylvania, and that corporations which were engaged in one operation were transacting business' in Pennsylvania where one corporation had its principal office. Motion dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Blackwell Printing Co. v. Blackwell-Wielandy Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Corporation is ordinarily an entity, separate and apart from its stockholders, and mere ownership of all stock of one corporation by another, and identity of officers of one with officers of another, are not alone sufficient to create identity of corporate interests between the two companies or to create the relation of principal and agent or to create a representative or fiduciary relation between the two; rather, there must be such dominion and control that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Assignee of realty purchaser brought action claiming that defendant, which had been a tenant of building on the realty, wrongfully removed a ventilating system, two conveyor systems, and two wash basins. The Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, Michael F. Godfrey, J., set aside verdict for plaintiff and granted tenant a new trial. On plaintiff's appeal, the Supreme Court, Houser, Commissioner, held, inter alia, that every legitimate inference to be drawn from the evidence of plaintiff led to conclusion that landlord-vendor, which conveyed the realty to plaintiff's assignor, never owned or claimed to own conveyor systems in building on the realty; on the contrary, the undisputed facts of record established that the conveyor systems, which were installed by tenant, constituted trade fixtures which the tenant, upon surrender of its lease, had right to lawfully remove. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: ACS Industries, Inc. v. Keller Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Where alleged agency or alter ego claim is based on an agreement whereby one corporate entity is made subordinate to the other, the corporate veil will be pierced; however, although the officers and directors of the two corporations are the same, the corporate veil will not be pierced so long as the officers and directors can be said to wear two hats and operate in theoretically distinct capacities for each corporate entity.
Document Preview: On motion to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction, the District Court, Timbers, C.J., held that, notwithstanding fact that cause of action did not arise out of transaction between plaintiff and defendant's subsidiary, and no aspects of disputed transaction occurred within jurisdictional forum, service in Connecticut on defendant's subsidiary was sufficient to confer jurisdiction over defendant where plaintiff made threshold demonstration that defendant and its subsidiary failed to maintain sufficient formal separateness; that it necessarily followed, from disposition of jurisdictional issue, that for venue purposes defendant constructively did business in Connecticut through a subsidiary; and that there was not controlling question of law as to which there is a substantial ground for difference of opinion justifying an immediate appeal. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brown v. Margrande Compania Naviera, S. A.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: More than identity of officers and stock ownership in corporate setup must exist before corporate fiction will be disregarded; it must appear that corporation was organized for a fraudulent purpose or that some injury has resulted from the transaction, something of fraud, illegality, or wrongdoing or something giving moving party cause for complaint.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation and its subsidiaries for salvage services in towing and saving tanker chartered by one subsidiary and carrying other subsidiary's cargo. Upon parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Kellam, J., held that instrumentality rule would not be invoked to make parent corporation liable, even though corporations had interlocking directors and officers, and though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parent corporation, where there was no injustice, fraud, or wrong, public convenience was not affected, and no illicit act was committed. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brown v. Margrande Compania Naviera, S. A.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that two corporations have same officers, directors, and stockholders, or that stock in one company is owned by another company does not justify invoking the instrumentality rule.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation and its subsidiaries for salvage services in towing and saving tanker chartered by one subsidiary and carrying other subsidiary's cargo. Upon parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Kellam, J., held that instrumentality rule would not be invoked to make parent corporation liable, even though corporations had interlocking directors and officers, and though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parent corporation, where there was no injustice, fraud, or wrong, public convenience was not affected, and no illicit act was committed. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: My Bread Baking Co. v. Cumberland Farms, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Bristol.
Headnote: Although common stock ownership of corporations and common management alone will not make one corporation liable for acts of another, liability may be imposed upon one or more of group of closely identified corporations (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequences of intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Conversion actions tried in Superior Court before Mitchell, J. One defendant excepted to judge's refusal to direct a verdict for it. The Supreme Judicial Court, Cutter, J., held that separate corporate entities were disregarded, and principal family-owned corporation which sold its milk and dairy products to retail dairy stores operated by satellite family-owned corporations was liable for conversions of plaintiff's bakery racks on termination of arrangement for sale of plaintiff's bakery products in stores, where principal corporation's sales manager was responsible for order that stores not return racks, principal corporation and satellite corporations were operated from same headquarters as closely coordinated single enterprise in which sales manager was dominant figure, and manager dealt ambiguously with plaintiff. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Inn Operations, Inc. v. River Hills Motor Inn Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: Ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another does not, itself, create an identity of corporate interest between the two companies, nor render the stockholding company the owner of the property of the other.
Document Preview: Action to restrain city and others from consummating sale of an urban renewal tract. The Polk District Court, Harry Perkins, Jr., J., granted an injunction and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Mason, J., held that where city had failed to notify qualified land developer, which had submitted proposals on the development of an urban renewal tract, that the restrictions contained in the renewal plan and the applicable ordinances would not be enforced, and thereafter the city accepted the bid of another and modified the restrictions to conform to that bid, procedures followed by city were improper for lack of a definite common standard on which to submit competitive proposals, and arbitrarily and unreasonably deprived developer of its right to bid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pauley Petroleum, Inc. v. Continental Oil Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Mexican subsidiary of defendant Delaware corporation which had its own directors, officers and records and which had some officers and personnel in common with parent corporation was not mere instrumentality of parent and parent would not be enjoined from prosecuting suits filed by subsidiary in Mexico against plaintiff Delaware corporation and plaintiff Mexican corporation on theory that defendant subsidiary was responsive to defendant's wishes.
Document Preview: Action by Delaware corporation and Mexican corporation to enjoin defendant Delaware corporation and its agents and associates from prosecuting lawsuits pending in Mexico. The Court of Chancery, New Castle County, Duffy, Chancellor, held that Mexican subsidiary of defendant Delaware corporation which had its own directors, officers and records and which had some officers and personnel in common with parent corporation was not mere instrumentality of parent and parent would not be enjoined from prosecuting suits filed by subsidiary in Mexico against plaintiff Delaware corporation and plaintiff Mexican corporation on theory that defendant subsidiary was responsive to defendant's wishes. Temporary restraining order dissolved and motion for preliminary injunction denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Zaist v. Olson
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Essential purposes of corporate structure, including stockholder immunity, must and will be protected when corporation functions as entity in normal manner contemplated and permitted by law, and when it functions in such manner, there is nothing insidious in stockholder control, interlocking directorates, or identity of officers, but when corporation is so manipulated by individual or another corporate entity as to become a mere puppet or tool for manipulator, justice may require courts to disregard corporate fiction and impose liability on real actor.
Document Preview: Action was brought against individual defendant, first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant for services and materials furnished by plaintiffs in clearing and grading land. The Superior Court in New London County, Thim, J., after reference to Thomas E. Troland State Referee, entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the referee's report against the individual defendant and the second corporate defendant, and all defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Alcorn, J., held that where individual defendant caused creation of both first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant and thereafter completely dominated and controlled them, and all work and material furnished to first corporate defendant by plaintiffs in clearing and grading went into land which, after being juggled about, came to rest in individual defendant or second corporate defendant, and first corporate defendant was used for benefit of individual defendant and second corporate defendant,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Overstreet v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate fiction should not be disregarded because of identity of corporate names, stockholders and officers and fact of ownership of stock in one corporation by another.
Document Preview: Action against railroad arising out of crossing accident. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, William Harold Cox, J., overruled plaintiff's motion to set aside and vacate summary judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appraled. The Court of Appeals, Ainsworth, Circuit Judge, held that under circumstances, separate identities of two railroad corporations would not be disregarded, although first railroad owned all stock in second railroad, where second railroad owned and actively operated its own business, and first railroad would not be held liable for alleged negligence of second railroad in crossing accident. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Palmer v. Stokely
Court: United States District Court W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation is mere instrumentality of parent when (1) parent owns all stock; (2) both have common directors and officers; (3) parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent causes subsidiary's incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has no business except with its parent or subsidiary corporation or no assets except those transferred by its parent or subsidiary; (8) directors and officers do not act independently in interests of subsidiary; (9) formal legal requirements of subsidiary such as keeping corporate minutes are not observed; (10) distinctions between parent and subsidiary and subsidiary and its subsidiary are disregarded or confused; (11) subsidiary does not have full board of directors.
Document Preview: Action by trustee in bankruptcy against individuals and company owned by them to recover amounts allegedly fraudulently transferred to defendants. The District Court, Daugherty, J., held, inter alia, that cancellation of amount owed bankrupt by corporation controlled by persons who controlled bankrupt was void where it occurred within one year prior to bankruptcy, there were creditors of bankrupt existing at time of cancellation, there were others who subsequently became creditors of bankrupt, bankrupt was insolvent at time of cancellation and was engaged in business for which property remaining in its hands after cancellation was unreasonably small capital, cancellation was made by owners in behalf of bankrupt and they believed it would incur debts beyond its ability to pay as debts matured, and was also made with actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud existing creditors and particularly premium stamp holders. Judgment for trustee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Shelburne Sportswear, Inc. v. City of Philadelphia
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Ordinarily, separate corporations retain their distinct identities notwithstanding the fact that they may have common stockholders, directors, and officers.
Document Preview: Taxpayer's action to review assessment under municipal mercantile license tax ordinance. The Court of Common Pleas No. 6, Philadelphia County, June Term, 1961, No. 2849, Bernard J. Kelley, J., reversed a tax review board decision affirming the assessment. The Superior Court, October Term, 1965, No. 306,206 Pa.Super. 349, 213 A.2d 92, affirmed. Application for allocatur was granted. The Supreme Court, No. 143 January Term, 1966, Roberts, J., held that a corporation which knitted yarns, which were supplied by corporate affiliate which had same stockholders holding shares in same proportion and same directors and officers, into unfinished garments which it transferred to affiliate which provided sufficient funds for corporation to meet its expenses was subject to annual mercantile license tax imposed on every person engaged in business for gain or profit within city of Philadelphia. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Whayne v. Transportation Management Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Ordinarily, common directors and officers and stock control are prerequisites for application of the instrumentality rule whereby one corporation is held to be mere instrument of another so as to place liability of first corporation for conduct of the second.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by cook aboard vessel owned by one corporation trict Court, on defendant's motion to disagainst a second corporation. The Dismiss, Van Dusen, J., held that where defendant corporation owned no stock in corporate owner of vessel, the two corporations had only one common director and officer, corporate vessel owner regularly paid defendant for bookkeeping and other services that defendant performed, directors meetings of corporations were held at different times and in different places, defendant did not direct movement of vessel, purchase any equipment or supplies used on it, finance building of it or hire or fire personnel on board, corporate vessel owner was not mere instrumentality of defendant and defendant was not liable for cook's injuries. Action dismissed with prejudice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Stauffer v. Isaly Dairy Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Mahoning County.
Headnote: When intermingled corporations have intermingled officers who conduct business and management in such manner that general public is under impression that they are all one and same, corporations should be bound by their representations.
Document Preview: Tort action. The Court of Common Pleas overruled plaintiff's motion to substitute proper name of party defendant, and plaintiff appealed on questions of law. The Court of Appeals, Lynch, J., held that under circumstances, plaintiff could amend, after expiration of limitations, to substitute name The Isaly Dairy Company for The Isaly Dairy Company of Pittsburgh as defendant in action for injuries sustained when struck by dairy truck, where, although named corporations were separate, they maintained same office with same officer for service, plaintiff and her attorney exercised reasonable diligence in attempting to ascertain identity of tortfeasor and mistake was caused or induced by officers of corporation, and plaintiff would have been informed of her mistake had originally-named defendant filed its answers to interrogatories within time originally allowed. Reversed. Jones, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Botwinick v. Credit Exchange, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Neither similarity of names between parent and subsidiary corporations nor total ownership of stock of subsidiary by parent nor fact that single individual is active chief executive of both corporations will per se justify a court in piercing the corporate veil if each corporation maintains a bonafide separate and distinct corporate existence.
Document Preview: Business libel case. The Court of Common Pleas No. 3 (heard in Court of Common Pleas No. 5) of the County of Philadelphia, No. 729 December Term, 1963, Lee Weinrott, J., dismissed the preliminary objections. The order was entered on January 7, 1965. The defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, No. 163 January Term, 1965, Jones, J., held that New York corporation was not doing business' within Pennsylvania even though it had a subsidiary which was a Pennsylvania corporation. Order reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mid-State Homes, Inc. v. Knight
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: That two corporations had same officers and directors and same postoffice address was not in itself sufficient to destroy their existence as separate entities.
Document Preview: Foreclosure suit brought upon installment note and mortgage. The Chancery Court, Woodruff County, Ford Smith, Chancellor, found transaction to be void for usury and entered decree for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that fact that holder of installment note and mortgage exercised option to accelerate maturity of future payments and filed suit for full amount without making any deduction for interest that had not yet accrued did not render transaction usurious. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Architectural Bldg. Products, Inc. v. Cupples Products Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Control of one corporation by virtue of stock ownership or incidental to overlapping directorates does not warrant disregard of individual corporate entities.
Document Preview: Action for damages for wrongful termination of representation contract. On motion of one defendant corporation for summary judgment, the District Court, Grubb, J., held that in absence of any showing that defendant corporation, which had acquired all capital stock of other defendant corporation in exchange for common stock of acquiring corporation under reorganization agreement, had evinced an intent to assume liabilities of other corporation whose stock it had acquired, acquiring corporation could not be sued by other corporation's distributor for alleged wrongful termination of representation contract. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Fawcett v. Missouri Pac. R. Co.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Lake Charles Division.
Headnote: Corporation is ordinarily an entity, separate and apart from its stockholders, and mere ownership of all of stock of one corporation by another and identity of officers of one with officers of another are not alone sufficient to create identity of corporate interests between the two or relation of principal and agent between them.
Document Preview: Action against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act. The District Court, Hunter, J., held that freight company employee, who died as result of being crushed between truck tractors on flatcar being loaded on siding owned by defendant railroad, who was not on railroad payroll, who was not doing work that railroad was required to do, and who was not under supervision of railroad employees was not employee of railroad within coverage of Federal Employers' Liability Act at time that he met his death, and his administratrix had no cause of action against railroad where freight company was not alter ego of railroad even though railroad owned all outstanding stock of freight company and five officers of freight company were also officers of railroad. Summary judgment for defendant. Judgment affirmed, 347 F.2d 233.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Fawcett v. Missouri Pac. R. Co.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Lake Charles Division.
Headnote: Extent of stock ownership and the mere potential control of one company over another is not controlling factor in determining whether to disregard corporate entity, and something must be disclosed to indicate exercise of undue domination or influence resulting in infringement on rights of subservient corporation for benefit of dominant one; otherwise, rights of separate corporations with respect to their corporate property will be governed by rules applicable in ordinary cases.
Document Preview: Action against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act. The District Court, Hunter, J., held that freight company employee, who died as result of being crushed between truck tractors on flatcar being loaded on siding owned by defendant railroad, who was not on railroad payroll, who was not doing work that railroad was required to do, and who was not under supervision of railroad employees was not employee of railroad within coverage of Federal Employers' Liability Act at time that he met his death, and his administratrix had no cause of action against railroad where freight company was not alter ego of railroad even though railroad owned all outstanding stock of freight company and five officers of freight company were also officers of railroad. Summary judgment for defendant. Judgment affirmed, 347 F.2d 233.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McLaughlin v. L. Bloom Sons Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Sole ownership by one individual of all of stock in two corporations does not require that court as a matter of law find that one of the corporations is the alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: Union's action for declaratory judgment that the new defendant corporation was the alter ego of the old defendant corporation for the purposes of collective bargaining agreement. The Superior Court, County of Santa Clara Robert F. Peckham, J., entered a judgment for the union and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Agee, J., held that it was not an abuse of discretion to apply the alter ego doctrine to the new corporation which was controlled by the same individuals as the old corporation that had signed a collective bargaining agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Murdock Acceptance Corp. v. Adcox
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Ordinarily, two or more corporations are separate and distinct entities although same individuals are incorporators of, or own stock in, several corporations, and although they have same officers.
Document Preview: Action by seller's assignee to replevy trucks under conditional sales contracts. The Circuit Court, Simpson County, Homer Currie, J., rendered judgment for defendant, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Kyle, J., held, inter alia, that assignee could bring replevin action, although assignee had reassigned contracts to bank, as security for loan, under agreement that assignee should continue to exercise right to receive payments and to repossess property. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brown v. Moorhead Oil Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Mere fact that entire stock in two corporations was owned by same person did not operate to create identity of corporate interests between companies, or create relationship of principal and agent, or representative, or alter ego between the two.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation case. An award of compensation by the Industrial Commission was affirmed on appeal by the Common Pleas Court, Anderson County, John Grimball, J. The Supreme Court, Lewis, J., held that tire recapping corporation, owned by same person as oil company, was not in reality a part of business operations of oil company, and oil company could not, on any such theory, be held liable for workmen's compensation for injury to tire recapping company employee. Reversed.
