Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Belk-Lindsey Co. v. Morse Sewing Center of New York City, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special and Trial Term, Part XXIX.
Headnote: Mere identity of officers and directors or stockholders is insufficient to overcome a separate corporate entity in order to predicate liability on an individual or another controlling corporation.
Document Preview: Action by department store to recover rent and other charges arising out of operation of leased sewing machine department. Defendants filed counterclaims. The Supreme Court, Special and Trial Term, Isidor Wasservogel, Special Referee, held that the evidence was sufficient to show that original contract between store and lessee was assigned with store's knowledge and consent, not to either of the defendants, but to a corporation which was not a party to the action. Judgment for defendants on the main case and in favor of plaintiff against both defendants on the counterclaims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Nolan v. Jensen
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Where stockholder had controlling interest in foreign corporation which was registered title owner of salvaged ship, but second corporation, which owned second ship, was susceptible of joint control by controlling stockholder of first corporation and another, each of whom had an equal number of shares in second corporation, corporate entity of second corporation would not be disregarded, and second ship was not subject to attachment in salvage action, in absence of fraud or libellants being lulled into any sense of security by misleading representations.
Document Preview: Salvage action, civil and maritime, instituted against partners and corporation which was registered title holder of salvaged vessel, in personam, wherein second ship was attached and respondents appeared specially and filed exceptions to jurisdiction and motions to quash service of process. The District Court, Walter E. Hoffman, J., held that where stockholder had controlling interest in foreign corporation which was registered title owner of salvaged ship, but second corporation, which owned second ship, was susceptible of joint control by controlling stockholder of first corporation and another, each of whom had an equal number of shares in second corporation, corporate entity of second corporation would not be disregarded, and second ship was not subject to attachment in salvage action, in absence of fraud or libellants being lulled into any sense of security by misleading representations. Motions to quash service of process and exceptions to jurisdiction sustained thereby...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Maule Industries, Inc. v. Gerstel
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Mere identity of corporate names, stockholders and officers, or the fact of ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another, are not sufficient to justify disregarding the corporate fiction.
Document Preview: Bankruptcy proceeding. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John W. Holland, J., entered an order reversing an order of a referee in bankruptcy requiring a corporation and its receiver under an order of the state court to turn over the corporate assets to a trustee in bankruptcy for a corporation allegedly in control of corporation in question, and creditor of bankrupt corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cameron, Circuit Judge, held that where petition of creditor of bankrupt seeking a turnover order alleged that bankrupt corporation controlled and directed another corporation as a corporate instrumentality, that the two corporations had the same officers, directors and stockholders, and that the affairs of corporation in question had been directed and dictated by bankrupt corporation and that the funds and activities of the two corporations had been so intermingled as to render them indistinguishable, such allegations were not sufficient...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Di Re v. Central Livestock Order Buying Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Ordinarily, two or more corporations are considered separate and distinct entities, even though the same individuals are the incorporators of or own stock in the several corporations, and even though such corporations may have the same persons as officers.
Document Preview: Unemployment compensation proceeding. The Department of Employment Security allowed benefits, and employer brought certiorari. The Supreme Court, Dell, C.J., held that commissioner's determination that proffered employment was unsuitable solely because it was not substantially the equivalent of work claimant had formerly been performing was error in view of fact that commissioner did not first determine claimant's prospects of securing local work in his customary occupation within reasonable period of time, and, therefore, matter would have to be remanded to commissioner for further evidence on such issue. Remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: American Anthracite & Bituminous Coal Corp. v. Amerocean S. S. Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: There must be something more than identity of officers as well as stock ownership in corporate set-ups in order to disregard the corporate fiction.
Document Preview: Libel in admiralty. On motion to vacate a writ of foreign attachment and to dismiss the libel on the ground that the respondent named as owner of the ship against which the writ issued was not the owner thereof and that the real owner was a Liberian corporation. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Ganey, J., held that the evidence did not justify disregarding the corporate entity of the Liberian corporation. Writ of foreign attachment dissolved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Clarke Auto Co. v. Fyffe
Court: Appellate Court of Indiana, In Banc.
Headnote: Generally, status of corporations as separate and distinct legal entities is not affected by fact that they have common officers and stockholders.
Document Preview: Action to recover price paid for automobile, on ground that seller, a corporation, did not have title thereto. The Circuit Court, Boone County, Charles F. Thompson, J., entered judgment for buyer, and defendant corporation appealed. The Appellate Court, Royse, J., held that where defendant corporation and associated corporation kept books and records at office of associated corporation, had confusingly similar names, and generally did business in such a manner that third parties had no way of knowing with whom they were dealing, and where buyer, was told to make check for automobile payable to defendant corporation, for purpose of action arising from sale the corporations were treated as merged, and defendant corporation could not escape liability by contending that associated corporation made the sale. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Slater v. Bright
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Where corporation closed down and another was formed, and there was interlocking relationship of officers and majority shareholders of both corporations, and affairs of two corporations were conducted informally and almost exclusively by the individuals who never considered corporations as entities, and meetings were not held regularly and minutes were rarely kept, and second corporation took over property and machinery of closed corporation and paid its debts, question of whether second corporation acted purely as volunteer in paying debts would be decided not by adherence to strict formality, but by nature and effect of all agreements, actual or implied, which could be deduced from conduct of parties.
Document Preview: Receivership proceedings wherein J. B. Bright, as receiver of the Bartlett Corporation, filed claim against the U. S. 60 Wood Mfg. Co., Inc., and as receiver of the latter corporation, filed claim against W. G. Slater, and wherein issue was whether payment by the Bartlett Corporation of the U. S. 60 Company's debts was payment by volunteer so that such amount would not be included for purposes of determining liability of shareholder of the U. S. 60 Company on his subscription. The Shelby Circuit Court, Rufus Lisle, J., entered judgment against Slater on his stock subscription and in computing same included amounts paid by the Bartlett Corporation on the U. S. 60 Company's debts, and Slater appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cullen, C., held that under the circumstances, the Bartlett Corporation was not a volunteer. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McComb v. Aibel
Court: United States District Court E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts will not destroy corporate entity merely because there is identity of control in parent and subsidiary corporations.
Document Preview: Action by William R. McComb, administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, United States Department of Labor, against Samuel H. Aibel and Harryette L. Aibel, co-partners, doing business under the trade name and style of French Textile Company, to enjoin defendants from violating the Fair Labor Standards Act. On plaintiff's motions for summary judgment and to vacate defendants' notice for taking depositions, and defendants' request to add a name to the notice, the District Court, Galston, J., held that the plaintiff was not entitled to a summary judgment where there was a genuine issue as to whether the corporation supplying defendants with materials and in which defendants owned 52 per cent of the stock conducted a substantial and separate business of its own, and as to whether defendants violated the recordkeeping requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act. Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment denied; motion to vacate notice of taking depositions granted in part, and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Galdi v. Caribbean Sugar Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock in several corporations by one person does not create a single unit or justify disregard of separate corporations, unless corporation is a sham or used to perpetrate deception to defeat public policy.
Document Preview: Joseph C. Galdi and others, holders of bonds issued by Caribbean Sugar Company, sued that company and others, to compel defendant National Shawmut Bank to account for funds allegedly held by it as constructive trustee for plaintiffs, consisting of proceeds of the sale of preferred stock of Caribbean Sugar Company. The Superior Court, Kirk, J., sustained a demurrer and dismissed the bill, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Williams, J., held that the bill did not show that the purchase of defendant corporation's preferred stock at allegedly excessive prices constituted a payment of dividend in violation of the indenture with bondholders, or a transaction fraudulent as to creditors under the showing made as to defendant bank's control of the corporation and its subsidiary who purchased the stock. Interlocutory and final decrees affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: General Motors Acceptance Corp. v. Commissioner of Banks
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Separate corporations with common stock ownership should not be treated as separate entities if reasonable regulation is hampered thereby.
Document Preview: General Motors Acceptance Corporation brought action against the Commissioner of Banks, formerly designated as Banking Commission, for a declaratory judgment that rule of the Banking Commission limiting automobile dealers' participation in charges made by automobile dealers to automobile buyers and defining dealer participation as including any amount collected from an automobile buyer as an insurance charge, if retained by dealer, was invalid. The Circuit Court for Dane County, Herman W. Sachtjen, J., rendered a judgment adverse to the plaintiff, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Broadfoot, J., held that the rule was not invalid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Surgical Supply Center v. Industrial Commission of Utah, Dept. of Employment Sec.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: The fact that stockholders of two corporations may be the same persons does not operate to destroy the legal identity of both corporations.
Document Preview: Original proceedings by the Surgical Supply Center, Inc., Professional Pharmacy, Inc., and others, against The Industrial Commission of Utah, Department of Employment Security, to review a decision of the Commission relating to the experience rating of employers for unemployment contribution purposes. The Supreme Court, Latimer, J., held that a corporation created to operate surgical supply business theretofore operated as separate enterprise of partnership as single employing unit and a second corporation created to operate pharmacy business theretofore operated as separate entity of partnership as a separate single employing unit did not acquire all or substantially all of assets of partnership as single employing unit, and hence were not entitled to experience rating of partnership. Order of Commission affirmed. Wade, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Rounds & Porter Lumber Co. v. Burns
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: A parent corporation is not liable for the debts of its subsidiary merely because parent corporation holds the controlling interest or because the two are managed by the same officers.
Document Preview: Suit by Homer Burns and wife against Rounds & Porter Lumber Company to hold defendant liable for lumber which defendants' subsidiary corporation was to process and sell as agent for plaintiffs, and for which subsidiary corporation had not accounted. The Chancery Court of Bradley County, D. A. Bradham, Chancellor, entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that the evidence warranted finding that defendant had wrongfully manipulated subsidiary corporation to its own advantage at expense of plaintiffs so as to entitle plaintiffs to a judgment directly against parent corporation, and affirmed the judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Minnesota Tribune Co. v. Commissioner of Taxation
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Generally, mere ownership by foreign corporation of stock in domestic corporation within state, and even of controlling interest therein does not in itself constitute doing business within state concerned in absence of circumstances justifying court in looking through form to substance of relationship between the two corporations.
Document Preview: Certiorari to Board of Tax Appeals. Certiorari proceeding by the Minnesota Tribune Company, successor by merger to Mutual Holding Company, to review a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals affirming an order of the Commissioner of Taxation determining an additional tax liability for the taxable year ending December 31, 1941. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Big Four Mills v. Commercial Credit Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Ownership of all, or substantially all, of the capital stock of one corporation by another corporation does not create an identity of corporate interest.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Kenton County; Joseph P. Goodenough, Judge. Suit by Commercial Credit Company, Inc., and others against Big Four Mills, Limited, to recover money due under a written contract, for accounting, and for appointment of a receiver. From the judgment, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Oceanic Insul-Lite Corp. v. Sullivan Dry Dock & Repair Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Control of one corporation by another through ownership of shares does not fuse the corporations, even if they have common directors, but one corporation will be legally responsible where it has become an actor in a given transaction, or in part of the business of another corporation, through immediate direction of its own officers.
Document Preview: Action by Oceanic Insul-Lite Corporation against Sullivan Dry Dock & Repair Corporation to recover a balance allegedly due for certain services performed and materials furnished for repair and conversion of a certain steamship. On motion by plaintiff to strike out defendant's answer and for summary judgment, on ground that there was no defense to the action. Motion for summary judgment granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Forest Hill Corp. v. Latter & Blum
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: The mere fact that some or all of the stockholders or officials of two corporations are identical or because one corporation dominates the other, does not, of itself, destroy the corporate identity or merge one into the other, but the legal fiction of separate corporate entity should not be so extended as to enable a corporation to become a vehicle to evade just responsibility.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Mobile County; Cecil F. Bates, Judge. Action to recover real estate broker's commission by Latter & Blum, Inc., against Forest Hill Corporation. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hordin v. City of Cleveland
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The separate corporate entities of a parent and subsidiary corporation will not be disregarded in the absence of proof that subsidiary was formed for fraudulent purposes, and the fact that the stock of a company is owned by a municipal corporation does not change the rule.
Document Preview: MORGAN, J., dissenting in part. Action by Philip Hordin, as taxpayer, against City of Cleveland and others to enjoin carrying out provisions of certain contracts allegedly entered into contrary to law. From a judgment for plaintiff, the defendants appeal.[Editorial Statement.] Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Eisenbarth v. Equity Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: St. Louis Court of Appeals, Missouri.
Headnote: Interlocking directorates, close association of several corporations, and domination of them by single officer are not sufficient to require disregard of separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Appeal from St. Louis Circuit Court, Robert L. Aronson, Judge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another or interlocking directorship does not create an identity of corporate interests or create relation of principal and agent or representative, unless such ownership has been resorted to, not for purpose of participating in affairs of corporation in normal and usual manner, but for purpose of controlling a subsidiary company so that it may be used as a mere agency or instrumentality of owning company or companies.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; J. D. Moore, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas against Swift & Company and Consumers Cotton Oil Company to recover from first-named defendant statutory penalties for doing business in the state without a permit, to cancel first-named defendant's permit to do business in the state, and to forfeit the corporate charter of the other defendant. From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: The same persons may form as many separate corporations to carry on as many separate businesses as they wish.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; J. D. Moore, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas against Swift & Company and Consumers Cotton Oil Company to recover from first-named defendant statutory penalties for doing business in the state without a permit, to cancel first-named defendant's permit to do business in the state, and to forfeit the corporate charter of the other defendant. From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts will not, because of stock ownership or interlocking directorship, disregard the separate legal entities of corporations unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violations of the anti-trust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; J. D. Moore, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas against Swift & Company and Consumers Cotton Oil Company to recover from first-named defendant statutory penalties for doing business in the state without a permit, to cancel first-named defendant's permit to do business in the state, and to forfeit the corporate charter of the other defendant. From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts will not disregard the separate corporate entities of parent and subsidiary corporations if a separate adequate financial unit is set up for each, day to day business of each unit is kept separate, formal barriers between the two management structures are maintained, and the two units are not represented as being one unit.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; J. D. Moore, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas against Swift & Company and Consumers Cotton Oil Company to recover from first-named defendant statutory penalties for doing business in the state without a permit, to cancel first-named defendant's permit to do business in the state, and to forfeit the corporate charter of the other defendant. From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Ohio Tank Car Co. v. Keith Ry. Equipment Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, corporations do not lose their identity merely because they are owned by same stockholders and have same officers and occupy same office rooms as other corporations.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division; William J. Campbell, Judge. Action by Ohio Tank Car Company against Keith Railway Equipment Company to recover a sum of money alleged to have been earned in the form of mileage allowances on certain tank cars owned by defendant and leased to plaintiff, wherein the defendant filed a counterclaim. From a judgment dismissing the complaint and ordering payment of the counterclaim, the plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mannon v. R. A. Young & Sons Coal Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: All corporations, regardless of fact that stockholders and officers are identical, are separate and distinct legal entities, and, in absence of facts on which liability would be predicated, one corporation is not liable for debts of another.
Document Preview: Appeal from Chancery Court, Sebastian County, Fort Smith District; C. M. Wofford, Chancellor. Action by Aster Mannon, and others against R. A. Young & Sons Coal Company to have the defendant corporation adjudge to be the same, single identity as the Bates Coal & Mining Company, a corporation, against which plaintiffs recovered judgments, and for other equitable relief. The complaint was dismissed on motion, and plaintiffs appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Massachusetts Bonding & Ins. Co. v. Master Laboratories
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Where an individual owns all or substantially all of the stock of several corporations and such corporations are but the juristic double of the owner, and fraud or injustice will likely operate to the injury of third persons, the separate identity of the corporations is dissipated and the corporations are held for the acts of the owner or vice versa, and the rule is the same although the stock of such corporations is owned by two or more who act in conjunction with the corporate organization.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Douglas County; Fitzgerald, Judge. Action by Massachusetts Bonding & Insurance Company against the Master Laboratories, Incorporated, on a special indemnity agreement. Municipal Court judgment was appealed by defendant to the District Court. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: M. McDonough Corp. v. Connolly
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Essex.
Headnote: "Corporations" are distinct entities, and, even where identity of stockholders in control of contracting corporation exists, this does not operate to "merge" the corporations into one or to make either the "agent" of the other.
Document Preview: Exceptions from Superior Court, Essex County; Morton, Judge. Action of contract by M. McDonough Corporation against Michael B. Connolly for value of labor and materials allegedly furnished the defendant by the plaintiff. The case was heard by superior court judge sitting without jury on report of auditor whose findings of fact were not to be final. The trial judge allowed plaintiff's motion for judgment on the report, and the defendant brings exceptions. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Dregne v. Five Cent Cab Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: The fact that shareholders of two corporations are identical or facts that one corporation owns shares in another corporation and that they had mutual dealings, do not require that they be regarded as single entity.
Document Preview: Action by Carol Dregne against the Five Cent Cab Company, the Yellow Cab Company, and others, for personal injuries. From a judgment of the Appellate Court, 313 Ill.App. 539,40 N.E.2d 539, affirming a judgment for defendant Yellow Cab Company, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Dregne v. Five Cent Cab Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: The courts will not disregard a corporation's corporate entity and treat it as another corporation's alter ego, though such other corporation owns all of first corporation's stock, unless there is such unity of interest and ownership that individuality of one corporation and owners of its stock has ceased and observance of fiction of separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action by Carol Dregne against the Five Cent Cab Company, the Yellow Cab Company, and others, for personal injuries. From a judgment of the Appellate Court, 313 Ill.App. 539,40 N.E.2d 539, affirming a judgment for defendant Yellow Cab Company, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Kelley, Glover & Vale v. Heitman
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: A "subsidiary" or "auxiliary corporation" which is created by a parent corporation merely as an agency for the latter may sometimes be regarded as identical with the parent corporation, especially if stockholders or officers of the two corporations are substantially the same or their systems of operation unified.
Document Preview: Action by Elmer W. Heitman, receiver of the First National Bank of Gary, Indiana, against Kelley, Glover and Vale, Inc., and others on a note and for foreclosure and sale of pledged collateral, wherein the defendants filed a counterclaim. From an adverse judgment defendants appealed to the Appellate Court and the case was transferred to the Supreme Court under Burns' Ann.St. § 4215. Judgment affirmed. Superseding opinion of the Appellate Court, 40 N.E.2d 408. Roll, J., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Seattle Ass'n of Credit Men v. Daniels
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: To invoke rule permitting corporate entities to be disregarded, something more than common ownership of stock and common management must be shown.
Document Preview: Department 2. Action by the Seattle Association of Credit Men, as common-law assignee of Eba's Incorporated, against Olaf B. Daniels and Oscar E. Turnquist, copartners, doing business under the firm style and name of Daniels and Turnquist, to recover, as a preference, a payment made by plaintiff's assignor to the defendant. From a judgment dismissing the action, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: De Stubner v. Microid Process
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: The fact that a corporation had officers, directors, agents and employees in common with another corporation does not, of itself, justify disregard of the entities of the corporations.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Kanawha County. Suit in equity by Emile C. deStubner against Microid Process, Incorporated, United Carbon Company, Incorporated, and the United Carbon Company, to cancel an exclusive and nonassignable license and right to sublicense from plaintiff to Microid Process, Incorporated, under plaintiff's patents, and a concomitant agreement between Microid Process, Incorporated, and United Carbon Company, Incorporated, for an exclusive license as to the field covered by part of the patents and to recapture the plaintiff's patent process and invention. From a decree in favor of the plaintiff as against Microid Process, Incorporated, and the United Carbon Company, Incorporated, those defendants appeal. Decree reversed in part and affirmed in part, and cause remanded for entry of decree in conformity with opinion. FOX, President, dissenting in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Hart, Schaffner & Marx v. Campbell
Court: Appellate Court of Indiana, in Banc.
Headnote: The fact that officers of one corporation were also officers and stockholders of another corporation would not, of itself, authorize conclusion that one of the corporations was fictitious.
Document Preview: Appeal from Industrial Board. Proceeding under the Workmen's Compensation Act by Mary L. Campbell, employee, opposed by Hart, Schaffner & Marx, a corporation, alleged employer. The Industrial Board made an award of compensation and the alleged employer appeals. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bank of California, N.A. v. American Fruit Growers
Court: District Court, E.D. Washington, Northern Division.
Headnote: Where business is transacted with various corporations, some of which are wholly owned and some partly owned by one of the corporations, and where there are interlocking directorates and interchanging officers, the court will zealously guard against any misuse of such corporate devices, and will scrutinize more carefully transactions carried out through such media.
Document Preview: Action by Bank of California, N.A., a national banking association, against American Fruit Growers, Incorporated, to recover on an alleged agreement and for conversion of mortgaged fruit crops. Judgment in accordance with opinion. See, also, 37 F.Supp. 1017.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bank of California, N.A. v. American Fruit Growers
Court: District Court, E.D. Washington, Northern Division.
Headnote: The use of wholly-owned subsidiaries and mutual officers and directors is not malum per se.
Document Preview: Action by Bank of California, N.A., a national banking association, against American Fruit Growers, Incorporated, to recover on an alleged agreement and for conversion of mortgaged fruit crops. Judgment in accordance with opinion. See, also, 37 F.Supp. 1017.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Wiseman v. Sierra Highland Mining Co.
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: The mere fact that investment company owned 75 per cent. of outstanding stock and rights in mining company and that an individual owned a large majority of outstanding stock of the investment company did not place stamp of fraud on activities which were not consummated for a dishonest or fraudulent purpose.
Document Preview: Department 1. Quiet title action by A. L. Wiseman and others against the Sierra Highland Mining Company and others, wherein Julia M. Thorne and others intervened. From a judgment for defendants, plaintiffs and interveners appeal. Plaintiffs' appeal dismissed, and judgment against interveners affirmed.

Title: Press Co. v. National Labor Relations Board
Court: United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Headnote: A parent corporation's ownership of stock of subsidiary, and identity of officers of parent and subsidiary, do not create agency relation so as to make parent responsible for act of subsidiary, but there must be such control by parent as to show that subsidiary is being used as the instrument of the parent.
Document Preview: RUTLEDGE, Associate Justice, dissenting in part. On Petitions for Review of Order of National Labor Relations Board. Proceedings by the Press Company, Inc., and by the Gannett Company, Inc., to review an order of the National Labor Relations Board. In the first case, the Tri-City Newspaper Guild and others intervened. Order enforced as modified.

Title: Fish v. East
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Whether subsidiary is mere "instrumentality" of parent corporation so as to permit disregarding the corporate entity depends on whether parent corporation owns a majority of the capital stock of subsidiary, the parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers, the parent corporation finances subsidiary, the subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, the parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, the subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation, the subsidiary is referred to as such by parent corporation or as a department or division, the directors or executives of subsidiary do not act in the interests of subsidiary, but take direction from parent corporation, and the formal requirements of the subsidiary as an independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: 37. Bankruptcy 467(4) 4A finding by the referee in bankruptcy upon conflicting evidence, where affirmed by the District Judge and supported by substantial evidence, may not be set aside by the Circuit Court of Appeals on review. Appeals from the District Court of the United States for the District of Colorado; J. Foster Symes, Judge. Proceeding between Erland F. Fish and others and John H. East, Jr., as trustee in bankruptcy of the Royal Tiger Mines Company, bankrupt, involving a turnover order.  Action by Erland F. Fish against John H. East, Jr., as trustee in bankruptcy of the Royal Tiger Mines Company, a bankrupt, to require the trustee to convey certain property to plaintiff, and to quiet title thereto.  Proceeding between Erland F. Fish and others and John H. East, Jr., as trustee in bankruptcy of the Royal Tiger Mines Company, bankrupt, also involving a turnover order.  Proceeding by Harry Cohen, doing business as Samuel Cohen Company, and others...

Title: Wade & Wade v. Central Broadcasting Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: The determination of the question whether one corporation is a mere agency or instrumentality or is identical with another depends on whether members, officers and objects of corporations are the same and the presence or absence of distinct interests of the two corporations.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Polk County; Russell Jordan, Judge. Appeal from order overruling motions to strike on the ground of misjoinder. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Lawyers Mortg. Co., Premises 6801 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, N.Y., Plan 1958-A
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: One corporation is not liable for the acts of another corporation merely because it owns all the stock of the second company and can control its activities nor because the two corporations have directors or officers in common.
Document Preview: Proceeding in the matter of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, Premises 6801 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, New York, Plan 1958A. On motion by the Superintendent of Insurance, as liquidator of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, to compel the Title Guarantee & Trust Company, as trustee for certificate holders in a bond and mortgage covering premises 6801 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, New York, to register a certificate held by him as liquidator and for an order declaring and adjudicating such certificate to be on a parity and entitled to share equally with certificates in the mortgage, and directing the trustee to pay over to him all moneys held by it with respect to principal and interest, as well as all future moneys collected on account of such certificate. Motion granted in all respects.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Kentucky Electric Power Co. v. Norton Coal Mining Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The mere ownership of all the stock of one corporation by another and identity of officers of the two corporations are not alone sufficient to create identity of corporate interest or to create the relation of principal and agent or to create a representative or fiduciary relationship between the two corporations.
Document Preview: Appeals from the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Kentucky; Elwood Hamilton, Judge. Consolidated receivership and mortgage foreclosure actions instituted by creditors against the Norton Coal Mining Company and others, wherein the Kentucky Electric Power Company filed an intervening petition.  From the decree, the Kentucky Electric Power Company, the Norton Coal Mining Company and others appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Raymond-Eldredge Co. v. Security Realty Inv. Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Where a dominant individual who owns substantially all beneficial interest creates several corporations and vests in them legal title to his property and endeavors to separate ownership among them, though in reality it is substantially all his, court will look through form of legal entities to real owners and to controlling power, and impute his knowledge to all of his corporations.
Document Preview: Appeals from the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Kentucky; Hiram Church Ford, Judge. Suit by the Security Realty Investment Company against the Wiedemann Brewing & Distilling Company, Walter B. Weaver, receiver, to foreclose upon a vendor's lien in a deed of the brewery property, wherein the Raymond-Eldredge Company, Inc., on behalf of itself and other stockholders of the same class, intervened and sought to establish a lien in favor of preference stockholders in the brewery property, to cancel common stock issued to the Pollak Securities Corporation, and its assignee, the 270 Park Avenue Corporation, as promoters of the brewery corporation, and for a disallowance of their claim to promotion fees represented by notes. From an adverse order and decree, the intervener appeals. Order and decree affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McLean v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Legal fiction of separate entities of two corporations of which stock is owned by same parties should be disregarded when necessary for prevention of fraud or to protect legal rights of third parties.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Texas; Randolph Bryant, Judge. Action by Marrs McLean against the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Incorporated. Judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gillis v. Jenkins Petroleum Process Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Organization of one company by another, or ownership of all stock of one company by another, or common officers and directors, or all such elements combined, are insufficient to defeat separate corporate entity.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of California, Central Division; Frank H. Kerrigan, Judge. Proceeding in the matter of receivership of the Western Oil & Refining Company, wherein the Jenkins Petroleum Process Company intervened. From a decree, Robert C. Gillis, as receiver of the Western Oil & Refining Company, appeals. Reversed and remanded, with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Fickling Properties v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Florida, Division A.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded in equity, where two or more separate corporations are controlled or owned by same individuals and are used merely as convenience for accomplishing an unconscionable transaction.
Document Preview: Suit by Jessie C. Smith, joined by her husband, Lorrain G. Smith and others, against the Fickling Properties, Inc., and others. From an adverse decree, defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Adams v. Morgan
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Where bankrupt actually owned all stock of corporation and four other record owners were nominal stockholders only, and bankrupt had for years directed all policies of corporation, trial court properly disregarded theory of corporate entity and permitted trustee in bankruptcy to take possession of bankrupt's stock certificates and to manage corporation for benefit of creditors, in compliance with order of referee in bankruptcy. Bankr.Act § 70, sub. a(5), 11 U.S.C.A. § 110, sub. a(5).
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Osage County; Robert T. Price, Judge. Action by Eva Lee Adams, as administratrix of the estate of D. D. Adams, deceased, against S. R. Morgan, wherein Ed Blisden, trustee in bankruptcy of S. R. Morgan, and H. Wade intervened and A. R. Jones and others were made additional defendants. From an adverse judgment, additional defendants and secondnamed intervener appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Cleary v. Higley
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Trial Term.
Headnote: Where three corporations had existed long before the intercorporate acts alleged to be wrongful to subsidiary corporation, various corporate entities could not be disregarded in determining validity of transactions, although the three corporations had some officers, directors, and stockholders in common.
Document Preview: Action by James N. Cleary and Fannie Lurie, suing on behalf of themselves and all other stockholders of the Fox Film Corporation similarly situated, and in the right of the Fox Film Corporation, against Charles W. Higley and others, wherein Gustav Oppenheimer intervened as a plaintiff. On defendants' motions to dismiss the complaint. Complaint dismissed as to all defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pittsburgh Reflector Co. v. Dwyer & Rhodes Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Mere common ownership of capital stock, interlocking directorates, or like evidences of close association, will not justify courts in disregarding corporate identities.

Title: Pittsburgh Reflector Co. v. Dwyer & Rhodes Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Corporate identities of two corporations owned by same person but carrying on separate businesses under separate management could not be disregarded because one corporation borrowed money from another, in absence of finding that such dealing tended to defraud or created confusion in corporations' affairs.
Document Preview: Department 2. Appeal from Superior Court, King County; J. B. Alexander, Judge pro tem. Action by the Pittsburgh Reflector Company against the Dwyer & Rhodes Company, Inc., and others. From an adverse judgment, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Pittsburgh Reflector Co. v. Dwyer & Rhodes Co.

Headnote: That borrowing corporation obtained money from corporation owned by same person owning borrowing corporation is not of itself badge of fraud justifying disregard of corporate identities.

Title: Continental Supply Co. v. Forrest E. Gilmore Co. of Texas

Headnote: Legal fiction of separate entities of corporations, stock of which is owned by same parties, should be disregarded, when necessary to prevent fraud or protect third parties' legal rights.

Title: Continental Supply Co. v. Forrest E. Gilmore Co. of Texas
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Amarillo.
Headnote: Courts will disregard legal fiction of separate entities of corporations, stock of which is owned by same parties, where fiction is used to perpetrate fraud, evade legal obligation, achieve or perpetrate monopoly, circumvent statute, protect crime, or justify wrong, or when one corporation is organized and operated as another's mere tool or business conduit.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Gray County; W. R. Ewing, Judge. Suit by the Continental Supply Company against the Forrest E. Title: Dobbins v. Pratt Chuck Co.

Headnote: Corporate entity may not be used as instrument of fraud, and court of equity may prevent any fraud, unfairness, or mutual mistake growing out of existence of two corporations under same ownership.

Title: Henry Waterhouse Trust Co. v. Home Ins. Co. of Hawaii
Court: Supreme Court of the Territory of Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Mere fact that stockholders in two corporations are the same or that one corporation owns shares in another or even majority of shares or that two corporations have many dealings with each other will not ordinarily suffice to show that one is mere instrumentality of other.
Document Preview: As a general rule the knowledge of the officers and agents of a corporation is deemed to be the knowledge of the corporation; but when the officer whose knowledge is sought to be charged to the corporation aids or abets or participates in a fraud upon the corporation for the benefit of himself or another, his knowledge is not imputable to the corporation. The ordinary presumption is that when a corporation has been formed in the manner provided by law it continues to have existence as a separate and distinct entity. When it is claimed that a corporation is in reality not a separate entity but is merely an adjunct or department or instrumentality of another corporation for purposes of fraud, the burden rests upon those so contending to prove the fact. Upon the undisputed evidence in this case, held that it was correct to instruct the jury that two certain corporations were separate and distinct entities.

Title: Seymour v. Woodstock & Sycamore Traction Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: The fact that two corporations have same president, or same president and same secretary, or that one of corporations, a construction corporation, agrees to pay in part for work done by delivering bonds or stock of another corporation, does not prove that the two corporations are the same, nor does fact that one corporation owns majority of stock in another, if it can lawfully hold such stock, prove that they are same, or that one is dummy for the other and that what one corporation does the other really does also.

Title: Ft. Smith Light & Traction Co. v. Kelley
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: The fact that some of the stockholders and officers in one corporation were stockholders and officers in another corporation did not establish the identity of the corporations, nor make the acts of one the acts of the other.

Title: Ohio & M.R. Co. v. Wheeler
Court: Supreme Court of the United States
Headnote: Two corporations existing under the laws of adjoining states, although composed of the same corporators, cannot be joined in suits as one plaintiff by one name.
Document Preview: 1. A corporation exists only in contemplation of law, and by force of law, and can have no legal existence beyond the bounds of the sovereignty by which it is created. It must dwell in the place of its creation. 2. A corporation is not a citizen within the meaning of the Constitution of the United States, and cannot maintain a suit in a court of the United States against the citizen of a different State from that by which it was chartered, unless the persons who compose the corporated body are all citizens of that State. 3. In such case they may sue by their corporate name, averring the citizenship of all the members, and such a suit would be regarded as the joint suit of individual persons, united together in the corporate body and acting under the name conferred upon them for the more convenient transaction of business, and consequently entitled to maintain a suit in the courts of the United States against a citizen of another State. 4.
